We have lost in the mist of centuries the folk events underlying such invitingly titled Scottish dances as "The Sow's Tail," "The Rock and the Wee Pickle Tow" and "Old Jim's Lumber Room." It is imperative, then, to set down the true-life tale of the newest Scottish country dance, "MacDougall's Fancy."
The stock market finished mixed yesterday in slower trading, the Dow Jones industrial average rising 0.35 point to 836.11.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 Arab members of the United Nations, in political disarray over President Anwar el-Sadat's visit to Israel, appeared today to be trying to close ranks as they sat down together for their first private group meeting since the events in Jerusalem.

Adeline Trapp Muhlenberg, who was called "Queen of Hellgate" in 1909 for being the first woman to swim that swirling East River channel, died in Brooklyn Methodist Hospital yesterday. She was 89 years old and lived at 386 Parkside Avenue, Brooklyn.

TORRINGTON, Wyo., Nov. 21 (UPI) Peter M. Kelly, the Colorado-Wyoming news editor for United Press International, died here Friday of an apparent heart attack before he could begin research on the story he planned to write about high school graduates of the 1960's and their lives 10 years later. He was 38 years old.

Shows will be running in-all 16 Shubert theaters in New York City this week and their marquees will remain lighted up at least into next year, the first time there has been such sustained prosperity on Broadway in more than 20 years.

In designing reforms to reduce or eliminate unjustified tax preferences, the Administration will take into account the importance of tax incentives for "capital formation, both for corporations and for individuals," Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal promised yesterday.

Charges and rumors floated just before the recent election hinting that Representative Edward I. Koch was a homosexual were found yesterday completely baseless by the City's Department of Investgiation.

ATLANTA, Nov. 21 Two New York experts, Kathie Wel and Judi Radin led into the final session of the life master women's pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals here tonight.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 245,391 shares in the month ended Nov. 15 to 33,322,411 shares, a new high. The short interest for the year earlier level totaled 24,777,197 shares.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) Five years after signing a treaty restricting antiballistic missile systems, the United States and the Soviet Union reported today that the pact was operating effectively and needed no revision.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) A scrambling Joe Theismann threw a 7yard touchdown pass to Mike Thomas late in the fourth quarter tonight, enabling the Washington Redskins to edge the Green Bay Packers, 10-9, and remain alive in the National Football League playoff sweepstakes.
After more than a full year of its controversial Sunday openings here, R.H. Macy Company, the area's biggest retailer, has come up with a measure of their full worth.

Disclosure of preliminary test results indicating 4 link between the birchwood sweetener xylitol and cancer in laboratory animals has put the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company--now marketing nationally a xylitol-sweetened chewing gum called Orbit--under a cloud of uncertainty.

Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch and the man he has designated to be his first deputy mayor, Edward N. Costikyan, tried yesterday to damp down the first controversy of the budding Koch administration--a controversy that arose when Mr. Costikyan raised the possibility that he might not accept the post because of Mr. Koch's plans to de-emphasize it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22--In a move to achieve formal rights and recognition for Reform Judaism in Israel, delegates of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations have voted to establish a Zionist-affiliated body to seek membership in the World Zionist Organization.
A judge in Connecticut Superior Court ruled yesterday that Peter A. Reilly, whose conviction for the 1973 slaying of his mother was overturned last year, could not be retried.

PRODUCTION OF MOVIES and plays in New York may both be up this year, but the chairman of a State Senate subcom mittee nevertheless yesterday urged the creation of a state authority with the power to generate as much as $25 million a year for the rehabilitation of the theaters and the opening of new film and videotape production facilities.

For years, Linda Wasserstein, a dedicated bread baker and pastry-making teacher from Long Island, searched for a way to make old-fashioned homemade bread that was moist on the inside, crusty on the outside. She experimented with clay flowerpots, toyed with the idea of building a brick oven in her backyard and even approached several manufacturers to create a bread pan that would allow cooks to create crusty "bakery" bread at home.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 22--A top Jordanian official said today that President Anwar el-Sadat's peace mission to Israel had achieved its purpose, opening the road to progress toward a Middle East peace settlement.
Individual investors apparently stepped up their purchases of Treasury notes yesterday as the Federal Government sold $3.77 billion of two-year securities at an average rate of 7.13 percent.

The Polaroid Corporation has cut off all shipments to South Africa following disclosures that its distributor there was secretly selling film to the South African Government in violation of a 1971 agreement, the company announced yesterday.

A second former official of the Central Intelligence Agency who served in South Vietnam accused the agency yesterday of leaving behind its Vietnamese allies and collaborators and then covering up the evacuation failures.

Like Anthony Braxton, with whom he has worked closely, Mr. Smith treads the elusive borderlines between "jazz," classical avant-garde and ethnic musics. One puts the word "jazz" in quotation marks because, for musicians of this sort, jazz is considered yet another form of improvisatory music.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--In an attempt to reduce birth defects, the Food and Drug Administration is seeking to have labels placed on containers of liquor, beer and wine warning pregnant women that the excessive use of alcoholic beverages may harm their babies.

Kansas City has emerged as a candidate (with Boston, Houston and Montreal) for a franchise in the North American Soccer League.

MATITIAHU BRAUN showed that he had more than one string to his bow Monday night in Town Halt by per forming on both the violin and viola. The two principal works of the evening, Schubert's "Arpeggione" Sonata and Grieg's Violin Sonata No. 3, in C minor, are sweetly lyrical compositions, and they proved to be admirable vehicles for Mr. Braun's cultured artistry on each instrument.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 22 (AP)-- Superior Court Judge Irving Levine, saying "sufficent reason" exists for a recount, today ordered a recount of the recent controversial election of First Selectman in Greenwich.

Rich Gossage, whose father "almost but not quite" struck it rich in the gold fields of Cripple Creek, Colo., in the 1940's, struck gold on his own in New York yesterday. The right-handed relief pitcher signed a six-year contract with the Yankees believed to be worth $3.6 million.

A Congressional subcommittee subpoenaed records of the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday, less than a week after the subcommittee's chairman had warned the association not to interefere with the panel's investigation.

THE NEW WORKS commissioned by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center tend to be taken like so much medi cine by its conservative audiences. Not so Frank Lewin's "Variations of Greek Themes," which had its first performance at the society's concert late Sunday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall. The piece gave every indication of being a genuine crowd pleaser.

Patricia Garvan Grover, daughter of Hope Jackson Garvan of New York and the late Francis P. Garvan Jr., was married yesterday in Bogart, Ga., to Alan Graham-Collier, professor of the philosophy of art at the University of Georgia. The Rev. William Larkm Power, professor of the philosophy of religion at Georgia and a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home. _ _ _ _ .

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--A coalition of civil lights, labor, religious and community organizations threw its weight today behind the Humphrey-Hawkins full employment bill endorsed last week by President Carter. TWO hundred eighty-four years ago tomorrow the first American in my family ate a drumstick at the Plymouth Colony's first Thanksgiving dinner. Did he enjoy the wild turkey that was shot down? The red corn, the dry beans, the squash pudding? It's something I don't suppose, at this late date, we'll ever know.
This recipe and the one below are those of Fernande Allard, as included in "Grandes Dames de la Cuisine" by Madeleine Peter.

BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S "Peter Grimes" returned to the Metropolitan Opera Monday night for the first time since the 1972 73 season, for the delectaction of those who regard it as one of the high-water marks of 20th-century music theater. The revival, presented in tribute to the memory of the late British composer, brought back Jon. Vickers in the title role, which he made his own in previous Metropolitain performances.

HACKENSACK, Nov. 22--A Bergen County grand jury charged today that two Greek immigrants, operating from a small travel agency in Teaneck, had embezzled $565,000 from five airlines. Both men returned to Greece last December, and the Bergen County Prosecutor, Roger W. Breslin Jr., said that his office had asked the State Department to invoke the nation's extradition treaty with Greece in an attempt to return the men here for trial.

BRASILIA, Nov. 22--Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance urged Brazil's leaders today to reconsider their commitment to a nuclear-energy program using plutonium fuel, calling it uneconomic and politically hazardous.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--The Government reported today another modest increase in the inflation rate with a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index for October.

ATLANTA, Nov. 22 (AP)--Fred Turner, owner of the Atlanta Braves, today named Bobby Cox manager of his National League team and said he hoped the former coach of the world champion Yankees would "lead us to the promised land." Turner said Cox, 36 years old and the youngest manager in the major leagues, was signed to a two-year contract. Salary terms were not disclosed.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22-- Egypt's chief delegate walked out of the General Assembly today in protest against a Syrian speech in which the visit of President Anwar el-Sadat to Israel was denounced as a "visit of shame" and a "stab in the back of the Arab people."

The marriage of Rochelle Hilsenrath, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Yakov R. Hilsenrath of Highland Park, N.J., to Philip Goldschmiedt took place last evening at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadow. queens. The bride's father, rabbi of the Highland Park Jewish Center, officiated with the bride's brother, Rabbi Baruch M. Hilsenrath. Eight other rabbis and a cantor also participated.

TOKYO, Nov. 22--Earlier this fall NHK, Japan's semi-Governmental television network, dispatched a film crew to Youngstown, Ohio, to get local reactions to the steel-import controversy rising between the United States and Japan.
The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday that it would open 44 of its branches on Saturday and one on Sunday, from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. beginning this weekend.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22--The Chicago City Council voted unanimously this morning to establish a special committee of 18 aldermen to investigate the controversy resulting from charges by a former aide that Mayor Michael E. Bilandic conspired with a taxi company official to get fares increased.
Komisar: When did you begin to change your attitude toward the Soviet Union?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured White Weld Company, Kidder Peabody Company and Butcher Singer Inc. for minor violations of the agency's reporting requirements.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22--The startling political events of this Thanksgiving week can hardly be understood without paying some attention to the moral and religious convictions of President Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Begin of Israel--a couple of true believers who, like Jimmy Carter, proclaimed their religious faith before they took office.

Concorde airliners from London and Paris yesterday began their long-blocked trial passenger service to Kennedy International Airport, the gateway that the operators of the supersonic craft have deemed essential if they are to have any hope of turning a profit.

A psychiatrist testifying for the defense reiterated under cross-examination yesterday that Robert Torsney, the police officer accused of fatally shooting a Brooklyn youth last Nov. 25, acted reflexively during an epileptic psychomotor seizure.
A good thing for Graham Marsh that he wasn't in New York yesterday. Had he been, the 33-year-old Australian golf professional would have been made to feel as old as Sam Snead.

With a rapid series of multimilliondollar deals making baseball look like a game between General Motors and IBM, Oscar Gamble crept quietly into the vault yesterday and made out like J. Paul Getty.

New York's real estate tax structure is notoriously Byzantine, with loopholes the size of Hagia Sophia. The Tax Commission has been doing its best to close the larger escape tunnels and to return some of the city's unusually large number of tax-exempt properties to the tax rolls. The effort is commendable, both as a way of helping a city in distress and as a move toward equity.
Dr. Beatrice Kassell, a research scientist, died Monday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston of complications that followed brain surgery. She was 65 years old.
The state's Board of Public Utilities approved a plan to tack an additional $4.12 on an average Public Service Electric Gas Company gas bill by implementing a fuel-adjustment clause.

The Source WHY DO curators of the Metropolitan Museum, Winterthur Museum and the Victoria and Albert Museum go to High Point, N.C.? Not to attend the twice-yearly Southern Furniture Market. They go to visit High Point's Furniture Library an institution that is the best-kept secret in the furniture industry.

The credit markets rose slightly in price yesterday, at least partly because many traders were anticipating that the Federal Reserve would report something of a decline tomorrow in the nation's money supply for the week ended Nov. 16.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 23 Saying that the time was ripe for peace negotiations with all Arab foes, Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan told the nation today that Israel had to decide, and soon, on its "lastditch" attitude on the questions of ultimate borders, on a solution to the Palestinian problem and on the nature of the peace to be negotiated.

MACUTO, Venezuela, Nov. 23 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that he had been unable to persuade President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela that an oil price freeze should be imposed next year.

VIJAYAVADA, India, Nov. 23 When President N. Sanjiva Reddy arrived in this city this afternoon for a two-day inspec- tion of the flooded coastal region of southeastern India, his first caution to the reporters and officials greeting him was, "Let us not get panicky" in estimating the death toll.

MASHPEE, Mass., Nov. 23 The rustic wooden signs at the town limits, erected as a centennial project in 1970 when feelings were different here, proclaimed that this is "Mashpee Land of the Wampanoag." But the signs have taken on an ironic meaning since the Indians filed a lawsuit 15 months ago to recover all 16,000 acres of the town.
ZURICH, Nov. 23 (Reuters) A Russian Orthodox monk was recently released after 40 years in a Soviet prison camp and placed in a, psychiatric clinic in Kazan, a Swiss religious rights group said today.
Two nonpolitical committees of prominent businessmen yesterday recommended that New York City raise the salaries of more than 2,000 policy-making executives from managers up to mayor.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 23 Mark Gerard, the veterinarian accused at switching racehorses at Belmont Park, won the right to return to his equine practice today.

NEWARK, Nov. 23 A Bergen County man-wearing a bulletproof vest because of an attempt on his life earlier this year was shot and wounded yesterday by a nervous, almost apologetic, gunman just before he was to testify on a $7 million Florida real-estate bankruptcy case in which he was a principal.

JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 23 (AP) A prominent South African economist and his wife were found shot and stabbed to death in their home near here early today. Indecipherable words had been sprayed in foot-high letters with red paint in two rooms of the house.
BOSTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) Dave Cowens scored 22 points and six other Boston players scored in double figures tonight as the Celtics defeated the Houston Rockets, 109-100.

OTTAWA, Nov. 23 In a decision that requires the return of hundreds of millions of dollars to oil companies, the Supreme Court of Canada ruled today that the taxes and surcharges levied by the government of Saskatchewan on oil produced in that province were unconstitutional.

TRENTON, Nov. 23 The Assembly has scheduled a vote for Monday on a bill to lower the age of criminal responsibility from 16 to 14 years. The action is in line with a recent trend within the state to try to bring spreading juvenile crime under control.
The Hewlett-Packard Company reported yesterday a 1.8 percent drop in earnings for the fourth fiscal quarter but a 33.8 percent rise for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31.

The maestro settled for two all beef patties, special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles, onions on a sesame seed bun, and the band played on. MOSCOW, Nov. 23 The Soviet Union has reduced its imports from the capitalist world by nearly $2 billion so far this year from 1976 levels, according to official figures made public here today.
The Hewlett-Packard Company reported yesterday a 1.8 percent drop in earnings for the fourth fiscal quarter but a 33.8 percent rise for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31.

Edward N. Costikyan, who had been one of Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch's closest advisers during his election campaign, said yesterday that he would not serve in the Koch administration because the new Mayor would not appoint him as first deputy.

A psychiatrist testifying for the prosecution said yesterday that Police Officer Robert Torsney had acted in panic when he killed a Brooklyn youth last Nov. 25, and had not been suffering from mental defect or disease, as another psychiatrist had testified.

The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in stock by officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 23 Saying that the time was ripe for peace negotiations with all Arab foes, Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan told the nation today that Israel had to decide, and soon, on its "lastditch" attitude on the questions of ultimate borders, on a solution to the Palestinian problem and on the nature of the peace to be negotiated.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 The Soviet Union reportedly still wants the Geneva conference on the Middle East convened, but is apparently worried that the visit to Israel by President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt has damaged the prospects of negotiations by deepening the split in Arab ranks.
A 130-foot freighter carrying several tons of marijuana was seized off the coast of North Carolina Tuesday night by the United States Coast Guard and customs agents, the Coast Guard announced.

LEOTI, Kan., Nov. 20 The price of farm land has turned downward in most of the nation's major grain-growing regions for the first time in many years, threatening troubled growers with new financial problems.

HACKENSACK, Nov. 23 A Superior Court judge ordered an afternoon newspaper here today to surrender tapes of a jailhouse interview with a murder suspect, contending that the newspaper had no right under the United States Constitution or state law to withhold them.
PAGOPAGO, American Samoa, Nov. 23 (AP) Peter T. Coleman will become the first elected Governor of American Samoa next January, ending 77 years of leadership appointed by the United States Government.
DETROIT, Nov. 23 New-car sales by the nation's four major automobile manufacturers fell 3.9 percent below their year-earlier level in mid-November, the car producers reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) House Senate conferees agreed today on a threeyear extension of the Federal legal aid program, retaining a controversial provision to prohibit lawyers from handling school desegregation suits.

WASHINGTON Nov. 23 The Carter Administration is examining the possibility of not deploying the controversial neutron bomb in return for a pledge by the Soviet Union to limit a new mobile missile that is aimed at Western Europe.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 (AP) Two paper-bag manufacturing executives and their companies were convicted in Federal District Court here today on charges of criminal price fixing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) Nine members of the Senate Finance Committee, which approved a series of tax breaks for the oil and gas industry, received more than $547,000 in contributions from oil and gas interests in the last three years, a Ralph Nader group reports.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 23 Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization opened a diplomatic offensive today against separate Egyptian peace moves toward Israel but kept the doors open to their participation at a Geneva peace conference.

Buffalo IN "SEMMELWEISS" at the Studio Arena Theater Howard Sackler has taken the life story of Ignaz Philipp Semmelweiss (1818-65), the pioneer Hungarian physician, and transformed it into the spellbinding evening of theater.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 Bert Lance, the former Georgia banker who resigned under fire in September as President Carter's director of the Office of Management and Budget, has become the subject or a Federal grand jury investigation in Atlanta, Justice Department sources said today.

Physicists at Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois believe that by smashing together two protons, the nuclei of hydrogen atoms, they have very briefly created a "diproton" heavier than the combined weight of the two original particles.

Carol Louise Bearnot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Bearnot of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married at the Hampshire House yesterday to Dominique Bastien, son of Dr. and Mrs. Pierre C.V. Bastien of West Windsor, N.J. Rabbi Bert Siegel performed the ceremony.

The New York State Project Finance Agency, set up to complete work started by the ill-fated Urban Development Corporation, is refinancing almost $240 million of bonds carrying sky-high taxfree interest rates of 8 and 9 1/8 percent that were placed privately with savings banks. The effort will save the agency an estimated $17.4 million.

STAVANGER, Norway, Nov. 23 (AP) A helicopter on a routine flight to offshore oil wells crashed into the North Sea today, killing all 12 persons aboard, officials said.

About 4,000 dock workers began yesterday, a general strike that shut down the port of Baltimore while the International Longshoremen's Association made tentative plans for a Monday ratification vote that could end its limited 54-day strike in ports from Maine to Texas.

BURLINGTON, Nov. 23 On the eve of Thanksgiving, a sense of history was particularly strong today in this little city where the Quakers arrived 300 years ago and set up Yorkshire and Londonshire sections to house settlers from York and London.

That program has been scheduled for Dec. 14 at 10 P.M.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 23 The Giants today signed a player released by three other National Football League teams this year who will not be the answer to the following key questions concerning Sunday's game at Cincinnati with the Bengals:

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 23 A Government doctor testified today that he had approved a police plan to take Stephen Biko on a 700-mile road journey without qualified medical assistance despite tests showing that the black leader had suffered possible brain damage.

IN A WORLD papered with florals, pastoral scenes, polka dots and paisleys, the graph-paper check is the opiate of the rationalists and lately it has been turning up on more home furnish ings than there are pages in graph-paper pads. Whether you call the check pattern tattersall, windowpane, counterpane, cross section, crossword or quadrille, it is the same grid of parallel, vertical and horizontal lines intersecting at equal intervals to form a pattern of squares.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 A controversial three-star Air Force general who has stirred the ire of the White House is quietly leaving his Pentagon job overseeing arms sales abroad.

WASHINGTON John H. Fanning, who was sworn in this week to a fifth five-year term as a member of the National Labor Relations Board, probably knows as much as anyone about the way the national labor law operates.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 23 (AP) The Meteosat 1 weather satellite owned by the European Space Agency was in a stationary orbit 22,300 miles from the Earth today.
A new plan to prevent the possible manipulation and cornering of the coffee futures market next month was disclosed by the Government and the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange late yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 23 (Reuters) Israel's Deputy Prime Minister, Yigael Yadin, said today that the atmosphere at the first meeting last Saturday between President Anwar el-Sadat and Prime Minister Menachem Begin had been quickly relaxed by small talk about heart ailments.

SINGING LIEDER OF a genuinely intimate sort with orchestral accompaniment is one of those tests of sensitivity that may be demanded of sopranos when they apply for entry into heaven. It can be done, and dine exquisitely, as Jessye Norman proved last night when she performed six songs of Richard Strauss at Carnegie Hall with the Rotterdam Philharmonic under the Dutch orchestra's youthful music director, Edo de Waart.

Charles Arata Grondona, a chemical engineer who retired in 1969 as a consultant to the International Paper Company in New York, died Nov. 14 in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y., after a brief illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 19 Old Hill Farms Road, Westport, Conn.

At the Great Neck (L.I) Synagogue yesterday, Marna Lynn Ludwig, a registered nurse at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. was married to Dr. Michael D. Moseson, a senior resident in surgery at North Shore. Rabbi David Moseson, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

IF YOU BELIEVE, as many people do, that Northern California is a mellower place than New York, it follows that a top-notch cham ber-music group from the San Francisco Bay Area might be expected to favor a gentler, less propulsive playing style than one customarily hears in Manhattan.

She was writing a school paper on the performance, she said, and needed to know.
John Hubley, the artist of the animated film who died last February, will be honored by an exhibition and film festival to be held at Yale University in New Haven from next Wednesday through Dec. 7.

Plans for a $25 million Eastern Airlines shuttle terminal to replace a 16-year-old "temporary" facility at La Guardia Airport were announced yesterday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

The assistant public affairs director of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center has been discharged because he helped write a report charging that the center's research into the controversial cancer drug laetrile was incomplete and scientifically invalid.

ALBANY, Nov. 23 Apprehensive about the spread of a disease that is menacing pine trees in the Adirondack Mountains, the state today restricted the sale of pines for Christmas trees grown in parts of 10 counties in the Adirondacks area.

The 22-year-old granddaughter of Al Capp, the cartoonist, was killed early yesterday and a fellow reporter on The Newark Star-Ledger was critically injured when the car in which they were riding was rammed in the rear as it was stopped at a traffic light on a Lower Manhattan Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 After James A. Cramer earned his doctorate in sociology, he taught for a year at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond. The next year, two jobs opened up in the department and Dr. Cramer applied, but both went to women who had lower qualifications and less experience.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 23 When Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. announced a plan here to use the state National Guard to help solve the problem of high unemployment among the city's youths, there was speculation about whether the youths would go along with the idea.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd yesterday promoted 256 members of the force, including a sergeant who is still recuperating from injuries received 14 months ago when a terrorists' bomb exploded while he was trying to disarm it.
Hector Marchini, vice president of the Morania Oil Tanker Corporation of New York, died Tuesday of cancer in New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Warren, Conn.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 28 An election for local offices on this Chinese Nationalist-ruled island last weekend, which produced the first anti-Government violence in 30 years, was one of the worst setbacks for the governing Kuomintang Party since 1949.

LONDON, Nov. 23 (AP) The dollar dropped to new all-time lows today against the currencies of Japan, West Germany and Switzerland. The stagnant American economic performance remained the reason for the low confidence in the dollar.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 Federal health officials have received reports that the deaths of 10 more persons, including those of two men, may be tied to crash dieting with predigested liquid proteins, raising to 26 the number of fatalities that have come under suspicion.

Now President Carter has approved a program to protect the Government's telephone talkers but not yet the rest of us.

Schlesinger did not signal a retreat by President Carter on energy legislation. WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) President Carter signed today legislation postponing for 18 months the Food and Drug Administration's proposed ban on the use of saccharin as an artificial sweetener the White House said.

TRENTON, Nov. 24 Although they have been in effect only a year, New Jersey's budget "cap" laws, or limits on municipal, county and school spending, are under increasing attack by critics who believe they are hampering new programs and in some cases threatening existing ones.

Kevin Fahey scored four touchdowns and ran for 229 yards on 16 carries to lead Stamford Catholic to a 54-8 romp over Noire Dame of Bridgeport. Catholic will face Ansonis, which stopped unbeaten Naugatuck yesterday, 18-0, in the Class S championship.
There were some in yesterday's crowd of 18,565 who thought Aqueduct's mud would ruin the favored Cox's Ridge's victory chances as seven starters appeared for the $54,450 Queens County Handicap.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall has passed over the career administrator of the Federal Mining Enforcement and Safety Administration, Robert E. Barrett, in making his choice for a new Assistant Secretary of Labor to run the agency when it is transferred from the Interior Department to Labor next March.
NEW YORK, Nov. 24 (AP) More married women of child-bearing age want sons than daughters, according to a report to be published in a family planning journal tomorrow.

Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch spent a quiet Thanksgiving with relatives in Putnam County yesterday and book no steps to line up prospective appointees for the half-dozen deputy mayor posts in his administration, a spokesman said last night.

In the Hippocratic Oath, every young physician pledges to act "only for the good of my patients, keeping myself far from all intentional illdoing...." In nations where the state is an oppressor, doctors working for that state may easily be drawn into betrayal of their most basic medical obligations. We have the examples of Nazi doctors experimenting on Jews and other "inferior" peoples and Soviet psychiatrists solemnly diagnosing political dissent as mental illness requiring confinement.

BULAWAYO, Rhodesia, Nov. 24 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that he was prepared to concede the principle of majority rule based on one man, one vote as a starting point for negotiations with black nationalist leaders living in Rhodesia.

SO quietly you haven't even heard about it, a new play has come in and is going into rehearsal on Monday. What is more, it is going into rehearsal at the Billy Rose Theater on West 4lst Street, where the last tenant, "Jump ers," moved out three years ago. The new play is called "The November People," and it will open Jan. 10. This means that Broadway will once again go south of 44th Street.

JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 24 A bomb that apparently was planted in a flower pot exploded in a subterranean shopping complex in the heart of this city today, shattering shop windows and injuring 16 persons. They were treated at a hospital for minor injuries.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 24 Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today after a special meeting of the Cabinet in Jerusalem that it was up to Cairo to say how, when and where the dialogue he had started with President Anwar el-Sadat would be continued. He said no schedule had been worked out in the Jerusalem talks.

METUCHEN, Nov. 24 Paul Marsa, a gas-station owner in the Middlesex County community who is also the state director of American Atheists Inc., has opened a campaign to end the Borough Council's tradition of opening each monthly meeting with a prayer, contending that the practice is a violation of the constitutional separation of church and state.

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 Reports of close links between the Central Intelligence Agency and the security unit of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police have emerged in the public examination of alleged spying activities by the Mounties.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 24 (UPI) An off-duty New York City police officer was arrested early today and charged with assault for allegedly shooting a Westchester County restaurant owner in the stomach.

"My problem," says the indignant harness driver, grateful for the chance to be heard, "is not that I've been accused of doing anything dishonest. I've been in the business 25 years, and I've always driven to win. That's my problem." Lou Puntolillo's husky, almost hoarse voice rises to the urgent tone of a patient on a psychiatrist's couch. "My problem," he says, "is that I won't go along with fixed races.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Nov. 24 (UPI) Suburban General Hospital, where at least six people are believed to have died because of a mixup in gas lines in the emergency room, has filed suit against the acting Montgomery County coroner.
LONDON Nov. 24 (AP) The troubled dollar slid to new lows today against three West European currencies in nervous trading on European money markets.

The New York state police and an Air Force team searched the Crest BurnHobble Hill area of the Adirondack Mountain wilderness yesterday for two practice bombs that were ripped from an Air National Guard fighter plane flying too close to the treetops during a practice mission last Saturday.

SALONIKA, Greece, Nov. 24 A tomb uncovered near here a month ago is "without reservation" that of King Philip II of Macedon, father of Alexander the Great, the archaeologist who discovered it announced today.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 24 Israel's past position that all matters of substance in the conflict with the Arabs must be directly negotiated has been altered by the historic visit of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt.
Vincent Gilroy, s farmer New York State Assemblyman and a lawyer with a special interest is mass transit, died in Coney Island Hospital Nov. 16, three days short of his 89th birthday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)-Caitlin West, a 9-year-old girl from La Jolla, Calif., came to Washington last week to visit her physician-father, who is a medical consultant in the capital. She wanted to see the White House.
KUWAIT A French company has won a contract to build the first iceskating complex here, with separate rinks for men and women.

BOYNTON BEACH, Fla., Nov. 24 (AP) Edward Mayo Smith, who managed the Detroit Tigers to their 1968 world championship, died today. He was 62 years old. Mr. Smith suffered a stroke last Tuesday night while dining with his family in a Lake Worth restaurant. His daughter said he never regained consciousness.

PILOBOLUS Dance Theater, that fabulously innovative group of young people who have developed hanging upside down from one another's necks into a fine art, arrived last night at the St. James Theater for its first Broadway season.
The tenants of Lincoln Towers, the 4,000-apartment development at Amsterdam Avenue and 66th Street have won a victory over their landlord, according to their lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Carter Administration is seeking to help the ailing steel industry by reducing foreign imports, and offering domestic producers financial aid.
ROME, Nov. 24 A delegation of Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders announced here today that they had met with senior Hungarian officials and had been invited to visit religious groups in Hungary.

ATLANTA, Nov. 24 (AP) Dr. Arthur B. Rutledge, executive secretary of the Southern Baptist Convention's Home Mission Board for 11 years, has died of a heart attack, a board spokesman said.

An 11-year-old boy and his grandmother were killed in a fire, that swept through their home in Long Island City, Queens, yesterday morning. Neighbors said the two-family shingle house at 5-45 47th Road went up like a tinderbox at about 11:30 A.M.
As both marketers and publishers know, the sure road to success is fulfilling a need. Alan M. Levine, 34 yeas old is moving down that road fulfilling three of them.

Shopping in Bloomingdale's with the store closed to the public, wandering through the aisles with drink in hand, watching models slither around in designer lingerie, dining with friends on the store's furniture: The guests agreed that it was certainly a novel way to raise money for private schools.

MADISON, W. Va. The practice of "red-baiting" in the coal fields, an accusatory tactic that has been used both by the-mine operators and by leaders of the United Mine Workers of America to attack union dissidents, is making a comeback on the strength of the discovery of a handful of Maoists in the mines.
MOGADISHU, Somalia, Nov. 24 (Reuters) President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia has bemoaned the apparent unwillingness of the United States to become involved in the Horn of Africa.
Keith Hunter passed for two touchdowns and ran for another yesterday as undefeated Barringer rallied for its 10th victory, 26-6, over East Orange at Newark Schools Stadium.

Glenn Zaukas ran for one touchdown and passed for two more as New Rochelle closed out its first perfect football season in 13 years by defeating their hometown rival, Iona Prep, 20-15, yesterday in their traditional matchup.

John Franklin Wharton, a lawyer who founded the well-known firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton and Garrison, and a theater aficionado who was one of the founders of the eminent Playwrights Producing Company, died early yesterday at his come at 141 East 72d Street of complications brought on by emphysema. He was 83 years old.
Up and down a corridor west of the Rocky Mountains, roustabouts who normally work in the oil fields of Texas and Oklahoma are drilling for hot water.

PARIS, Nov. 24 (Reuters) Civil aviation authorities from 21 European countries called today for tougher antihijacking measures at airports, including an end to the immunity of diplomats from personal searches.

PARIS The unsmiling futures of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia stare down from the waiting room wall. On the coffee table are scattered copies of the annual report, printed in French and Arabic. In financial difficulties, WBAI-FM, the listener-supported radio station, may sell its studio building, the former Swedish Evangelical Church at 359 East 62d Street.

PLAINS, Ga., Nov. 25 (UPI) Thousands of tractors rolled into President Carter's hometown today in a protest by farmers who are threatening a national strike over hgh production costs and low crop prices.

Edward N. Costikyan, who lost his job as First Deputy Mayor even before he got it, says that Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch did not change the definition of the post he eliminated it. Mr. Koch does not disagree.

It is essentially a "legitimate" voice that can seem much too elegant. So the singer is apt to shift awkwardly back and forth between pop simplicity and "legitimate" elegance, losing whatever merits there might be in either style.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 25 An expert who studied the brain of Stephen Biko testified today that the late black leader must have become unconscious immediately after incurring the head injuries that ultimately proved fatal.

A doctor recently asked International Flavors and Fragrances Inc. to reproduce the odor on a patient's breath before he slipped into a hepatic coma. MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 28 A study of 17,000 Harvard alumni has found that there were fewer heart attacks among those who engaged regularly in strenuous sports activities like jogging, swimming, tennis and mountain climbing than among those who were less active.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 The Carter Administration decided today to join with Israel and accept Egypt's invitation to attend informal talks in Cairo to prepare the way for the convening of a Middle East peace conference in Geneva, Administration officials said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (Reuters) President Carter is planning to leave on Dec. 28 or 29 on a foreign tour that he postponed this month because of preoccupation with energy legislation, officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) A study group on teen-age pregnancy has told the Department of Health, Education and Welfare that abortions are "essential to reduce the numbers of high-risk adolescent births."

MOSCOW, Nov, 28 (UPI) A group of Soviet dissidents accused some Western European countries today of failing to speak out in defense of human rights to the Belgrade conference of East-West cooperation.
ATLANTA, Nov. 28 (AP) Delta Air Lines said today that it had withdrawn its application to the Civil Aeronautics Board for low-cost "aerobus" flights between New York City and Miami.
WESTPORT, Conn. The principal arguments vehemently raised in support of the Panama Canal treaties are not altogether convincing.

Hunt, the one-time company clerk who rose to head the giant Crown Zellerbach timber and paper products corporation and later served as chairman of President Nixon's Commission on Financial Structure and Regulation, died Satruday at a Tacoma hospital. HARTFORD, Nov. 28 Two World Hockey Association players were fined and suspended and six others were fined by the league today as the result of a bench-clearing brawl during the New England-Edmonton game here last Saturday.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 28 Andy Robustelli said today he would be back next year with the Giants, but didn't say whether Larry Csonka or John Hicks would also return.

Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain's largest chemical producer, reported yesterday a 43 percent drop in third-quarter earnings and an 11.2 percent decline for the first nine months of this year, despite higher sales in both periods.

Depressed by heavy selling shortly after midday, soybean futures prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Grain prices declined as well.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 An interagency task force set up to deal with problems of the steel industry sent a preliminary, summery of its report to the white House today, proposing a $20 million program of Federal aid for communities hit by steel layoffs and a $250 million revolv ing loan guarantee fund to provide fresh capital for modernizing the industry.

Justice George J. Balbach of State Supreme Court yesterday revoked bail for 65-year-old Sam Piazza and ordered the defendant in a long-delayed arson-murder case to be seized and brought into court as soon as he is released from the latest of a long series of hospital stays.

Rhodes of Arizona, the House Republican leader, suggested today that abortion foes in the House might be willing to end a five-month deadlock and accept a Senate compromise on federally financed abortions if Democratic leaders agreed to expedite consideration of a constitutional amendment that would prohibit abortions.

Mr. Dengler is the 32-year-old substitute teacher and shortorder cook who is asking a Minneapolis court to let him change his legal name to "1069." He already calls himself that and says friends call him "One Zero" for short.

NEWARK, Nov. 30 The unemployment rate among blacks in the greater Newark area in 1976 was twice that of whites, and more than three-and-one-half times as many adult black men than adult white men were out of work, the United States Department of Labor reported today.

Robert Shaplen, the New Yorker magazine correspondent in Asia, has denied a published allegation that he and other newsmen in South Vietnam had their reporting "shaped" or in other ways manipulated by the Central Intelligence Agency and the American Embassy in Saigon.

Sir Terence Rattigan, the playwright, died yesterday of bone marrow cancer in Hamilton, Bermuda, where he had been confined to his home for the last two years. His age was 66.

ROME The Italian Communist Party, going beyond its usual Communist allies, has begun sounding out the important socialist parties of Europe on a plan for a big meeting in Italy to set up joint study groups and establish regular relations. The International Air Transport Association (I.A.T.A.), which sets ticket prices for international travel, may be about to crash. LARGO, Fla., Dec. 2--Tommy Bolt, whose terrible temper was once a leg end on the pro-golf tour, is a bit more restrained these days, but he still is no pussycat. Bolt, now 59 years old and suffering from a touch of what he calls "arthuritis," had a few angry moments today, but not enough to spoil his day.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 2--Two convicted murderers were hanged at dawn here today, the Government an nounced, after a night of riots by blacks protesting the British colony's first executions in 30 years.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 2--Faced by angry critics of the state's mental-health policies, Governor Carey heatedly denied today that his administration had sought to "dump" psychiatric patients onto Long Island, but acknowledged there had been problems in the placing of such patients in community facilities.

NEWARK, Dec. 2--Robert J. Del Tufo, taking the oath of office as the new Unit ed States Attorney for New Jersey, voiced the hope today that "the dawn of a new era of Federal-state coopera tion" in law enforcement was on the hori zon.

COXSACKIE, N.Y., Dec. 2--About 40 youthful inmates of the State Correction al Facility here seized three hostages to day but released them unharmed, one of them late this afternoon and two tonight, after being allowed to present a list of 35 grievances to state officials and rep resentatives of the news media.

Hayes apologized to Freedman, who was apparently struck by the blow, a few days later.

DETROIT, Dec. 2--Despite uncertainty in some automotive circles, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Thomas A. Murphy, reiterated today his belief that new-car sales during 1978 will rise 4.4 percent to 11.75 million units from the 11.25 million projected for this year. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 20.44 points last week, with the big tumble coming on Tuesday's 12-point decline. The blue-chip indicator finished the week at 823.98. Cosmic rays from space probably generate the added electric potential that triggers a lightning stroke, according to scientists of at the Applied Physics Laboratory of the Johns Hopkins University in Laurel, Md.

New York City's air is significantly cleaner than it was a decade ago, but it is still dangerous to health. The problem is the continuing pollution caused by cars.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) The House decision yesterday to continue funds for two B-1 bombers amounts to "pouring half a billion dollars down a rat hole," the White House said today.

Harry Stern, a former New York City assistant commissioner of real estate, was indicted yesterday on four counts of income-tax evasion and four counts of filing false returns.

In another sign of Governor Carey's intention to seek re-election, Carey allies disclosed yesterday a million-dollar fundraising effort to retire his debt from the last gubernatorial campaign and to start a war chest for next year's election.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) Following is the roll-call by which the House agreed to soften its stance and move to a compromise bill with the Senate on federally financed abortions. A yes vote is a vote to soften the House position. Those who did not vote are denoted by xxx.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday it would spend a record $12.5 billion on construction in 1978, more than any American corporation has ever expended on construction in a single year.

MONTCLAIR, Dec. 7 A union leader accused Governor Byrne today of reneging on a campaign promise that there would be no faculty reductions at the eight state colleges, and said a job action was being considered to protest against the dismissal of what he said was about half the teachers who were up for tenure or reappointment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) John D. Ehrlichman learned today that his imprisonment will end after one and a half years, the third longest stretch for anyone caught up in the Watergate scandal that ended Richard M. Nixon's Presidency.

American publishers made it clear yesterday that Moscow would have to comply with the human-rights provisions of the Helsinki accords before they signed any trade protocol with the Soviet Union's book-publishing industry.

WEST POINT, Dec. 7 A study of the United States Military Academy's first women cadets indicated today that they had integrated suprisingly well despite the opposition of most male cadets.

The General Electric Company and Japan's Hitachi Ltd. announced yesterday the formation of a new joint venture, General Television of America Inc., that will engineer, manufacture and market television products. The new company will produce G.E., Hitachi and privatelabel television sets and will manufacture and sell parts to other producers as well.
THE DYING ART of the dance solo remains surprisingly alive and intermittently well at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

Christmas Tree Sale, Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 East 91st Street A Christmas tree sale, sponsored by the school's Alumnae Association, will take place in the driveway at 1 East 91st Street from Wednesday, Dec. 14, through Saturday, Dec. 19. Quality balsam and Scotch pine trees will be offered; all proceeds will go toward the preservation of the school's landmark buildings, the Otto Kahn and William Burden mansions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 The House and Senate compromised today on their dispute over the use of Medicaid funds for abortion, ending a five-month impasse that had held up appropriations for two major Government departments.

THE EMPIRE STATE Building's classic profile has been inspir ing a lot of close looks lately and that is because it doesn't look quite the way it used to. Since midautumn, the tower's top 30 floors have been bathed at night by colored floodlights, and the change has been dramatic enough to make the building an altogether different presence on the city's nighttime skyline.

SAN DIEGO, Dec.8 Are Americans ready to buy small import-like cars made in the United States? The Chrysler Corporation hopes so. Much of Chrysler's future product and marketing strategy in this era of "downsizing" and its financial livelihood for that matter rest on its gamble that they are and that the company's two import-like cars, the Dodge Omni and the Plymouth Horizon, introduced here today will be among the beneficiaries of the trend.

Alan Baer Rothenberg, author, poet, painter, and former teacher at Prospect Heights High School, Brooklyn, and at Hunter College, died suddenly Monday in his home, 225 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn. He was 70 years old.

Schlesinger swooped into New York City yesterday to appeal for support for the Administration's national energy plan before an audience of key businessmen.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 7 Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes pleaded guilty today to a charge of attempting to practice law without a license, a misdemeanor, and was fined $150. He could have been fined $500 and sentenced to 90 days in jail.

Dave Maloney called it "a barn-burnet." Said Pat Hickey, "It was good hockey, good fun." Coach Jean-Guy Talbot said simply, "Whew"! IF THERE are gardeners on your gift list, relax. They are easy to please if the gift will grow, make a plant look better as it grows or add to the gardener's knowledge of growing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7-- Taxpayers filing income tax returns next year on the 1040A "short form" will need to fill in only 15 lines as against 25 lines this year. The Internal Revenue Service estimates this will save almost 70 million hours in paperwork, which would be a reduction of 10 percent.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Dec. 7 (AP) Seventy-six workers at a toy manufacturing plant here were taken to hospitals in the area today and 1,400 others were removed when toxic fumes spread through the plant. Officials said it was the second such incident in the same building of the Coleco Industries plant in three days.

Retaliating against foreign critics of its peace initiatives, Egypt closed down the cultural centers and some consulates of the Soviet Union, East Germany, Hungary and Czechoslovakia. Snow belongs to the open country. It has no reason for being, in the city, where it becomes a slushy nuisance with little beauty, once it has fallen. A snowfall itself, the shifting curtain of flakes drifting down, has its brief loveliness even in the city's canyons; but once on the streets it is just so much cold, wet inconvenience.

"My Fair Lady" and "The Royal Family" have in common? The answer is Oliver Smith, whose set designs for ballet, opera and theater mark a 35-year career that began with his work for the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo.

The player who falls behind early in a match is well advised to throw everything into making up the lost ground as soon as possible. With a sizable number of games to go, his opponent cannot rely on cautiously holding draw after draw no one has good enough nerves to follow that policy but will have to meet him on equal terms.

Marlene Ellen Nadel, daughter of State Supreme Court Justice Bernard Nadel and Mrs. Nadel of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Stolz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Stolz of New York and Westport, Conn.

"Heart of Glass," which was shown at the New York Film Festival, was reviewed on Oct. 1 by Janet Maslin. Following are excerpts from the review. The picture opened yesterday at Cinema Studio, 1966 Broadway, at 66th Street.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 Ron Jaworshi scored on a 1-yard bootleg run with 20 seconds remaining to play and gave the Philadelphia Eagles a 17-14 victory over the Giants today.

ABU DHABI, Dec. 11 (AP) Syria will stay out of Arab-Israeli negotiations in Cairo even if they produce progress, and will boycott any subsequent Geneva peace talks, Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria said today.

A Housing Authority police officer was charged with attempted murder last night after he reportedly shot and critically wounded a sergeant in the locker room of the authority's South Bronx precinct station house, and then refused to discuss the incident.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 A tally of the human races can almost be made in Heller's Bakery in the Mount Pleasant section of this city, a city that is predominantly black, where most whites live in separate enclaves, where residential segregation is reasserting itself.

Nearly half of all new welfare applicants in New York City are being turned down 48 percent since July 1, compared with 25 to 35 percent before new, tighter controls in mid-1976 and complaints of harassment and delays are being raised by client representatives.

At Rockefeller Center yesterday, thousands of fingers fumbled numbly with cameras pointed at ice skaters in the rink. And elsewhere around the city, buses were arriving from farther west bearing snow on their roofs, a clue of what may lie in store for New York.
MOSCOW, Dec. 11 Soviet dissidents said today that K.G.B. secret police agents had left the apartments of more than 20 activists who had been kept under house arrest all day yesterday.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 11 The five judges waited patiently as the bailiff brought the defendant into the woodpaneled room that had a hand-lettered sign saying "Peer Court."

The Leo Castelli Gallery on West Broadway in SoHo was thronged for much of the last several weeks. That would have been no surprise had the gallery been showing one of its regular artists such as Jasper Johns or Roy Lichtenstein. But the exhibition that recently filled Castelli was not only not a show of work by a well-known artist, it also was not, strictly speaking, a show of works of art at all.

DENVER, Dec. 11 There's nothing unusual about football mania at this time of year Texans and their Longhorns, Nebraskans and their Big Red and diehard Giants rooters are all famous cases, and then there are the Minnesota Vikings fans. But Denver's Broncomania is something else again.

A warning that prisoners' rights should be expanded by legal means or "other less-peaceful attempts at securing rights will surely follow" is set forth in a new American Civil Liberties Union handbook.

A 26-game treadmill of defeat finally ended yesterday for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in New Orleans. The Bucs, who had lost every game they played since joining the National Football League last year, used three touchdowns on pass interceptions to defeat the Saints, 33-14, and set off a jubilant victory celebration, their first.

MANILA, Dec. 11 (AP) The Spanish team of Severiano Ballesteros and Antonio Garrido combined for a threestroke advantage over the Philippine team of Rudy Lavares and Ben Arda today as Spain took its second straight World Cup golf championship.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 11 (Reuters) Riot policemen have arrested a former vice president of Kenya, Oginga Odinga, and 17 other persons at a meeting he was to have addressed, witnesses reported.

LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 11 (AP) Kevin Porter scared 30 points and had 17 assists today to pace the New Jersey Nets to a 106-95 victory over the Washington Bullets in a National Basketball Association game.

JACQUES BE NIMBLE Jacques D'Amboise, leading male dancer of the New York City Ballet, will give a talk and demonstration tonight based on his career, which also includes choreography and teaching. The informal event, at 6 o'clock, will have the audience participate in questions and answers. It will be in the main rehearsal hall of the New York State Theater.

Half a century ago, the American Auction Bridge League, for men only, was founded in Chicago. It was a considerable surprise to most of the founders that within a few years the word "auction" was dropped, and so, incidentally, was the sex restriction.

CAIRO, Dec. 11 The latest wrinkle in the new fabric of contacts between Israel and Egypt was the appearance last week of an Israeli lecturer before a rapt official audience of Egyptian generals and other ranking military officers.

DEPEW, N.Y., Dec. 11 (AP) The 15year-old son of a Buffalo police detective apparently shot and killed himself after taking his father's police cruiser for a joy ride last night and wounding a Depew police officer, authorities said today.
SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., Dec. 11 (AP) Glenn Ramsey, former Associated Press chief of bureau in New York City, died yesterday. He was 77 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 11. As seen from here, the position of the Palestine Liberation Organization has been rendered precarious by the split between President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and the Arab countries that have attacked his peace initiatives toward Israel.

The Exxon Corporation said "many persons" had called the company yesterday for reimbursement of the cost of cleaning cars and homes after oil sprayed across the New Jersey Turnpike and parts of Staten Island from a blowout Saturday at an oil-distillation tower at the company's Baywater refinery in Linden, N.J.

A chemical found in the pituitary gland has been synthesized and used with promising results in treating severe pain and the symptoms of narcotic withdrawal in a small number of patients, according to scientists who are doing research with recently discovered, natural opiate-like substances.
ATHENS, Dec. 11 (Reuters) At least five persons were drowned in the northern part of the city today as flooding followed heavy rains that fell on Greece for the second straight month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Representative Don Edwards, Democrat of California, has filed a suit in Federal District Court here asking that the Central Intelligence Agency be required to make public any records it might have concerning the publication in this country of a book allegedly commissioned by a company with ties to the agency.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 11 (UPI) George F. Baker Jr., who was prominent in New York City society, was found shot to death early today on his 13,000-acre Horsehoe Plantation near here. A spokesman for the Leon County Sheriff's Department said Mr. Baker had apparently taken his own life with a shotgun.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 11 Lebanese leaders fear that President Anwar elSadat's peace initiatives will lead to a separate treaty between Egypt and Israel, leaving Lebanon with the Palestinian problem unresolved.

Suzie Chen, a candidate for a doctoral degree in genetics at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, was married yesterday to Dr. Leigh Switzen Wise, who is doing biology research as a postdoctoral fellow at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The New York City Police Department's efforts to put more officers on patrol to combat crime are lagging behind objectives.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 11 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the United States would do all it could to mend the split in the Arab world and thereby improve the chances for achieving an overall Arab-Israeli peace agreement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland said today that he was uncertain about the effects of this week's threatened farm strike, but the Administration would not give in to farmers' demands for guaranteed profits.

As a cherry picker raised Senator Jacob K. Javits and Rabbi Shmuel M. Butman 30 feet in the air to light the candles of the "world's largest Hanukkah menorah," thousands of people, mostly bearded Hasidim in long, black coats, sang and danced horas on the cold cobble stones.
LONDON, Dec. 11 David Holden was considered by his peers in Fleet Street to be one of the outstanding British correspondents of the postwar era.

PARIS, Dec. 11 Parisians by the hundreds of thousands jammed the city's express subway trains this weekend, trying out new lines and visiting a huge new main station at Les Halles in the center of town.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) The Interior Department has hired the American Arbitration Association to study ways of resolving the growing conflicts of environmental protection and energy development, it was annonced today.

Adverse publicity about the plight of developing nations particularly those heavily dependent upon imported fuel appears to be a factor in the depressed prices of bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
BOSTON, Dec. 11 Peace requires choices. That practical truth has been imprinted on the consciousness of Israel in these last weeks: a principal effect of President Sadat's visit.
Community officials on the West Side have given their final approval to a plan to develop the last nine sites in the controversial West Side urban-renewal area.

With the announced purchase of an additional 851,600 metric tons of American corn and wheat last week, Moscow fulfilled the minimum annual requirements of the second stage of the five-year pact, signed with Washington in October 1976.
Commodity futures trading volume jumped 26 percent last month from the November 1976 level, the Futures Industry Association reported over the weekend.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 11 (UPI) Job prospects for college graduates look better for the second consecutive year although employers will continue to be selective in their hiring, according to the results of a survey, made public today, by the College Placement Council.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 President Carter's adviser on national security held out the possibility today that the Geneva conference on the Middle East, which the Administration had hoped to reconvene this year, might be mostly a mechanism for ratification of progress already made elsewhere.

Andrew Young, the United States representative to the United Nations, told worshipers at Riverside Church yesterday that the concept of human rights although defined by the United States as civil, political and spiritual freedoms must, by necessity, take on different meanings in other countries if the concept is to be universal.

An advertisement the other day described a necktie, made of cut velvet and studded with diamonds, "for that man in a million, only $2,000." The initial temptation was to exclaim "Obscene!" but that, we soon realized, would be as irrelevant as mothers urging children to finish their liver because people not as fortunate are starving in Calcutta.

Unilever, the giant international food, soap and chemical company, and the National Starch and Chemical Corporation of Bridgewater, N.J., announced fast night that the two companies had reached tentative agreement for Unilever to take over National for $73.50 a share a total of $482 million in cash.

Anthony Romano, a member of the Manhattan law firm of Romano Schenker and the acting village justice of Piermont, N.Y., died Saturday in Summit Park Hospital in Piermont, N.Y. He was 78 years old and lived in Upper Nyack N.Y.
Negotiators for the striking United Mine Workers union and the coal industry met for several hours yesterday for contract talks and a top union official said afterward, "We're making progress."

JERUSALEM, Dec. 11 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the United States would do all it could to mend the split in the Arab world and thereby improve the chances for achieving an overall Arab-Israeli peace agreement.
One is holding his stack of newspapers jauntily. His hat is pulled down rakishly. There is a toughguy look on his face and a cigarette dangles from his lips.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 It was the annual Awards Presentation of the American Foreign Service Association, the club and the trade union of the country's career diplomats, and nobody expected fireworks, even though "intellectual courage" and "creative dissent" are among the criteria for which the awards are made.

VIENNA, Dec. 11 Speculation that President Carter may entrust his wife, Rosalynn, with the mission of taking the historic Crown of St. Stephen back to Hungary has caused bafflement close to displeasure in Budapest.

Lukas Foss's "Meet the Moderns" series with the Brooklyn Philharmonic at the Brooklyn Academy of Music doesn't exactly offer only the froth on the cresting wave of the avant-garde. The program Saturday night began with a piece that is 76 years old, and included two works by worthy inter-war German composers. There was also one work from 1971 and one that had literally just been finished.

ANCHORAGE, Dec. 11 A new state capital, to be built in a wilderness valley, will be designed for buses, boats, snowmobiles and skiers rather than automobiles under the plan chosen this weekend by the Alaska Planning Commission.

Constance Meadnis Saintonge, who taught English literature, composition and creative writing at Mount Holyoke College from 1928 until her retirement in 1970, died Friday at her home in South Hadley, Mass. She was 72 years old.
Last week ended up with an exciting flurry of account movement on both the national and retail level.

The salaries of teachers in New Jersey rank in the top 20 percent of teachers' salaries nationwide, according to an annual survey just released by the New Jersey Education Association, which represents the teachers in contract negotiations.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 11 The quiet on the Lebanese border was broken last night when Arab guerrillas ambushed an Israeli patrol in Lebanese territory shortly before midnight and Israeli artillery responded with an intensive bombardment, according to military headquarters here.

Congress has legislated restrictions on abortions for the poor at a time when the Federal Government is paying for abortions for Government employees and their dependents. Among the officials who are eligible for this benefit are the members of Congress.
LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP) Billie Jean King defeated Virginia Wade of Britain, 6-3, 6-1, today to win the Bremar Cup women's tennis tournament.
Melvin C. Krampf, a reporter and columnist for The Freehold (N.J.) Transcript since 1928, died Saturday in Freehold Area Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 37 Broad Street in Freehold.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Dec. 11 (Reuters) Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai of India left Nepal today after a two-day visit that both sides said could open a new chapter in relations between them.
A picture of "moderate economic growth" for the industrial world in 1978 has been painted by a blue-ribbon panel of American economists and analysts assembled by the Conference Board.

BASLE, Switzerland Bankers and foreign exchange dealers the world over will be closely watching the two-day meeting of central bank governors opening here tomorrow for any sign that new steps are planned to bolster the sagging United States dollar and to allay growing European anxieties about its decline.

Dominica Garcia woke up early one recent morning and decided to do a little work in her New York hotel room. "I typed this," she said after some coaxing, reaching across a desk at the office of the International Rescue Committee. "It's an appeal... I guess it's a little emotional."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) A communitywide experiment in Denver involving intensive educational help has been 89 percent successful in turning hardcore juvenile delinquents away from crime, a Government report said today.

JOHORE BHARU, Malaysia, Dec. 11 (AP) Searchers have recovered the flight recorder of the hijacked Malaysian Airlines System jetliner that crashed near here, killing all 100 people aboard, the police said today.

The leisurely process by which an overhaul of the nation's welfare system is to be brought to fruition appears to have become even more leisurely.
