PANAMA CITY, Fla., Dec. 11 The State of Florida is investigating charges by the prosecutor here that the Federal Bureau of Investigation set up a huge marijuana smuggling deal in which four passers-by were murdered at Sandy Creek, Fla., last January.

Susan Kottler of Arlington, Mass., a psychiatric social worker in Boston, was married at home yesterday afternoon to Stephen Shestakofsky, a New York lawyer. Rabbi Benjamin Rudavsky performed the ceremony.

It is as inevitable as an occasional piece of burnt toast or a half-puffed souffle that all recipies emanating from that nearby stove and from this typewriter human factors being what they are are not of uniform inspiration. Nor could they be received with equal enthusiasm by whatever readers may chance upon this Column.

KEYSTONE, Colo., Dec. 11 In this Rocky Mountain country where silver miners once braved winter's rigors at their own risk, many of America's skiarea operators gathered last week to consider the vital subject of resort owner-skier liability.

Whether they wanted the game to be over quickly because it was so terrible or because the weather was so cold, the Shea Stadium fans booed timeouts yesterday while the Jets were dropping a 14-10 decision to the Buffalo Bills.
ATLANTA, Dec. 11 What may be the most intensive and controversial anti-obscenity drive in the country is now under way in Atlanta and surrounding Fulton County.
Seven New York City police chaplains have field a suit seeking raises that would amount to nearly $25,000 each.
The 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, now entering its second week, runs through February, but many who contribute think of the fund many times during the year.
Last weekend, the temperature reached 20 degrees and the chill factor was 9 degrees below zero an early reminder of the prediction that this winter will be harsh, much like last year's.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) Retail stores increased sales 1.5 percent in November, the second straight monthly gain, the Commerce Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Japan presented to American officials today its proposals for dealing with the severe trade imbalance between the two nations, but the Americans promptly said that the proposals "fell considerably short" of what was needed.
BASEL, Switzerland, Dec. 12 Western central bankers registered their concern over the sagging dollar at talks here today, but they announced no new steps to strengthen it.

Recent news articles about the kidnapping of one of Europe's richest men, and the payment of a huge ransom, failed to point out that the victim was a prominent bridge enthusiast. Maurits Caransa, the self-made Dutch multimillionaire disappeared after leaving his bridge club, the exclusive Continental in Amsterdam.

The partly frozen bodies of two men, each bound by the hands and shot in the head, were found by the police of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday in the trunk of a car that had been parked in a lot at Kennedy international Airport since last Tuesday.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 George Meany, 83 years old, was re-elected today as expected to the presidency of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 12 In preparation for the arrival here this week of Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance. the Saudi Government has affirmed that restoring East Jerusalem to Jordanian control is one of the "main objectives of the entire Arab world."
ROME, Dec. 12 (Reuters) At least six persons were injured tonight when 2,000 students rampaged through Rome, setting cars, offices and bars on fire.

The chairman of the Assembly Education Committee said yesterday that, while he favored the retention of New York City's lay Board of Education to help set policy for the public schools, the system should be made more accountable to the Mayor and the public.

TRENTON, Dec. 12 Jeffrey Bell of Trenton announced today that he would challenge United States Senator Clifford P. Case for the Republican nomination next year, becoming the first official candidate of either party to enter the race.
An off-duty police of officer who shot and killed a teen-ager in Brooklyn last Sept. 2 after a brief scuffle was indicted yesterday on charges of manslaughter in the second degree.

The international adventure of an unwittingly illegal courier of Mayan art a mild-mannered, scholarly banker and former president of the New York City Y.M.C.A. has come to light after several years of mystery and speculation in archeological circles.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 12 Fred Dryer was unhappy, said so, and he's gone.

The agreement announced last week by The Washington Post and The Detroit News to exchange television stations is the first major step in what may end up as a sweeping restructuring of the broadcast industry throughout the country.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 12 Lebanon's main Christian political organizations declared a general strike today, ostensibly to protest press censorship but actually to call attention to the Palestinian problem on the eve of the visit here by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

HONG KONG, Dec. 12 A train carrying Mao Tse-tung is due to pass over the long steel Yangtze River bridge at Nanking in a few minutes. There have been rumors of an attempt against the life of the leader, and an alert sentry on the bridge stops a young woman as she tries to cross the tracks.

CIUDAD OBREGON, Mexico After just a year in office, President Jose Lopez Portillo, reversing the controversial agrarian policies of his predecessor, has begun stressing increased food production over expropriation of private estates.
Henry Geldzahler, curator of 20th-century arts at the Metropolitan Museum, is scheduled to be named the city's new cultural commissioner by the incoming Koch administration.

Banker-borrower lending practices of the kind highlighted in the Bert Lance inquiry have been found to exist among New York State-chartered commercial banks only in "isolated questionable instances," Muriel F. Siebert, the state's Superintendent of Banking, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The House special welfare subcommittee approved a schedule of Federal cash benefits today of up to $4,200 for a poor family of four.

LONDON, Dec. 12 Britain begins highlevel negotiations in New York tomorrow that may well lead to a change in the status of the Falkland Islands, one of the 15 remaining colonial fragments of the British Empire.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 12 King Hussein, after conferring with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, said today that Jordan would still not attend the preliminary peace talks that are to begin on Wednesday in Cairo, but he left open the strong possibility that Jordan would join the negotiations for an overall ArabIsraeli settlement "at a later stage, possibly in Geneva."
BRUSSELS, Dec. 12 (Reuters) A NATO spokesman said today that the alliance was "evaluating the extent of the damage done by the material compromised" in the latest West German spy scandal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency announced plans today to restrict the amount of lead in the air. The problem is particularly acute for young children, who are especially sensitive to low levels of the pollutant, agency officials said.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 12 The entire Jets' starting team on offense and defense may be composed of secondstringers for next Sunday's finale at Philadelphia, Coach Walt Michaels disclosed today.

More than anything else, it probably was the program that kept Steven De Groote from making his full impact in Carnegie Hall last night. The 24-year-old pianist, winner of the 1977 Van Cliburn Competition, put forth his credentials with Haydn, Prokofiev, Beethoven and Chopin. It was a program that aimed to establish his musicianship as well as his pianism. But he was not fully up to it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The Supreme Court unanimously reversed today the rape conviction of an Illinois man who had been identified by the victim during a pretrial courtroom hearing at which he was not represented by counsel.

HONG KONG, Dec. 12 No complete manuscripts of underground literature in China are known to have reached the outside world. In part this seems a tribute to the effectiveness of the Chinese security system compared with that of the Soviet Union. It may also reflect the greater isolation of Chinese intellectuals from their counterparts in the West.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Wallace L. Timmeny has been named Deputy Director of the Securities and Exchange Commission's Enforcement Division, it was announced yesterday by Stanley Sporkin, director of the division.
The stock market edged higher yesterday, led by National Starch and Chemical, which soared 20 points to 65 .

DAMASCUS, Syria. Dec. 12 (Reuters) The Syrian Government said today that Syria's leaders would refuse to receive Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance if on arriving here tomorrow he tried to give them a message from Israel.

A memorial service will be held in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University next Monday at 4 P.M. for Goldthwaite H. Dorr, a 1904 law graduate of the Columbia Law School, who died at his home in Carmel, N.Y., on Dec. 7 at the age of 101. He had practiced law for 70 years until his retirement in 1974 from Mudge, Rose, Guthrie Alexander.
LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP) The final draft of the document under which a large part of Germany's forces surrendered at the end of World War II sold for $5,640 here today.
ANKARA, Dec. 12 (Reuters) Bulent Ecevit, leader of the opposition, claimed a major victory today after local elections throughout Turkey.
The annuity an old-fashioned way to save for retirement is finding new expression in no-commission policies that offer, at least for the present, high returns on a tax-deferred basis.
The consensus of American business forecasters is that 1978 will be a relatively good year, with real gross national product total output corrected for inflation rising by 4.2 percent.
Leila Roig, director of advertising and public relations of Flagship Cruises, died Sunday in the home of her mother, Henrietta Havens Roig, at 435 East 52d Street. She was 55 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The Health Research Group demanded today that the Federal Government remove the artificial hormone DES from the prescription drug market because of new information that links its use to the development of breast cancer and other malignancies.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. 12 (AP) An agreement has been reached after months of negotiations for televising the 1980, Winter Olympic Games from Lake Placid, N.Y., throughout Europe. The agreement was reached in Geneva, where the four groups met secretly this weekend and continued their talks today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) President Carter announced his choices today for five nominations to the board of directors of the Legal Services Corporation, the nonprofit organization established by Congress two years ago to finance local groups offering legal aid to the needy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 President Carter is pressing ahead with two controversial nominations to the Federal Election Commission even though one threat ens to worsen his already strained relations with the Republican Congressional leadership and the second has been challenged on the ground of propriety.
Henry Geldzahler, curator of 20th-century arts at the Metropolitan Museum, is scheduled to be named the city's new cultural commissioner by the incoming Koch administration.
ATLANTA, Dec. 11 The focus on desegregation in the South is shifting from primary and secondary schools to colleges and universities.

TOKYO, Dec. 12 Japan's new Foreign Minister, Sunao Sonoda, said today that his nation's trade liberalization proposals being presented in Washington this week represent the "maximum possible package" at the moment. But he expressed some doubt that the package would be acceptable to the United States and said a failure of the talks would be "quite serious" in bilateral relations between the two Pacific allies.

L'Ensemble is a group that presents chamber music in a rococo ballroom of the James E. Burden mansion, one of the city's landmark buildings, at Fifth Avenue and 91st Street. Overweight cherubim, playing tambourines and Plutes in bas relief, look down on the scene, and one may fleetingly imagine what it was like to listen to after-dinner music in old New York, if not old Vienna or Versailles.
The New England Patriots won, but at the same time they lost. The Baltimore Colts lost, but won. What's going on here?

HARTFORD, Dec. 12 With all the hushed excitement of the opening an ancient tomb, a collection of 19thcentury French, Italian and California wines discovered in Albany in September was opened here yesterday for the first time.

Disturbed by excessive violence in the National Basketball Association, Commissioner Larry O'Brien yesterday handed out the largest fine in sports history. He penalized Kermit Washington, a Los Angeles Lakers' forward, $10,000 and suspended him for at least 60 days and possibly for the rest of the season.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12 In the words of a third-world diplomat here, Julian Grenfell is "ubiquitous" and "we are glad that he is."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The Supreme Court declined to accept for review today a libel case growing out of a dispute over the effect of pesticides on the nation's bird population.
When Eastern Airline's Flight No. 1 leaves the runway of Newark International Airport today for Orlando, Fla., it will signal the return in a major way of European producers to the American market.

Edwin J. McCarthy, the general business manager of the Hearst publications magazines Harper's Bazaar, House Beautiful and Town and Country, died Sunday at his home in Woodside, Queens, after a short illness. He was 77 years old.

Of the four unresolved playoff positions in the National Football League, first and foremost is the berth that goes to the team that wins the Eastern Division title in the American Conference, because it involves three teams battling for one spot the Colts, the Dolphins and the Patriots.

Steel production for the week ended Dec. 10 declined by 0.4 percent to 2.27 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry produced 2.29 million tons in the preecding week.

Talley Beatty went prospecting for choreographic gold on the wrong side of the tracks long before it became fashionable for dance to examine the seamier side of life. His "Road of the Phoebe Snow" has been delighting and jarring audiences for nearly 20 years and did so again Sunday evening as it was presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 The Velsicol Chemical Corporation was indicted today on charges that it conspired to suppress the results of tests that allegedly showed that two widely used pesticides produced by the company may cause cancer in humans. The Federal indictment also named six present or former company employees.

President Carter seems eager for House-Senate conferees to break their deadlock on the minor issue of a college-tuition tax credit so they can send him a finished Social Security bill in this calendar year. But the American people would be better off if the deadlock lasted long enough for this massive tax bill to be recognized for the economic disaster it is. For example:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Negotiators seeking a new labor contract to end the week-old coal miners' strike recessed their talks again today for what officials on both sides called "a study" and reassessment of their positions.

JOHANNESBURG, Dec 12 A private investigator in the coastal city of East London has accused members of the South African security police of having mailed acid-impregnated T-shirts to the home of Donald Woods, a controversial editor who was barred from journalism by the Government two months ago.

The Fluor Corporation, builder of petroleum processing and petrochemical facilities, yesterday reported increases of 12 percent for the fourth fiscal quarter and 16.3 percent for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31.
Seventy-four new school-crossing guards were sworn in at ceremonies at Police Headquarters in Manhattan yesterday, bringing the city's total number of guards to 500.

AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 12 (UPI) The Firestone Tire Rubber Company is recalling 1,200 passenger car tires because they may have a buckle in the body ply fabric that could lead to a flex crack and air loss in continued use.

A 13-year-old boy who stole three cars, was sent to a shelter and then escaped and went on a wild ride in a fourth stolen car was cited yesterday as an example of "oversights and mishandling" by the juvenile-justice system.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 12 After six months of acrimonious racial controversy that blocked the hiring of new police officers, the city administration here has agreed to a hiring plan that gives preference to minority applicants to the force.

HONG KONG, Dec. 12 A train carrying Mao Tse-tung is due to pass over the long steel Yangtze River bridge at Nanking in a few minutes. There have been rumors of an attempt against the life of the leader, and an alert sentry on the bridge stops a young woman as she tries to cross the tracks.
Several factors considered bearish by traders combined yesterday to send grain and soybean prices tumbling on the Chicago Board of Trade.

The following case histories are excerpted from "The Annals of Babble," Montclare Shortside's monumental, immensely moving and poignant, but wise and witty study of human decay. It will soon be published by Skein Ossa, with illustrations, at $27.50.

An Israeli woman testified here yesterday that a 73-year-old retired carpenter from Mineola, L.I., was a former police "commandant" in Nazi-occupied Latvia in World War II who rounded up Jews including members of her family for execution at the Dwinsk ghetto in 1941 and 1942.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The White House today conceded the impossibility of getting energy legislation through Congress this year and complained that President Carter may leave later this month on a foreign trip with neither the promise nor the essential outlines of an energy program in hand.

LINDEN, N.J., Dec. 12 Hundreds of Staten Island residents clogged telephone lines today, complaining about the droplets of oil that rained on their homes and automobiles Saturday after a "blowout" at the Exxon Company's refinery here.

Look magazine (1936-71) will be resurrected in this country next fall, according to an announcement made yesterday in Paris by Daniel Filipacchi, publisher of Paris Match magazine and of the French edition of Playboy. It will be published every other week, just like the old days.
The dollar fell in value in New York and European foreign-exchange trading yesterday, after edging higher against the yen in Tokyo. The Associated Press reported.

On the eve of United States Senate hearings on Federal loans to New York City, the city's Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, yesterday proposed a comprehensive financing plan that would commit the city to use large portions of new loans for economic development projects.
ATLANTA, Dec. 11 The focus on desegregation in the South is shifting from primary and secondary schools to colleges and universities.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 12 (UPI) In a major move to protect its endangered wildlife, Kenya ordered a halt today to the multimillion-dollar trade in animal skins and trophies.
With the main onslaught of this week's record volume of new tax-exempt bond financing still a day away, the municipal bond market declined slightly in price yesterday.

New York State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's office has ordered the packagers of a so-called "million dollar" backgammon tournament, to take place in Las Vegas, to "clarify" possibly misleading statements in their promotional brochures.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 The floor of the convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations is largely a sea of white male faces. Nonetheless, minorities and women are becoming an increasingly important factor in the trade union movement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 This port city, still proclaiming its historic tolerance toward such bawdy diversions as topless dancing, has begun to move against storefront sex parlors with tough enforcement of new and old ordinances.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 12 (AP) Parole hearings began today for the 138 Americans transferred from Mexican jails over the weekend under a historic prisoner exchange treaty, and as many as 44 of them could be freed beginning tomorrow morning.

TRENTON, Dec. 12 Legislative leaders said today they were lining up votes to extend unemployment benefits to more than 400,000 workers not now covered in New Jersey some maids, certain agricultural workers and employees of state and local governments, including school districts.

Striking United Mine Workers members invaded the nonunion coal fields of eastern Kentucky yesterday and forced at least five truck drivers to dump coal alongside highways. About 400 strikers ranged through parts of Ohio, West Virginia and Kentucky in a 100-vehicle caravan.

WOOD-RIDGE, Dec. 12 Nearly 1,200 white- and blue-collar workers were forced out of work here today when the Curtiss-Wright Aerospace Corporation locked its gates in a dispute with two unions over a new contract.

Frank Boucher, a member of the original New York Rangers, of 1926, who won selection to the Hockey Hall of Fame after 29 years with the team as a player, a coach and a general manager, died yesterday in Ottawa after a long battle against cancer. He was 76 years old.

It may not be the Palace, but the Astor Place Theater, only a few steps down at 434 Lafayette Street, has a big, buoyant and joyful sound in it this week. Its source is a handsome fellow who sings and goes by the name of Joe Masiell.

Dr. Frederick J. Gaudet, professor emeritus of psychology at Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., died yesterday in his home in Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 12 (AP) The University of Kentucky announced today the establishment of a memorial cancer fund to honor the memory of Adolph Rupp, the university's longtime basketball coach who died Saturday of cancer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The HouseSenate conference committee on the Social Security bill is deadlocked, and one of the most important pieces of legislation of the year is thus stalled over the unrelated issue of whether a special tax break should be given to the parents of college students.

ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 10 Four months after Ghana's military leaders were nearly toppled by an unusual campaign of civil disobedience, Gen. Ignatius Kutu Acheampong has reasserted control end is leading the country toward a new form of government that may perpetuate his leadership.

Some of the evidence from the animal testing used in a Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center report on laetrile last June has been found to be "erroneous," according to The Sciences, a magazine published by the New York Academy of Sciences.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 (AP) The Very Rev. Stanley Rodgers, Dean of Grace Cathedral, suffered a fatal heart attack yesterday shortly after delivering a sermon at the Episcopal church here. He was 49 years old.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 12 Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan said today that Israel might agree to partition the lands of the West Bank of the Jordan River if that was what the Arabs wanted.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 With no momentous football issues at stake, the Dallas Cowboys and San Francisco 49ers entertained 55,000 spectators in Candlestick Park and the season's last Monday night television audience with an 11-touchdown display tonight, ending with a 42-35 Dallas victory.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (AP) Soviet television showed Yuri Romanenko and Georgy Grechko working in the Salyut 6 space station today in their second day aboard the laboratory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The Supreme Court ruled today that employers can force workers to retire at age 60, despite the Federal ban on age discrimination, if the workers were members of an age60 pension plan before the ban went into effect.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) Attorney General Griffin B. Bell proposed today that the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration be abolished and replaced by a National Institute of Justice.
KANSAS CITY, Mo. The Army Corps of Engineers, under urgent prodding from the White House, has begun inspections of 9,000 "high-hazard" non-Federal dams that were identified in a 50-state inventory.

LINDEN, Dec. 12 Hundreds of Staten Island residents clogged telephone lines today, complaining about the droplets of oil that rained on their homes and automobiles saturday after a "blowout" at the Exxon Company's refinery here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The Agriculture Department said today that Federal personnel will take over inspection of meat and poultry plants that do business entirely within New Hampshire, effective Jan. 9.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 The Velsicol Chemical Corporation was indicted today on charges that it conspired to suppress the results of tests that allegedly showed that two widely used pesticides produced by the company may cause cancer in humans. Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan, a holdover from the administration of former Mayor John V. Lindsay, has survived the first winnowing of Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch's appointment process.

Luce, the Consolidated Edison Company's board chairman, charged today that a report by consulting engineers finding that Westchester County's electricity consumers could save up to 44.8 percent if the county took over the supplying of electricity from Con Edison was "very superficial."

The conversation format was used by Mr. Sevareid himself over many years for extended interviews with public figures ranging from Walter Lippmann to Anne Morrow Lindbergh.
A new technique for the detection of breast cancer being tested at the Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center appears to be completely safe and highly effective, the center announced Sunday.

The international adventure of an unwittingly illegal courier of Mayan art a mild-mannered, scholarly banker and former president of the New York City Y.M.C.A. has come to light after several years of mystery and speculation in archeological circles.

In one of the largest potential retailing mergers in recent years, Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., Los Angeles, the owner of both the Bergdorf Goodman and the Neiman-Marcus fashion stores, announced yesterday a $342 million bid for effective control of Marshall Field Company, the largest department store chain in Chicago.

WEST BERLIN, Dec. 12 A major spy scandal was disclosed today as the West German Defense Ministry said in Bonn that three persons who were arrested last year on charges of having spied for East Germany had had access to more than 1,000 secret military documents, including blueprints for Atlantic Alliance defense planning.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Dec. 12 The superintendent of the Fire Island National Seashore announced new rules today sharply restricting the use of motor vehicles on the island all year long.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) Federal pressure is getting trucking concerns to revise their schedules so that drivers are less likely to stay behind the wheel too long or to violate the 55mile-an-hour speed limit, the Transportation Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Japan presented to American officials today its proposals for dealing with the severe trade imbalance between the two nations, but the Americans promptly said that the proposals "fell considerably short" of what was needed.

New York City's Police Commissioner, Michael J. Codd, who will be leaving his $47,093-a-year post on Dec. 31, could receive a gross tax-free pension of $46,600 a year if his request for a line-of-duty disability pension is approved.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Unsubstan tiated reports circulated here today that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries may postpone its next semiannual meeting, now schduled for Dec. 20, in Caracas.

The New York City Board of Education agreed in 1974 to provide bilingual education for Hispanic children with English-language difficulties. This agreement, called "the Aspira consent decree," resolved a Federal lawsuit that had not reached the trial phase. Now, under pressure from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to desegregate the city school system, the board is claiming that the bilingual program makes desegregation impossible.
MATSUYAMA, Japan, Dec. 12 (Reuters) Japan's fourth-biggest business collapse since World War II occurred today when a court announced it was freezing the assets of the Hashihama shipbuilding company.

CLINTON, Dec. 12 The 90-foot-high Spruce Run Dam received generally high marks for safety today in becoming the first of 413 "high hazard" New Jersey dams to be inspected under a new Federal program. The program grew out of the recent dam collapse in Toccoa, Ga., that killed 38 persons.

WOOD-RIDGE, N.J., Dec. 12 Nearly 1,200 white-and blue-collar workers were forced out of work here today when the Curtiss-Wright Aerospace Corporation locked its gates in a dispute with two unions over a new contract.
MADRID, Dec. 12 (Reuters) Spain introduced new measures today to cut energy consumption as part of a general austerity program.

CAIRO, Dec. 12 The Egyptian Government was wrapping up arrangements today for its preparatory peace conference after stressing that all parties to the Middle East conflict were still welcome to attend.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The Carter Administration told Congress today that North Korea was engaged in a "major, long-term buildup" of its military forces and that this had given it a sizable advantage over South Korea.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Attorney General Griffin B. Bell named 10 persons today to take over the problem of allegedly illegal break-ins by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York. He thus replaced the group of five attorneys that suit the investigation last week after a sharp dispute with him over the proper strategy for handling the case.

But there can be little doubt that the appeal of "Anne Sexton: A Self-Portrait in Letters" is extraliterary.

Instead his country will have a trade surplus of over $13 billion, about $8.5 billion with the United States alone.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which has undergone major surgery in an effort to regain its former top rank in the supermarket industry, disclosed yesterday that it would report a loss of about $5 million for its fiscal third quarter.

The Federal Aviation Administration is looking into an unusual run of three incidents in the last two weeks in which, officials said, airliners over the New York area were given faulty instructions that brought them uncomfortably close to other planes.
An investigation into charges that John Maniscalco had often beaten his wife, Rosemary who died last week after 12 days in a coma was dropped yesterday by District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn.

Jerry Jenkins, who became a guest of the New York Hilton after his car was stolen, driven on a spree in Times Square that left one dead and 15 injured and was wrecked last week, yesterday gave up another free room at Rikers Island to be escorted back to Vermont to face criminal charges.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 13 A spokesman for the Venezuelan Government denied this afternoon that there were any plans for postponing the annual meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) that is scheduled to begin here Dec. 20.

Sam Goody Inc., New York's oldest record-tapes-audio equipment retail chain, has signed a preliminary agreement to merge with the Pickwick International subsidiary of the American Can Company, according to a joint announcement yesterday. WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 House energy conferees tried to break the natural gas deadlock today with a compromise proposal on intrastate gas sales, but the Senate side remained too deeply split over prices to respond.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 13 (UPI) A girl died last night of Injuries suffered Dec. 4 in a car crash caused by a youth who swung a pipe at the driver.

PASSAIC, N.J. The year 1972 is not recalled with affection by this venerable industrial city on the Passaic River. That was the year that Uniroyal Inc. and Raybestos-Manhattan Inc. pulled up stakes from their manufacturing facilities here, at a cost to Passaic of 3,000 jobs. Unemployment rose to 17 percent.

ABOUT 23 MILLION adult Americans have high blood pressure, a major cause of premature death and disability in this country. Most people think of high blood pressure as a disease of old age, but doctors now realize that the problem actually has its roots in childhood.

ATLANTA, Dec. 13 (AP) The National Bank of Georgia, once headed by Bert Lance, former Federal Budget Director, said today it had asked Federal bank regulators to allow trading of its stock to resume as scheduled this week when a 10-day trading halt expires.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 The worst form of smallpox, the kind that kills, blinds and maims, has been eradicated but a much milder form remains in Somalia on the horn of Africa, Dr. Halfdan Mahler, the head of the World Health Organization, said here today.

Anheuser-Busch, which has been looking for a new agency to replace Gardner Advertising as agency for its Busch Bavarian beer and Busch Gardens theme parks, yesterday announced it was splitting the assignment between two of the three finalist agencies. Needham, Harper Steers, Chicago, is getting the beer and McDonald Little, Atlanta, the parks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Henry W. Loomis, who has been president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting since 1972, announced today that he would retire at the end of his current term next September, or sooner, if a successor were found.

Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. called last night for President Carter and the leaders of both parties to convene a national employment conference of the nation's leading businesses to find work for the poor and unemployed.

The new superintendent of Community School District 5 in Harlem, citing "questionable practices" in the spending of Federal funds, has asked for an audit of the district. Schools Chancellor Irving Anker has said in reply that a full-scale audit will be undertaken.

A controversial bill that gives substantial raises to the city's top 51 incoming elected New York City officials, including the Mayor, the Comptroller and the City Council President, was approved last night by the City Council, 33 to 7.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 A $37.8 million Government contract to manufacture concrete railroad ties for the Northeast Corridor Project, originally earmarked for a company owned by members of a minority group, was awarded today to two white-owned concrete companies.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 13 (AP) The New Orleans Jazz gained a 117-94 victory tonight over the Los Angeles Lakers, who had to fly in a sick player to muster the eight-man squad required by National Basketball Association rules.

WINE LOVERS come into their own at holiday time. They have the key to the most desirable of all last-minute giftgiving routines. Anyone else may have fretted for weeks over what to give that grumpy uncle in Boston. The wine enthusiast sends him a bottle of Dom Perignon. What? He doesn't like champagne? What difference does that make? There is no finer gift. That's an end to it, grumpy uncle or not.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 With Congress about to put off final passage of an energy program until next year, Vice President Mondale conceded today that the Carter Administration had overloaded Congress and that some of its initiative had suffered from "fratricide."

WATERFORD, Conn., Dec. 13 (AP) Two explosions at the Millstone nuclear power plant today blew a door off a building at the plant, injuring one employee and releasing a "shall" amount of radioactive material.
ROME, Dec. 13 (UPI) The police reported firebomb and arson attacks against political party offices, a church and a West German commercial office today.

TRENTON, Dec. 13 The New Jersey Supreme Court overturned today an old but rarely enforced law forbidding sexual relations between a man and an unmarried woman, ruling it an unconstitutional invasion of privacy. The ruling did not apply to homosexual relations.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 12 The arrival on Australia's northern coast of a sudden rash of fishing boats carrying Vietnamese refugees in the last few weeks has provoked unusual xenophobia in a country that, since the end of World War II, has become accustomed to receiving large numbers of non-Anglo-Saxon immigrants.

LONDON, Dec. 13 The House of Commons adopted tonight a voting system for the first election of a European Parliament. The action by Commons will almost certainly delay that election until 1979.

ELIZABETH, Dec. 13 A seclusive elderly couple and their daughter were found slain in their flaming beds here this morning, and their son, discovered unconscious in his bedroom, died later at a local hospital.

TOKYO, Dec. 13 (AP) Mayor Ichio Asukata of Yokohama was unanimously elected today as chairman of Japan's opposition Socialist Party, but citizens of the port city denounced his election as a "betrayal."

As the Cairo conference convenes today appropriately enough, in the shadow of the Sphinx the Prime Minister of Israel and the President of Egypt, with the United States acting as uneasy middleman, are facing their moment of truth.

Killing has been dreadful and on an especially large scale in conflicts like the Thirty Years' War, World Wars I and II, Vietnam. But terrible as they have been, they were as nothing compared to what mankind now can do to mankind.

The Council for the Arts in Westchester will present to Nelson A. Rockefeller its 1977 Arts Award in recognition of "his lifelong commitment and leadership in the arts and in special recognition of the invaluable rule he has played in the growth of the arts in Westchester." BOSTON, Dec. 14--John Vorster and his colleagues in the South African Government, in their bitterness at current American policy, console themselves with one thought. They hope that before long another Administration will take a friendlier view of white supremacy in South Africa.

RISING burglary rates and the growing popularity of pleasure boating are chippingaway at the amount of protection many major insurance companies are willing to write into homeowner's coverage.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 14--Richard D. Hongisto, the former sheriff of San Francisco County, was sworn in today as Cleveland's chief of police, the third one this year.

ELVIS COSTELLO's New York debut Tuesday night at the Bottom Line was another of those eagerly awaited rock-and-rolloccasions that make following the rock world here so amusing, Mr. Costello is a leading member of London's new wave, at least in the looser sense of that term, although he really owes more to the pub rockers like Graham Parker and the rhythm-and-blues revival lists like Southside Johnny than to the true hunks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (Reuters)--Industry in the United States showed its biggest production gain in four months during November, despite slowdowns in auto and coal production, the Government reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--President Carter said tonight that his State of the Union message next month and the "major purpose" of his Administration in 1978 would be devoted to plans to strengthen the nation's economy.

Just when ski area operators throughout the East were becoming convinced the ski season was shaping up as an outstanding one, along came a forecast yesterday for a warming trend for the next three or four days.

CAIRO, Dec. 14 (AP)--Following are the official texts of the opening statements delivered in English at the Cairo conference on the Middle East by the chief Egyptian delegate, Ahmed Esmat Abdel Meguid; the chief Israeli delegate, Eliahu Ben-Elissar, and the chief United States delegate, Assistant Secretary of State Alfred L. Atherton Jr.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)--Attorney General Griffin Bell objected today to establishing a bankruptcy court system separate from the Federal district courts, saying the idea "is unwise as well as unneeded."

DETROIT, Dec. 14--Another slump in new-car sales was recorded in the first 10 days of December by the nation's automobile industry, as deliveries fell 6.3 percent below the level of a year earlier, according to reports issued today by the four major auto companies.
When the sickly old woman in the next apartment had trouble breathing one night, Maxine Campbell called the police. She told them that someone had just been shot next door.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI)--One of the nation's largest wildlife conservation groups has called off its four-year boycott of Japanese and Russian consumer goods because the two nations are complying with international efforts to conserve whales.

HOUSTON, Dec. 14--Jerry West, coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, had surveyed the events of violence and turbulence in the National Basketball Association during the last week, and he knew that now was a time to be magnanimous.
TOKYO, (Thursday), Dec. 15 (Reuters) --The dollar dropped sharply in early trading on the foreign exchange markets here, falling by more than two yen to another record low, 238 yen.

THE BEST of Families" began its eight-episode runon television in the setting of a heat wave in 1880. Last week, the three central families-the wealthy Wheelers, the middle-class Lathrops and the poor Raffertys--celebrated the birth of a new century on New Year's Eve 1899. Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, the final installment sud-denly jumps to 1977 and the coldest day of the year, Jan. 17.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--A $1 billion Army program to build an infantry combat vehicle has been sharply criticized by a Government agency that called the weapon slow, noisy, smoky, expensive and somewhat easy to destroy.

DENVER, Dec. 14--The American Agriculture Movement, which has been organizing a national farm strike that started today, makes a point of having no officers and of having its leadership shared among organizers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal told the Senate Banking Committee today that while the Carter Administration remained "firmly committed" to maintaining New York City's solvency, the continuation of a Federal loan program beyond next July 1 would have to be on "a declining basis."

For these who can appreciate greatness--in music, in a person and in a pianist--CarnegieHall was the place to be last night. Rudolf Serkin looking as ever like a benign and slightly befuddled chemistry professor, gave his annual Carnegie Hall recital for an audience that crammed the hall and overflowed into stage seats. Few of them could have gone away disappointed at what they heard.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 14 (AP)-The Alabama Supreme Court has ordered two convicted slayers put to death in the electric chair next March 10. It was the first time the court had fixed an execution date under the state's new death penalty law, erected by the Alabama Legislature.

A 39-year-old woman who owned a cooperative apartment in New York City and an expensively furnished $50,000 house in Suffolk County simultaneously received welfare payments in both places, the State Acting Welfare Inspector General charged yesterday.
Northfield, Mass. To find Dan and Robin Woodard'shouse, you drive over a mountain on a blacktop road until the blacktop ends, down a rutted dirt lane until the lane ends, and then you walk.
One of the hottest-selling toys this Christmas may not be a toy at all, but the promise of one.
TRENTON, Dec. 14--A plan to create a legislative oversight committee that would monitor actions by the executive branch was unveiled today.

Mutual savings banks experienced a net deposit inflow of $90 million in time and savings accounts last month, the smallest November gain since 1959, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)--Half of the nation's business leaders expect an economic recession in the United States within two years, and 15 percent think one will occur within a year, according to a poll released today.

"THE LION, the Witch and the Wardrobe," the first of a series of seven classic children's stories by C.S.Lewis, the British author, will be adapted by the Children's Television Workshop for broadcast on CBS-TV during prime time.

In a surprise move, the trustees of the Police Pension Board yesterday postponed a decision on granting the increasingly controversial request by outgoing Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd for a tax-free annual disability pension of $46,600.

TOKYO, Dec. 14--In the first detailed description of the proposed trade liberalization package delivered to Washington this week, the Japanese Government officially announced here tonight a number of tariff reductions and import quota expansions. Quantitative restrictions on imports of 27 categories of agricultural and manufactured goods were not abolished, according to the announcement.
COPIAGUE, L.I., Dec. 14 (UPI)--An 8-year-old boy was killed today when he leaned out the window of a moving school bus and his head struck a telephone pole, the Suffolk County police reported.

The condition of Rudy Tomjanovich, the Houston Rockets' star who was hospitalized Friday after having been struck by Kermit Washington of the Los Angeles Lakers, continued to improve yesterday. Surgery was tentatively scheduled for Saturday morning.

The head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association pledged yesterday that his union would cooperate fully with Robert J. McGuire, a 41-year-old lawyer who is scheduled to be named Police Commissioner today by Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 14--Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today that his trip to the United States was for the purpose of meeting with President Carter on new ideas "connected directly with the peace-making process."

SCHOOL GROOVES Down at New York University's Loeb Student Center, a thriving jazz sanctum in Greenwich Village, tribute will be paid tonight at 8 to the veteran tenor saxophonist Al Cohn. This is the annual evening of the "Highlights in Jazz" series that honors a living musician, and the special guest, whose contributions in the field go back to the bands of Artie Shaw, Woody Herman and Buddy Rich, is still very much with us.

CAIRO, Dec. 14--Egyptian and Israeli negotiators met today across a conference table in Cairo while Americans looked on, opening a new effort to work out a satisfactory framework for a peace settlement in the Middle East.

CAIRO, Dec. 14--Egyptian and Israeli negotiators met today across a conference table in Cairo while Americans looked on, opening a new effort to work out a satisfactory framework for a peace settlement in the Middle East.

CAIRO, Dec. 14 (AP)--Following are the official texts of the opening statements delivered in English at the Cairo conference on the Middle East by the chief Egyptian delegate, Ahmed Esmat Abdel Meguid; the chief Israeli delegate. Eliahu Ben-Elissar, and the chief United States delegate, Assistant Secretary of State Alfred L. Atherton Jr.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 14--Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today that his trip to the United States was for the purpose of meeting with President Carter on new ideas "connected directly with the peace-making process."
Fred Gladstone, a builder in New York City and Florida, died Tuesday at a hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old and had lived in Palm Beach since 1950.

FIRST there was the brownstone movement, then "alternative use" of existing buildings began cropping up: the rundown factory into a chic collection of shops, the unused railroad station into a restaurant.

Judging from the results of a redemption last spring, there must be a number of rueful former holders of National Starch and Chemical securitiesnow that National Starch is about to become a part of Unilever, the giant international food and drug company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed rules defining the circumstances in which an accountant involved in litiga-tion will not be considered independent from the client he is auditing.
At 41 years of age, some thought, Robert J. McGuire was about to become the city's youngest Police Commissioner. Not so.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The president of the Aerospace Industries Association called today for a "clear signal" from the Carter Administration and Congress as to whether they are committed to keeping the United States the world leader in aerospace technology.

LONDON, Dec. 14--The Liberal Party retreated tonight from a threat to break off its Parliament alliance with the Labor Party, giving yet another reprieve to the crisis-ridden Government of Prime Minister James Callaghan.

The stock market yesterday ignored the slump of the dollar abroad and news of lower domestic automobile sales as the Dow Jones industrial average showed late strength to post its first noteworthy gain of the week.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14--The General Assembly today adopted 14 resolutions--a record--condemning apartheid in South Africa, including one censuring Israel for its economic relations with South Africa.
The Municipal Assistance Corporation announced yesterday that it plans to refund $250 million of its outstanding bonds in order to get lower interest rates and longer maturity.

FEW PIANISTS are viewed with such awed admiration by their colleagues as Martha Argerich. She is a born virtuoso, witha staggering yet effortless command of the keyboard, and an elemental, even animal, vitality that must be the envy of many a more civilized artist.
"For the incumbent agency, making a pitch is like going to a wake," said Donald E. Creamer, chairman of Creamer Lois FSR.

JAZZMANIA, the fourth-floor walkup jazz room at 14 East 23d Street, founded in 1974 by Mike Morgenstern, a bass clarinetistin search of a place to play, is celebrating its third birthday this week with a six-day festival that began Tuesday eve-ning and will continue through Sunday. Normally the room is open only on Friday and Saturday evenings.

Strategy in backgammon has evolved considerably in the last few years--particularly with regard to the opening stages of the game. Experts today emphasize quick and efficient development, rather than the safety of individual men. Bold play like this often leads to complicated positions in which both sides have several men back early in the game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal told the Senate Banking Committee today that while the Carter Administration remained "firmly committed" to maintaining New York City's solvency, the continuation of a Federal loan program beyond next July 1 would have to be on "a declining basis."
A state audit has charged that New York City's program of home attendants for the elderly sick poor is pockmarked with nearly $8.4 million a year--more than 10 percent--in errors and fraud.

One of the American stars who won the world championship in Manila is a man of many talents. Eddie Kantar of Los Ankles is a fine athlete who used to rank high in tournament table tennis and can beat almost any amateur tennis player.

TORONTO, Dec. 14--The Islanders should teach Borje Salming some more bad words. The Toronto Maple Leafs' star defenseman, a native of Sweden, spouted off to the referee in the first period of tonight's game at Maple Leaf Gardens and was sent off for a two-minute penalty, during which the Islanders scored a goal.

Despite White House assurances to the British-French Concorde team that such action would be delayed, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey adopted a noise rule yesterday that would keep the supersonic airliner from using New York airports in 1985.

One of the academic community's mostsuccessful affirmative action programs,aimed at producing more minority engi-neers, is quietly moving toward its goal and avoiding much of the controversy that has surrounded other special recruit-ing efforts.

Louis Stulberg, a nationally known labor leader who was president of the 400,000-member International Ladies Garment Workers Union from 1966 to 1975, died yesterday at his home at 25 Central Park West after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

NEWARK, Dec. 14--Officials of the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission said here today that New Jersey would be unable to meet the Dec. 31, 1981, federally imposed deadline for an end to ocean-dumping of sludge. They said that a ruling by Eckardt C. Beck, regional administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency, which voided bidding procedures because of rule violations for an $80 million sewage treatment plant here, would result in a crucial delay in construction.

ALTHOUGH EDWARD GOREY is primarily thought of as an artist and illustrator, he is also a gifted writer; his proseis as intricate and as elegant as his spidery pictures. Together, words and drawings form little Victorian melodramas, cliff-hanging Gothic tales of malfeasance, mischief and pranks of fate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The principal contractor on the Northeast Corridor rail improvement project urged the Government as recently as last May to award a $37 million contract for concrete cross ties to any of "four or five" minority business qualified to handle it.
MIAMI--Investigators from five Feder-al and local agencies are actively pursu-ing here one of the largest financial fraud inquiries in recent history.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14--The Soviet Union announced plans today for low growth rates in key sectors of its economy during 1978, including the smallest increase in heavy industrial production since World War II.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 14--Sec-retary of State Cyrus R. Vance flies back to Washington tomorrow convinced that his latest Middle East mission has underscored the need for the United States to be as active as ever in the region's complicated diplomacy.

IF NEW YORKERS are curious about whether their new Mayor-elect dances, he does. A Fred As-taire he is not--his style is 1950-ish, heads-to-temple and his partner's, right hand held rigidly vertical. But Edward I. Koch was very visible on the dance floor of the Plaza's grand ballroom Tuesday night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--House and Senate conferees cleared the way today for final Congressional approval tomorrow of a multibillion-dollar Social Security tax increase.

Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 14--The South Korean Government has asked the United States to agree to the unconditional return of Tongsun Park as part of a deal under which the indicted businessman would be returned to Washington to testify on an alleged Korean scheme to buy influence with members of Congress, informed Korean sources said today.

An elderly Brooklyn couple, who Converted the basement of their two-family house into a third apartment and wound up with an albatross around their necks, have won relief in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

These are auspicious days for the Federal program of legal assistance to the poor, that embattled but successful survivor of the late war on poverty. The Legal Services Corporation is on the verge of receiving more money and a fresh charter from Congress. And now President Carter has moved to desegregate--by race, sex and profession--the corporation's 11-member board of directors which, as currently constituted, is all-white, all-male and all-lawyer.

DENVER, Dec. 14--Marvin Davis, a wealthy, independent Colorado oilman, announced today that he had an agreement to buy the Oakland A's and hoped to bring the club to Denver next year, pending approval by the American League and the settlement of the A's current stadium contract in Oakland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)--A special House subcommittee on welfare today defeated attempts to weaken a proposal that would require welfare parents of young children to take part-time jobs or lose their cash benefits.
Dr. Kenneth May, professor of mathematics and of the history of science at the University of Toronto, died Dec. 1 of a heart attack at his home in Toronto. He was 62 years old.

ALTHOUGH they have been around for many years, interior paints that create a three-dimensional, textured finish on walls and ceilings have became popular again with many homeowners and apartment dwellers. Particularly suitable for do-it-yourself painters who have "problem" walls or ceilings, these paints have a much heavier body than ordinary flat paints, with a creamy consistency that makes them easy to apply without dripping or spattering.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The Roman Catholic Church in the United States, through its social action agency, appealed to the Carter Administration today to offer unlimited asylum to refugees who have fled by boat from Vietnam, and it promised to find them homes and jobs even without financial help from the Government.

Why has capital spending revived so slowly in the current business recovery? One of the most common explanations --asserted by many businessmen and business economists--is that corporate profits are too low by historical standards...

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 12--Every afternoon the men in tattered clothes push against each other in the betting shops of Kingston to hear the results of some distant horse race. They are part of the army of jobless men who have drifted into the capital, walking the streets past women hawking green bananas and citrus fruits spread on newspaper on the sidewalk.

The New York Telephone Company will postpone its shortening of the time the drop of a dime will buy in a pay phone, a spokesman said yesterday because the company is not sure the added revenue will exceed the cost of the changeover.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved a $1.5 million extension of a World Trade Center cleaning contract that has been criticized for alleged irregularityies in an un-released New York State Comptroller's report.

WASHINGTON--American exports have been growing since the second quarter of 1975, but not so rapidly or steadily as imports, especially imports of oil. The result has been a trade deficit approaching $30 billion this year,five times the previous record.

The Tokyo Shibaura Electric Company of Japan announced plans yesterday to build a color television factory at Nashville. It is the sixth Japanese electronics company to decide to assemble TV sets in the United States.

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 14 (Reuters)--Canada will resume shipments of uranium to the European Economic Community on Jan. 1, Guido Brunner, the Common Market's Commissioner of Energy, told the European Parliament here today.

ARCHITECTURE can sometimes be like a Broadway play--a good concept that may need a bit of tinkering before it canattain commercial success. That was surely the case with the U.S. Steak-house Company, a restaurant that opened in 1975 in the Time Life Building in Rockefeller Center.

WITH AN ASSERTION that the incoming administration of Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch had not consultedthe Commission on Cultural Affairs in its planning for the future of the arts and the city, Martin E. Segal, the unsal-aried chairman of the commission, yesterday submitted his resignation.

Government bond prices dropped sharply yesterday as Treasury securities were pushed down after the Federal Reserve drained some reserves from the banking system temporarily. Corporate bond prices, meanwhile, were hit by news that the Bankers Trust Company sought to sell $150 million of high-grade long-term bonds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--President Carter said tonight that his State of the Union message next month and the "major purpose" of his Administration in 1978 would be devoted to plans to strengthen the nation's economy.

Congressional hearings into the state of the arts and humanities will be held in New York tomorrow and Saturday. People prominent in the arts anti humanities will testify at both healings. The public is invited to attend.

The election of Joseph P. Flannery as president, chief operating officer and director of Uniroyal Inc., one of the nation's largest tire and rubber companies, was announced yesterday by David Baretta, chairman and chief executive officer.

PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 14--The New Jersey Nets, who had their longest victory streak of the season--two games--broken by the Boston Celtics last night, bounced back tonight and defeated the Golden State Warriors, 108-104, before a crowd of 3,363, in Rutgers gymnasium.

George W. Russell, senior vice president and a director of the American Cyanamid Company, died Tuesday night at Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. after a short illness. Mr. Russell, 62 years old, lived on Indian Trail Drive in Franklin Lakes, N.J.

Steve Cauthen, the sensational 17-year-old jockey, was named "Sportsman of the Year" yesterday by Sports Illustrated. Cauthen picked up the Grecian vase trophy at a mid-morning luncheon, then went to work at Aqueduct where he had one winner in four trips to the post.

VIENNA, Dec. 14--The small Austrian Communist Party, apparently reflecting Moscow's views, said in a statement this week, that Israel had a "right to existence," but must withdraw from occupied Arab terrorities and agree to creation of a Palestinian state.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--Defense Secretary Harold Brown, in placing a lid on the Navy's budget for next year, has ordered a sharp cutback in the production of F-14 jet fighters that could mean the loss of thousands of jobs on Long Island.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 14 (Reuters)--A law passed yesterday will require women wanting an abortion to get approval from two doctors belonging to a committee appointed by Parliament.

Solomon Dickstein, who produced plays in Yiddish both on Broadway and on Second Avenue, died Tuesday at the Vanderbilt Nursing Home on Staten Island. He was 87 years old and lived at 154 Avenue P, in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14--The Soviet Union announced plans today for low growth rates in key sectors of its economy dur-ing 1978, including the smallest increase in heavy industrial production since World War II.

DENVER, Dec. 14--Farmers opened their national strike today with picketingof food stores, long caravans of flag-draped tractors and attempts in some areas of Texas to block deliveries of food and milk. The purpose was to cut off food supplies until they receive higher prices for their crops.
WASHINGTON, Dec, 14 (UPI)--Attorney General Griffin Bell gave approval today for 5,000 Soviet refugees, most of them Jews, to enter the United States by May 1.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 14--The New York Knicks made the big plays down the stretch tonight and captured their second National Basketball Association nail-biter in two nights with a 101-98 conquest of the Indiana Pacers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--J. Edgar Hoover told Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy in 1963 that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had information that Mr. Kennedy had paid a $500,000 settlement and had had court records sealed in a lawsuit brought by a woman who said she had been engaged to marry his brother, John F. Kennedy, in 1951.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec, 14--Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel and his ar-chrival, Bulent Ecevit, who heads the main opposition party, have become locked in another struggle for power, the second in five months.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14--The United States has decided to press Vietnamese authorities for the release of three Americans held since their sailboat was seized in October off southern Viet-nam.

RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 14 (AP)--King Hassan II of Morocco reportedly began diplomatic moves today toward convening an emergency conference of Arab leaders to consider the outcome of the Israeli-Egyptian talks in Cairo.

LE GROUPE de la Place Royale, a feisty little modern-dance troupe founded in 1966 in Montreal, made its New Yorkdebut last night by raising the sort of questions nobody bothers about much in these parts.

The National Basketball Association said last night that it was considering decisive steps to try to bring an end to the incidents of serious violence that have plagued league play over the last few years. The most recent incident was the spectacular fight in Los Angeles last Friday that resulted in the hospitalization of a longtime N.B.A. player, Rudy Tomjanovich.

Salesmen for one surgical eduipment supply company have participated, to some extent, in more than 900 operations, and have "scrubbed in" on more than 3,000 operations in New York State in the last five years, the president of the company said yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 15 Members of the Yale Corporation who still hope to decide on a new president for Yale University this weekend, have backtracked a bit now that Dean Henry Rosovsky of Harvard has declined to take the post. William P. Bundy, who heads the search effort, said today that the corporation "will go back to the drawing board"

In the following record of observations yesterday at weather stations In the United States, high and low temperatures given are for the 20-hour period ended at 8 P.M.; precipitaton totals given are for the 24-hour period ended at 8 P.M. Weather descriptions are forecalled conditions for today. (All times are in Eastern Standard Time.)
Irv Levin, the owner of the Boston Celtics, has asked Red Auerbach to return to coaching for the remainder of the season, leaving doubts about Tom Heinsohn's future.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Congress approved today and sent to President Carter a Social Security financing bill that Republicans denounced as "the biggest peacetime tax increase in history."
DENVER, Dec. 15 The new owner of the Oakland Athletics, who are about to become the Denver somethings, may yet accomplish the stupendous feat of making Charles O. Finley look colorless.

For all the merriment of the Christmas season, vacation time can hang heavy on the hands of city schoolchildren, especially those with working parents whose playmates have all gone off to sunnier or snowier climes for the holidays.
NEWARK, Dec. 15 New Jerseyans have either eight shopping days until Christmas or nine, depending on where they live and, in some instances, what they want to buy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance returned from the Middle East today and reported to President Carter later that the Israeli Government was "rethinking" its once strongly held insistence on retaining complete control over the territory on the West Bank of the Jordan River it has occupied since 1967.

Mayor Beame won the passage of millions of dollars of lucrative Federal job training contracts last night many of them going to his political allies at what was to have been the last Board of Estimate meeting of his administration.

MADRID, Dec. 15 Spain's political temperature has risen sharply following deadly confrontations between demonstrators and the police in Malaga and the Canary Islands, which are both plagued by heavy unemployment and with the specter of further trouble in the volatile Basque region.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 In defining the role of the United States in the Middle East peace negotiations during his latest press conference, President Carter used an interesting phrase, which indicates that he is thinking about the day after tomorrow. His hope, he said, was that the negotiators would define a genuine peace, a predictable peace, and "a relationship among human beings that might transcend the incumbency of any particular leader."

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 The Soviet authorities have decided to extend by six months the pretrial detention of Anatoly Shcharansky, a Jewish activist accused in the official press of having worked for the Central Intelligence Agency, his mother told Western correspondents today.

PUTNEY, Vt., Dec. 15 (UPI) Fire today raced through the arts and crafts building at the Putney School, an exclusive coeducational prep school that has educated children from some of the nation's most prominent families. All students were removed safely soon after the fire broke out.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 President Carter said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization had forfeited the right to speak for Palestinian Arabs at any forthcoming Middle East peace talks, but the President added that a solution to the Palestinian problem was still vital to achieve an enduring peace in the region.
Governor Carey yesterday appointed State Senator Karen S. Burstein, a consumer-advocate and a liberal, to the Public Service Commission.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 15 For a third time, the apparent winner of the November election for First Selectman in Greenwich has changed temporarily.
Vice President Mondale was presented with the Spirit of the City award by the Cathedral of St. John the Divine last night in recognition of his expressed concern for New York City.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 (Reuters) Security Council members agreed today toa six-month extension of the mandate of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus. The mandate was to have expired tonight.
Exploratory merger talks are under way between the Seaboard Coast Line Industries Inc. and the Southern Pacific Company, the two transportation holding companies disclosed late yesterday.

No one can accuse Ann Wilson, an artist and art historian, of thinking small. By means of paintings, constructions danc ers, actors and singers, she's produced an epic environmental and theatrical work entitled "Butler's Lives of the Saints" (after an 18th-century chronicle by an Englishman, Alban Butler). It's a paean to those exalted creators whose visionary ideas have plunged them into struggle and suffering and sometimes even madness.
A double fare will be eliminated early next month at three key subway transfer points to encourage increased ridership, according to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

A Manhattan gang, whose members worked just a decade ago as teen-age errand boys for major narcotics traffickers, has now emerged as a new and violent force of its own in organized crime in New York, according to confidential police and Federal agency intelligence reports.

HE WAS an alert horse but plain, a dark foal with coarse features and a body that seemed out of proportion. His head was too big, his legs too long." This is Steve Cady's description of Seattle Slew on the morning of Feb. 15, 1974, as he struggled to his feet in the foaling stall.

If too many chefs spoil the broth, can too many chiefs ruin management? "Yes," according to Frank R. Beaudine, president of Eastman Beaudine Inc., one of the nation's large management recruiting firms.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 15 (AP) In a rematch of what was billed as "Charlotte's greatest fight," a 51year-old boxer. Neil Wallace, finally got his revenge on 49-year-old Waban (Tugboat) Thomas last night.

HONOLULU, Dec. 15 The big saltwater tanks at the Marine Research Facility at Kewalo Basin are still empty, but plans are afoot to resume the dolphin testing program that was stopped last May 29 when two employees released the test animals into the sea.

The former custodian of Far Rockaway High School and his assistant, the school's present custodial foreman, were indicted by a Queens grand jury ysterday on charges of taking kickbacks of more than $9,000 each from their employees and falsifying records to conceal the transactions.

VILNIUS, U.S.S.R. The Palanga Restaurant is one of the most popular spots in Vilnius, the capital of Soviet Lithuania. It is a vast room taking up the entire top floor of a modern twostory building on Lenin Prospekt, and from the street the dull beat of a cock group's drums can be heard through the big steamed-up windows.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 The Resource Conservation Committee, an interagency study group, announced today that it would recommend to President Carter and Congress eight provisions to be included in any Federal legislation on mandatory beverage container deposits.

EAST BERLIN, Dec. 12 A year ago, East Germany was gripped by political tensions as dissident intellectuals protested the forced exiling of a folk singer, and thousands of people flooded authorities with applications for permission to move to the West. Now, these energies appear spent.
CAIRO, Dec. 15 Middle East peace negotiators met today behind closed doors for their first formal session, then adjourned for a long weekend.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 The White House has ordered the Defense Department to conduct a major review of contingency plans for waging nuclear war against the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Congress approved today and sent to President Carter a Social Security financing bill that Republicans denounced as "the biggest peacetime tax increase in history."
A tax-evasion trial of Anthony Salerno, reputedly an important figure in organized crime, ended in a mistrial yesterday when the jury remained deadlocked after three days of deliberation.

DETROIT, Dec. 15 (AP) United States auto makers are stepping up production this week to make up for cars and trucks that could not be built because of last week's snowstorms, Ward's Automotive Reports, the trade publication, estimated today.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 15 (AP) The European Common Market announced today it is investigating a dumping charge against United States producers of kraft liner, a type of corrugated paper used in packaging.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Prime Minister Menahem Begins unexpected trip to the United States on the day that the Cairo conference opened seems to indicate that substantive talks on as Arab-Israeli settlement are under way now. Israel's security must figure prominently in such talks, but no impasse should be expected over that issue. Israel's security need not conflict with any legitimate expectations that the Arabs may have from a negotiated peace.

Until just about 10 years ago, scrimshaw, made from the teeth and bones of whales could be bought at the gift counter of the Whaling Museum in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. It was odd commerce, the museum's present executive director, Gerard W. Dempsey, acknowledged the other day, since the museum celebrates an animal whose numbers dwindle with each year.

About 60 shotguns and rifles as well as ammunition were stolen from Outdoorsman Inc., a sporting goods store at 257 Sunrise Highway, Merrick, L.I., the Nassau County police reported. The total value was put at $25,000. A Federal judge in Manhattan imposed prison sentences on three Croatian nationalists convicted of charges involving an armed invasion of the Yugoslav Mission to the United Nations.

A planned cutback in the production of F-14 jet fighters would be a "stab in the back of the economy of New York State," the Corey administration charged yesterday, and would cause the loss of at least 5,000 jobs, most of them on Long Island.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 A member of the Senate Select Intelligence Committee said today thatt he Central Intelligence Agency's recently p ublished regulations on relations with the news media opened new "loopholes" for using journalists as covert operators.

Last Monday's decision by the Texas Railroad Commission ordering the Coastal States Gas Corporation to refund more than $1.2 billion to its customers in effect makes Coastal States OPEC's latest victim.

CONTRARY to what some people may think, a knife, chisel, wood plane or similar cutting tool is actually safer to use when its blade is very sharp, rather than being dull or nicked. A dull or incorrectly sharpened blade is not only harder to use and slower to work with, it also requires much more pressure on the tool's handle, and this means there is a much greater chance of slipping and an accident occurring.

Christmas is celebrated in almost every country of the world. But while the sprit and meaning of the occasion are the same everywhere, the ways of celebrating it vary tremendously from culture to culture. CONTRARY to what some people may think, a knife, chisel, wood plane or similar cutting tool is actually safer to use when its blade is very sharp, rather than being dull or nicked. A dull or incorrectly sharpened blade is not only harder to use and slower to work with, it also requires much more pressure on the tool's handle, and this means there is a much greater chance of slipping and an accident occurring.
