Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Friedman of St. James, L.I., and New York of the engagement of Mrs. Friedman's daughter, Della Abby Gilson, to Dr. Jeffrey A. Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Levy of Rhinebeck, N.Y.
DETROIT, Dec. 17 (AP) Vito Giacalone, a reputed gangster, was acquitted by a Federal grand jury yesterday of charges that he masterminded a multimillion-dollar numbers racket in Detroit.

CAIRO, Dec. 17?President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said today that Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel would come to Egypt within the next few days?earlier than originally planned. He announced the visit without waiting to know the full details of the Israeli proposals carried to Washington by Mr. Begin.

Peru has a grave cash problem, which many bankers believe could lead to the first major default on foreign loans by a third-world nation. After borrowing almost $1 billion from American banks to buy Soviet arms, Peru's military rulers find their nation skidding toward insolvency.

Investors who have credibility problems with the rosy bottom-line figures of American business in these times of continuing inflation got some sympathy last week from Harold M. Williams, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Margaret Danita Hair and Morgan C. Brown 3d. 1970 graduates of Syracuse University, were married yesterday in St. Baylon Roman Catholic Church in Hollis, Queens, by the Rev. Ernest Rudloff.

The performance of Puccini's "La Boheme," given by the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night went smoothly and affectingly, and one of the reasons it did was that Leona Mitchell, taking the part of Musetta for the first time with the company, sang and acted convincingly.
DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 17 Ann and Michael Coburn were ordained this morning as Episcopal priests, becoming the first married couple in the nation to be ordained together into the priesthood.

On Wednesday, Aug. 31, 1977, 27 Mexicans and six Americans boarded the Mexicana Airlines 8:30 A.M. flight to Oaxaca at Mexico City International Airport. The tall, smooth gringo in a tan leisure suit and shades who got on right before the doors closed went more or less unnoticed. He wore a deep blue polyester shirt patterned with red and orange blossoms. His tourist permit listed him as one Henry Amazon, a...

Creating torrents or new movement concerns Nancy Zendora much less than performing a few motions with extreme concentration and weight. She could be categorized as a minimalist for the zenlike economy and tranquillity of her dances, in which sitting in a chair can be an exercise in style. She presented "The Voice of Things" and "Inner Landscapes" at Hunter College on Thursday evening, in a program that was thought-provoking rather than instinctively enjoyable.

It has been a banner year for automobile makers, those mighty engines of the American economy. Record profits are in store for the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company. But support for the auto industry appears to be running out of gas on Wall Street.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17 (UPI) The Soyuz 26 astronauts finished reactivating the main onboard systems and some of the scientific instruments aboard the orbiting Salyut 6 laboratory during their first week in space, Tass said today.

The marriage of Julianne Quinn La Fond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Donovan La Fond of Tenafly, N.J., to Grant Fraser Bowman, took place yesterday at the La Fonds' summer home in New Milford, Conn. The Rev. Alastair C. Sellars of the Newtown (Conn.) Congregational Church performed the ceremony.
VULCAN, W.Va., Dec. 17 (AP) A Russian reporter says that the power of the Soviet press may have forced the state of West Virginia to help a small town get a new bridge.
VIENNA, Dec. 17 (Reuters) Leopold Boeham, an Austrian retailer, paid more than $1.2 million for the release of his kidnapped wife today, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 President Carter told Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel tonight that the United States regarded his latest peace proposals as "a constructive approach" toward an overall Middle East settlement.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17 In the past 20 months, there have been at least 27 unsolved murders perhaps as many as 41 in suburbs and rural areas near here. In each of three recent cases, a man died of shotgun wounds and a woman was abducted; one of the women was later found beaten to death and the other two are still missing.

CANDYMAKING is increasingly becoming a lost art. The number of acceptable commercial sweets on the market, a calorieconscious public and the time, patience and cost involved in producing handmade candies discourages all but the most persistent outlets, whose following is faithful and carries over from year to year.

Throughout American history, black intellectuals, artists, activists and politicians have argued among themselves over what path to take toward full equality: integration into mainstream America, or selfchosen separation? It is Thomas Blair's intention to examine how this debate took shape in the turbulent "second Reconstruction" since the Supreme Court's 1954 school desegregation decision.

Mary Newbold Warden, daughter of Mrs. H.H. Hugo Fries of Wilmington, Del., and Herbert W. Warden 3d of New York, was married yesterday to Herbert Hudson Taylor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The Rev. Eric G. Crichton performed the ceremony in the Calvary Independent Church in Lancaster, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Pro football produced another wild scene today at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium when the Washington Redskins persevered in the final seconds and defeated the Los Angeles Rams, 17-14, thus preserving their chances to qualify for the National Football League's postseason playoffs.
Cathleen Debra Krueger and David E. Cohen, graduates of Johns Hopkins University, plan to be married in March.
ALBANY, Dec. 17 (AP) The Town of Massena has won the latest round of its longstanding court battle to take over the facilities of the Niagara Mohawk utility and start its own power company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) A new mail service called Express Mail is the best hope for getting Christmas packages to their destinations by Dec. 25, the Postal Service said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Business associates of Bert Lance, the former director of the Office of Management and Budget, are scheduled to meet Monday in Washington with representatives of Arab financial interests to negotiate a purchase of the control of the National Bank of Georgia, a source close to Mr. Lance said tonight.

In the depths of the Great Depression a retailer needed an edge to get by, and Sam Goody had one. He bought up discarded old records for well a song and sold them at a good markup to aficionados eager to fill in their collections of jazz vocals of the early 1920's and the like.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) Philip C. Habib, the third highest official in the State Department, was reported in critical condition today at Walter Reed Army Hospital with a suspected heart attack.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 18 (Reuters) The kidnapped son of President Spyros Kyprianou was released unharmed early today and returned home to a hero's welcome after more than three days as the hostage of guerrillas seeking the release of jailed comrades.

A new program in New York State requiring visual inspection and photographs of automobiles for which property-damage insurance is sought is causing controversy within the insurance industry and among car owners.
HONOLULU, Dec. 18 A plan to build a rapid transit corridor through the congested heart of Honolulu has picked up important support and important opposition in recent weeks.

Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, yesterday presented Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch with a modified plan for New York City financing that calls for Federal guarantees of new M.A.C. bonds and increased participation by New York State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 One week before Bert Lance resigned as budget director last September and returned home to Georgia, officials of the three principal Federal bank regulatory agencies appeared before a Senate committee and said that both the nation's banking system and its regulatory mechanisms were essentially sound.

Soviet military officers admire the United States Army's professionalism, the experience and stability of its noncommissioned officers and the freedom given junior officers to use their own initiative in combat, according to Defense Department specialists who have a studied Soviet assessments of the American military establishment.

It's been a long time, nearly nine years, since Zara Nelsova played a New York recital, but this season the cellist has compensated for her absence with a pair of recitals at the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. There would also have been a third if a bout of flu had not caused her to cancel the first concert in the series.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 18 A. Bartlett Giamatti, a 39-year-old Renaissance literature scholar, emerged today as the leading candidate to become the 18th president of Yale University.
Morris O. Alprin's holiday greeting card is specially designed to express his appreciation of the annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
CORTLAND, N. Y. A decline in standardized test scores is but the most recent indicator that American education is in trouble.
The wheeling Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the ninth-largest steelmaker in the nation, announced yesterday that it would raise its prices for basic sheet products by 7 percent on Jan. 3.

LARGO, Md., Dec. 18 A crush of people crammed into a room today at Capital Center, the gigantic entertainment arena 15 miles from Washington, for an unusual party after a benefit performance of the Moscow Circus. Mingling with needy children, Washington socialites and Administration officials were Russian Embassy aides, Russian children and a Russian baby bear.

HONG KONG, Dec. 12 When Wang Kuo-ying's parents arranged to introduce him to a prospective bride, a young woman from a nearby production team, he was happy indeed. As the daughter of a poor peasant family she had the proper class background, and she was considered a strong worker so she would be an asset in earning, work points, the main source of income for Chinese peasants on the mainland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Rosalynn Carter said today that she and the President had each made an important mistake this year, he by "not consulting in the very beginning with Congress as much as he could have," and she by not campaigning harder far the equal rights amendment.
The Beame administration and New York City's firemen's unions have apparently agreed to have the city assume full responsibility for the Fire Department Pension Fund's $700 million deficit.

Frank Navarro, who coached Columbia to its last winning football season in 1971, returned to the Ivy League yesterday after a four-year absence when he accepted the head football coaching job at Princeton.

VAL GARDENA, Italy, Dec. 18 (AP) -Herbert Plank of Italy defeated Franz Klammer, the Austrian downhill expert, by two seconds today and won the men's World Cup downhill race on Klammer's favorite course.
The complications of the National Football League's playoff system finally resolved themselves yesterday in a simple way: The regular season ended.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 18 Service workers at Yale University overwhelmingly ratified a three-year contract here today and prepared to return to their jobs on Wednesday, ending a two-anda-half-month strike that had closed most university dining halls and forced students to clean their own halls and bathrooms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 A Senate committee report issued today describes the current system of Federal bank regulation as "duplicative, confusing and inconsistent" and recommends a major consolidation of the supervisory functions of the three principal bank regulatory agencies.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 18 A consensus appears to have developed among third-world and Western delegates that Secretary General Kurt Waldheim should appoint a director general, who would be a sort of "economic czar" and the second-ranking official at the United Nations after Mr. Waldheim himself.

In a significant move, Governor Carey has declined flatly to endorse Comptroller Arthur Levitt for renomination but has expressed a strong preference for Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak to be his running mate again next year.
RENO, Dec. 18 (AP) William Loeb, the publisher of The Manchester Union Leader in New Hampshire, and his wife, Nackey, were seriously injured yesterday in a traffic accident south of here.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 18 There was no immediate official reaction to Prime Minister Begins proposals in Arab political quarters here, but they saw no reason for optimism.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 It was a long, long time from May, when the first rookies showed up, to December, and today the Jets played as if they hadn't learned a thing in between.

FUNCHAL, Madeira, Monday, Dec. 19 (Reuters) A Swiss airliner on a chartered vacation flight to this Atlantic resort island crash-landed in the sea near here last night, with 13 people killed, 23 missing and 21 survivors, maritime authorities said today.

A firebomb was tossed through a window in a house in the City Island section of the Bronx yesterday, and a second firebomb was thrown against the side of a van parked in front. The house is at 153 Schofield Street.
MOSCOW, Dec. 18 (AP) Sweden scored four goals in the second period and defeated the Quebec Nordiques of the World Hockey Association, 6-2 today in the Izvestia hockey tournament.

In this season of heavy entertaining, few guests are in greater demand than a select group of 960 Manhattanites who have suddenly found themselves flooded with invitations to cocktail parties, kaffeeklatsches, intimate at-home gatherings and more formal evenings devoted to serious discussion.

ROME, Dec.18 The Italian Communist Party is increasing its demands for a greater voice in the decisions of the minority Government of Prime Minister Giurio Andreotti than it has had under the a legislative arrangement worked out last summer.
RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 18 King Hussein of Jordan arrived here today for talks with King Khalid of Saudi Arabia and others of the nation's leaders.

If ever someone needed a hat it was Ron Duguay, the 20-year-old Ranger rookie center with the the buck-private haircut, courtesy of his teammates. And last night, thanks to the rainy weather, there were hats galore in Madison Square Garden to be tossed to the ice when Duguay scored three goals in New York's thumping 6-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 18 The American Committee on Africa has protested to President Carter against the planned sale of civilian airplanes to South Africa, objecting that the planes, which have been ordered for use in crop-dusting, could be used against black nationalist forces opposing the white minority Government.

SPOTSWOOD, Dec. 18 Cecelia Ostapiej is leading a neighborhood campaign in this small, semirural community to remove a new 50-foot high citizensband transmission tower in her next-door neighbor's backyard, which she says bradcasts "vulgarities" and "homosexual jokes" through her television set and radios.

After eight years of operating losses, the Metropolitan Opera Company has made a dramatic turnaround and is meeting its expenses and perhaps moving into a period of more stable financial fortunes, Anthony A. Bliss, the company's ' executive director, said yesterday.

The study of ethnomusicology has given American musicians new scales, tunings and instruments and the ability to play them, but it has not offered much to play on them. Performing nonWestern music by rote cannot remain satisfying to most Westerners, especially since so much non-Western music is deeply rooted in traditional cultural patterning. On the other hand, the integration of non-Western instruments and musical ideas into Western idioms poses daunting challenges.

Two children were killed and a third was critically injured yesterday in a fire that broke out in their Bronx apartment when their mother left them alone briefly to go to a store, One victim was a baby boy delivered in the apartment six months ago by three firemen who tried in vain to save him yesterday.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 18 Gov. Milton J. Shapp is expected to sign a bill this week that would raise $47 million by taxing electric utilities in New Jersey and neighboring states that own shares in Pennsylvania power plants and export electric to serve their customers.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 18 Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi resigned today from the executive committee of the Congress Party, protesting that it was not properly addressing itself to the "formidable tasks" of helping the Indian people.

Jean Pierre Millon, a former Vice president of Coty Inc. who was long active in the city's French-American community, died yesterday of lung cancer in his home at 1192 Park Avenue. He was 81 years old.

After eight years of operating losses, the Metropolitan Opera Company has made a dramatic turnaround and is meeting its expenses and perhaps moving into a period of more stable financial fortunes, Anthony A. Bliss, the company's executive director, said yesterday.

Harvey D. Carter, a retired petroleum consultant who was the director of the supply division of the Petroleum Administration for War, during World War II, died Saturday at his home in Williamstown, Mass. He was 80 years old and a former resident of Scarsdale, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 At a recent dinner party attended by the Ambassadors of both Egypt and Israel following the visit to Israel by President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, Hamilton Jordan, a top White House aide, made an offensive remark, according to some guests.

Every Christmas, David Randolph becomes one of New York's most conspicuously busy musicians. This year he is engaged in a series of five "Messiah" performances with the Masterwork Chorus. And Saturday night at Carnegie Hall he directed another of his groups, the St. Cecilia Chorus, in Bach's "Christmas Oratorio."

KEREN, Ethiopia, Dec. 17 (Reuters) Eritrean rebels seeking independence from Ethiopia have set up their own "mini-state" in which they are able to provide electricity and supply water and schools, hospitals, and bus service.
The complications of the National Football League's playoff system finally resolved themselves yesterday in a simple way: The regular season ended.

The continuing slide in the dollar's value against other major currencies is bringing smaller earnings to shareholders of American multinational corporations and bigger headaches to executives of those companies.

Youngsters, who now outnumber oldsters in the ranks of beer can collectors, want nothing more in the world these days than an empty can of Billy Beer, the new brew endorsed by First Brother Billy Carter.

BEAUNE France When visitors come to this little city, the capital of the Burgundy wine region, to see Daniel Senard, it is usually not to see his vineyards. WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Ninety-eight sewage-treatment projects in New Jersey are scheduled for financing as a result of the belated approval by Congress of the new clean-water bill. The biggest Federal allotment for 1978 would be $23 million for a project in Hudson County, according to the state's Department of Environmental Protection.
DALY CITY, Calif., Dec. 18 Bullfighting was the featured attraction here at the Cow Palace Auditorium yesterday despite attempts by some to block the event on the ground that it was cruel to bulls.

Because every New Yorker believes that he or she personally owns or is responsible for that enduring symbol of the city, feelings are running high. An informal and perfectly useless poll finds opinion divided between people who love the lighting and people who hate it, with a surprising absence of "don't knows."

Two brief new plays by Samuel Beckett, "That Time" and "Footfalls," opened yesterday at the Manhattan Theater Club. They were directed by Alan Schneider, who brought "Waiting for Godot" to the United States two decades ago and has introduced Beckett's dramatic work here ever since.
DAMUR, Lebanon, Dec. 18 Several hundred Palestinians today marched through the ruins of this coastal town, devastated during the Lebanese civil war, chanting "I will go back to Palestine again!"

Charging that New York City's Board of Water Supply is an "expensive, inefficient anachronism," City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday called for its abolishment to save $2.6 million a year.

Jim Valvano did not waste $300 scouting Kentucky Saturday night. The Iona coach has better ways to use the money in his meager basketball budget.

The Rev. Dr. Elder G. Hawkins, the pastor of the St. Augustine Presbyterian Church in the Bronx from 1938 to 1970 and a former moderator of the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church, died yesterday in Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. Since his retirement he lived in Princeton, at 226 Ross Stevenson Circle, and taught practical theology and black history at Princeton Theological Seminary. He was 69 years old.

CAIRO, Dec. 18 In a switch in plans today, Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel is now expected to .confer with Egypt's President, Anwar el-Sadat, at Ismailia, Egypt on Christmas Eve at the earliest and possibly a few days later, according to a well-placed diplomatic source.

From purly technical and stylistic aspects, Carol Wincenc's flute recital at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium Saturday afternoon displayed just about every facet of the instrument's capabilities Miss Wincenc, first flutist with the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra and a frequent recitalist, is a versatile, sensitive, accomplished musician, and she gave each a piece a vividly stimulating life of its own.

Christmas is a time when the special charms of pre-Baroque music seem particularly apt, and many of New York's "old music" ensembles have been regaling audiences the last few weeks with an assortment of seasonal fare. On Saturday night in Alice Tully Hall it was the New Yor Renaissance Band's turn to capture the holiday spirit and it did so with a lively program entitled "An English Renaissance Christmas."

Tampa Bay did it again. The Buccaneers, who won their first game last week after 26 tries in the National Football League, gave their fans a Christmas present yesterday by turning in another surprise, a 17-7 triumph over St. Louis in Tampa, Fla.

BACK IN THE GROOVE Jazz buffs will be happy to know that the downtown Village Gate (924-5026), with its continuously expanding entertainments, again will be harboring cool sounds on Mondays, starting tonight. Concerts by the Billy Harper Sextet will be given at 8 and 10:30. Tickets are $3.50.

A study of recent bond offerings by 55 municipalities around the country has described their accounting and disclosure practices as woefully "deficient," falling "far short" of voluntary guidelines suggested by an association of local government financial offices.

Thirty-two college students from around the country, including 12 women, were named yesterday as this year's winners of Rhodes scholarships for up to three years of study at Oxford University, where they will join Rhodes scholars from 17 other countries.

A fierce battle is in progress between commercial banks and industrial corporations in the hot competition to lend cash to, oddly enough, other industrial companies. Since a decade ago, when short-term lending by one corporation to another was a mere $757 million, this business has soared to $15.5 billion, cutting out the banks along the way.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 One week before Bert Lance resigned as budget director last September and returned home to Georgia, officials of the three Principal Federal bank regulatory agencies appeared before a Senate committee and said that both the nation's banking system and its regulatory mechanisms were essentially sound.

"When I started to work on this book," writes Hugh Fordin in an author's note to "Getting to Know Him," an authorized biography of Oscar Hammerstein 2d, "people wanted to know why I wanted to write the story of a man who didn't have a mean bone in his body, who was loved by everyone, revered by both his friends and fans."
The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the ninth-largest steelmaker in the nation, announced yesterday that it would raise its prices for basic sheet products by 7 percent on Jan. 3.

In this season of heavy entertaining, few guests are in greater demand than a select group of 960 Manhattanites who have suddenly found themselves flooded with invitations to cocktail parties, kaffeeklatsches, intimate at-home gatherings and more formal evenings devoted to serious discussion.
A foundation-supported study urged Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch yesterday to speed the involvement of the 59 community board districts in next year's New York City budget-making process.

The meeting last Wednesday between President Carter and a group of black leaders on domestic issues demonstrated a sharp change from the kinds of meet ings black leaders used to have with Presidents Kennedy and Johnson in the 1960's.
Linda Ann Friedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Friedman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew Barry Keesing, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gustaaf Keesing, also of Scarsdale.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 19 (AP) A 212foot yacht being built in the Netherlands for King Khalid of Saudi Arabia has three decks, a helicopter platform, an operating room, a swimming pool, a sauna, a barber shop and a gymnasium. It will cost $12 million.

Paul Kolton, who is to retire at the end of the year as chairman and chief change, was appointed yesterday as chairman of the Financial Accounting executive of the American Stock ExStandards Advisory Council, a new position. The council works closely with the Financial Accounting Standards Board, chief rule-making body in the industry.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 19--Prime Minister Menahem Begin's proposals regarding the Israeli-held Arab territories are beginning to be denounced by militant West Bank Palestinians as granting too little in the way of concessions and to be criticized by right-wing Israelis as possibly granting too much.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 When Bert Lance's financial manipulations hit the front pages last summer, they posed unpleasant questions for the banking business.

ROME Anwar Sadat didn't arrive. Neither did Jacqueline Onassis. But 13 of the 20 women and men named by the Italian Fashion Institute as the best dressed for 1977 did come to collect their prizes last night in the tapestry-hung reception rooms of the Palazzo Pecci Blunt.

The 150-member Ballet Troupe of the People's Republic of China, based in Peking and considered the country's representative national company, will tour the United States next summer under the auspices of the Metropolitan Opera and the National Committee on United States-China Relations.
Jack Reigot, a diamond expert, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital of cancer. He was 53 years old anl lived at 115 Central Park West.

The recent Supreme Court decision that cash meal allowances paid to New Jersey state troopers are includable in the troopers' gross income and thus subject to taxation probably will result in tougher tax treatment for a variety of fringe benefits, ranging from subsidized company meals to personal use of corporate jets, according to tax experts.

Gertrude Sturgis Cooper, who was superintendent of the Vanderbilt estate in Hyde Park, N.Y., for the National Park Service in 1940-45 and then assistant director and director until 1948 of Greenwich House, the settlement house at 27 Barrow Street in New York, died yesterday in a convalescent hospital in Chester, Conn. She was 88 years old and lived in Killingworth, Conn.

RENO, Dec. 19 (UPI) William Loeb, the newspaper publisher, and his wife, Nackey Scripps Loeb, remained hospitalized today for injuries suffered when their four-wheel-drive vehicle skidded on an icy highway and overturned.

A minor poet and a major anthologizer, whose collections of extracts from other people's poetry were widely used in schools and colleges, Louis Untermeyer was once described by a student as "an entire semester of required reading."

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, continuing as the world's largest money maker, reported yesterday a 13 percent jump in its fourth fiscal quar- ter earnings, to $1.16 billion. That lifted net for the full year to Nov. 30 to $4.5 billion.
CAIRO, Dec. 19 Senior Egyptian officials said privately today that they were disappointed by first reports of the peace proposal discussed by Prime Minister Menahem Begin in Washington.

Humor is undervalued among most serious concert dancers, but not by Susan Creitz, who presented two witty works on a program shared with Anne Marie Ridgway Sunday evening at the Theater of The Open Eye. Miss Ridgway's funny bone had a zany twist, too, and she ended the concert with an improbable collection of dizzy characters in a series of blackout sketches.

Six bewigged men wearing brown suits, neckties and false mustaches had a go at robbing the fashionable Carlyle Hotel before daybreak yesterday, but their own good forethought sacked the plan and even cost them a few of their possessions.

Anthony Provenzano, the leader of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in New Jersey, was indicted in Manhattan yesterday for the third time on the same Federal charge involving an alleged conspiracy to arrange a kickback on a $2.3 million loan from union funds.

Eggbag the cat is asleep in the back of the magic shop, and Eighth Avenue looks almost greasy with the afternoon rain. There isn't much magic on the avenue and the hookers stand out under their golf umbrellas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) House and Senate energy negotiators, increasingly edgy as Christmas crept closer, held repeated private sessions today on natural gas regulation and differed widely on what they accomplished.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) The Pentagon announced today that the McDonnell Douglas Corporation had been chosen over the Boeing Company as the primary contractor for the Air Force's advanced tanker-cargo aircraft mission.

An application to the New York City Planning Commission to renovate two apartment houses in the Bronx with Federal assistance was withdrawn yesterday because of the controversial background of the developer.

TRENTON, Dec. 19--The State Assembly today gave final legislative approval to a $19.5 million construction program for state prisons that would include the building of a new medium-security prison near Hopewell, north of here, and a partial remodeling of the maximum-security prison in downtown Trenton.

The American credit markets in 1978 will face their toughest challenge since the current economic expansion began nearly three years ago, Henry Kaufman, a partner and economist at Salomon Brothers, asserted yesterday as the firm issued its annual projection of supply and demand for borrowed funds for the year ahead.

The New York State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the press should be excluded from pretrial hearings on admissibility of evidence, unless the press could prove that the public had "an overwhelming interest" in keeping the proceedings open.
MONTEREY, Calif. "We've created an adventure," said Bruce Weaver, and if adventure has to do with the untried and uncertain, then he and his small group of astronomers are indeed adventurers.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 19 A. Bartlett Giamatti, a 39-year-old Yale professor of English, has accepted an offer to become the 18th president of Yale University, reliable sources reported tonight.

Seeking to extend City Hall's influence into the schools, the Koch administrationto-be has won a Board of Education pledge of "input" in picking a school chancellor and has approached former First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti to take the job.
Perhaps it is just a case of holidayseason opportunism, but television's determination to be inspirational has become distressingly sticky.
BOSTON, Dec. 19 Plans for redevelopment of the 10-acre midtown area, the subject of seven years of debate, were canceled today when the developer abruptly withdrw from the $150 million project.

Leaders of the national farmers' protest accused Federal officials yesterday of ignoring their strike for higher prices, and warned that the "total silence from Washington" might be met by intensified picketing in the final days before the Christmas holidays, according to United Press International.

BEIRUT, Dec. 19 The Palestine Liberation Organization rejected Prime Minister Menahem Begin's peace plan today and warned that as long as the Palestinians remained without a homeland there would be no peace in the Middle East.

The questionable call by Fred Silva, the referee, in the Baltimore-New England game on Sunday drew the sharpest protests yesterday in the Miami area, where Dolphin fans voiced their anger by telephoning television stations and newspapers.
A major processor of smoked whitefish in Brooklyn has won a court battle against enforcement of a Federal regulation that required extremely high temperatures for processing the fish.

Prime Minister Menahem Begin said here yesterday that he would meet Sunday in Egypt with President Anwar elSadat and was confident that the Egyptian leader would not reject Israel's peace plan out of hand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) The Federal Election Commission has accused the A.F.L.-C.I.O. of violating Federal campaign spending laws and recommended that a judge fine the labor organization $10,000.

The National Society of Film Critics yesterday selected "Annie Hall," the comedy starring, directed and co-written by Woody Allen, as the best film of 1977. The group, whose membership comprises 29 critics from New York and other cities, named Luis Bunuel's "That Obscure Object of Desire" and Steven Spielberg's "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" as second and third choices.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 19 (AP) Randy Garcia left the bench and threw two fourth-quarter touchdown passes, rallying the University of Nebraska football team to a 21-17 victory over North Carolina in the Liberty Bowl tonight.
Outdoor advertising is having its best year ever and because its 1978 rates will not be up as much as other media it expects to do even better next year.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel producer, announced price increases yesterday of about 5.5 percent for most of its steel products an advance that a spokesman for a key Government agency said was not out of line with inflation.
At Marshall Field Company, Chicago's largest department store, a customer called the State Street store's "personal shopper" and ordered all his Christmas gift needs on the telephone $1,500 worth.
LARK, Utah, Dec. 17 The 591 people who live in this tiny town have got word that it is being closed down by the Kennecott Copper Corporation.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 19 College students are not drinking any more these days and are not getting into any more trouble than they were five or 25 years ago, according to a report published today by the Rutgers Center of Alcohol Studies. The conclusions are based on a nationwide survey of 13 colleges and universities by Dr. Ruth C. Engs of Indiana University.

Representative Lionel Van Deerlin, Democrat of California, who heads the House Communications Subcommittee and who for two years has sought to rewrite the Communications Act of 1934, yesterday conceded that there was too much opposition to the proposal for the revision to occur in 1978.

A series of midair explosions some 50 miles out over the Atlantic Ocean during the last two weeks has baffled research scientists and military authorities. Columbia University's Lamont Laboratory at Palisades, N.Y., just north of New York City, has detected seven explosions since Dec. 2, each equal in force to the detonation of 100 tons of dynamite.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) One million fewer people were enrolled in the Federal Government's food stamp program in October than in the same month in 1976, the Agriculture Department reported today.

Facing a groundswell of adverse public opinion and opposition from Mayor Beame and Mayor-elect Edward I. Kock, the City Council leadership surrendered yesterday and agreed to withdraw the bill that would have increased the salaries of Council members and other elected city officials.

Rejected twice by voters in one year, Bella S.Abzug formally began an attempt at a political comeback yesterday by announcing her candidacy for Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch's seat in the House of Representatives from the East Side's 18th Congressional District.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 Today was the "Day Before" meaning the day before the General Assembly was scheduled to adjourn and the habitually leisurely tempo of the United Nations accelerated markedly. Delegates railroaded one resolution after another in committees and in the Assembly so they could go home for the holidays.

DETROIT, Dec. 19 A Federal judge, in an order accusing Government prosecutors of "persistent misconduct," today ordered a new trial for two Filipino nurses convicted last July of poisoning patients at the Ann Arbor Veterans Administration Hospital.

The sudden departure last week of David A. (Sonny) Werblin from the Meadowlands sports complex for the presidency of Madison Square Garden Corporation has left an element of confusion west of the Hudson.
Stock prices moved steadily lower in late trading yesterday as General Motors one of the market's bellwether issues finished at a 1977 low.

The New York Rangers announced yesterday that they had signed Dallas Smith, a 36-year-old free-agent defenseman, for the remainder of this season. Smith was formerly with the Boston Bruins.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 19 Plans to hold an international arms bazaar in this convention city next year have misfired.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 State Department officials said today that they have been informed by Vietnamese authorities that three young Americans seized aboard their boat off the Vietnamese coast in October would be released in time for Christmas.

Yet this creature, half woman and half bird, shows up in as many versions as do the more familiar beasts, in an exhibition of jewelry by about 40 artists at the Aaron Faber Gallery through Jan. 7.

NED HAVEN, Dec. 20 A. Bartlett Giamatti, a 39-year-old Renaissance literature scholar and one of Yale's most popular teachers, was formally named today to become the 18th president of Yale University.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 20 The second half of a two-man team of satirical artists from Moscow arrived today and announced that he and his partner would build a temple in Jerusalem and sacrifice his Soviet-made suitcase as a burnt offering to the "evil angel" he said hovered over Jews born in Russia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel was reportedly told by President Carter and other high officials last weekend that his plan for dealing with the Palestinians on the West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip did not seem to offer enough to President Anwar el-Sadat. The Israeli leader was urged to repackage his proposals before he met with the Egyptian leader this coming Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 A Senate Intelligence subcommittee has concluded that some newspapers and magazines performed as well as or better than United States intelligence analysts did in predicting and evaluating Saudi Arabia's role in the oil embargo imposed in October 1973 by Arab nations.

SECAUCUS, Dec. 20 The concept of high-rise residential development in the Hackensack Meadowlands one of the basic precepts of development of the huge tract was jeopardized today by the rejection of plans for the first high-rise complex in the district.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) Federal bank regulators postponed indefinitely today the effective date for proposed rules dealing with the financial condition of banks with foreign offices.

Santa Claus, the Telephone Company, F.A.O. Leon I. Mirell, a film and television production executive, died Dec. 8 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 54 years old.

Tom Bagley, a 38-year-old former physicist who has been driving 160horsepower Formula Super Vee cars for six years, next year will become the first graduate of the Mini-Indy series to enter Indianapolis-type auto racing.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 20 The Westchester Board of Legislators voted tonight to reduce County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's proposed $410,218,822 budget for next year by $3,046,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) The Secret Service investigation into the assassination of President Kennedy was heavily preoccupied with possible Cuban and even Chinese Communist involvement, according to documents released today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Barbara Walters gave a dinner party in Washington recently to bring together the Ambassadors of Egypt and Israel, who had never officially acknowledged each other in the past. The evening turned out to be memorable, even though reports about it have a Rashomon-like quality.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Dec. 21 Long Island clammers, whose 60 percent share of the American hardshell clam market has been threatened by a loss of 17 percent of the region's shellfishing waters to pollution in recent years, returned to port this afternoon to the good news that nearly 6,000 acres of highly productive underwater lands had been reopened to them by the state.

In their distinctive and increasingly ers lost an early 3-0 lead over the predictable way, the New York RangWashington Capitals last night and struggled to earn a 5-5 tie with two goals in the final period.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 21 The General Assembly ended its 32d session today after having adopted a $986 million budget for the coming two years and a record number of 256 resolutions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 President Carter, reacting for the first time to the mounting pressure on the dollar in the international exchange markets, today suggested the United States might take stronger action to preserve the dollar's value and outlined moves to improve the foreign accounts of the United States.

The Municipal Assistance Corporation's $250 million bond issue being sold this week was increased slightly in yield yesterday to perk up sales of the securities as prices for most New York State agency bonds declined sharply.
CARABALLEDA, Venezuela, Dec. 21--The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, concluding a meeting here today, said that crude oil prices would not rise for the time being.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Dec. 21 (UPI) The ski dispute between Austria and Italy turned ugly today when Austria said it would conduct a "control" or recheck of Italy's World Cup downhill victory at Val Gardena. Ugo Albl, Austrian trainer, said the recheck was necessary because of charges that the Italians had fiddled with the electronic timer during Sunday's race to give the victory to Herbert Plank.

After pleading in vain yesterday with the Rev. Louis R. Gigante to answer questions before a grand jury investigating the city's Department of Correction, Justice Leonard H. Sandler reluctantly held the Roman Catholic priest in contempt and sentenced him to 10 days in jail.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 21--Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Fahd, in an interview published here today, said there would be no Middle East peace if Isreal did not yield the Arab lands it occupies and if the Palestinians did not regain what he called their rights.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 President Carter gave his approval today for direct air service to Europe from 11 new American cities.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 In the headquarters of the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency are terminals linked to a million-dollar computer system in Florida the National Bank Surveillance System.

A PUBLIC-TELEVISION special, "Christmas Around the World," will employ the largest and most complex international satellite hookup ever used to pick up and transmit signals from 7 countries for a live broadcast in 30 countries on Christmas Eve.

Beginning in January, investors will have to hold securities for a full year to qualify for long-term capital-gains treatment. Wall Street, meanwhile, is looking for ways to protect short-term gains from erosion until they mature.

ATLANTA, Dec. 21 The dam that ruptured near Toccoa, Ga., on Nov. 6, resulting in 39 deaths, had not been properly inspected and maintained by its owners, a Federal investigative board said here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)--A House intelligence subcommittee plans to begin hearings next week on the Central Intelligence Agency's involvement with the news media, the panel's chairman said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The Carter Administration plans to appoint Frank C. Carlucci, the United States Ambassador to Portugal, as Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, top-ranking White House and State Department officials said today.

A city Council meeting that had been set for today to override a mayoral veto of a pay-increase bill will be held as scheduled, but the Council members will override themselves instead. The bill in question is the controversial pay-rise measure for the Councilmen and other elected officials, whch the Council is withdrawing from Mayor Beame's consideration.

BERN, Dec. 21 (AP) A 26-year-old West German woman arrested in a shootout with Swiss customs guards was one of the terrorists who raided the OPEC meeting in Vienna two years ago, the Swiss Justice Ministry announced today. She also carried money paid in ransom for a Viennese businessman, the ministry said.

PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec, 21 Calvin Murphy has some good news and some bad news for the National Basketball Association. The good news is that, after the crippling blow to the head that his roomate, Rudy Tomjanovich, took from Kermit Washington of the Los Angeles Lakers, Murphy has decided to hang up his boxing gloves. The bad news is that from now on he may come out shooting basketballs, that is.

In East New York, where the buildings are withering fast as a life-sick forest, some of the people sit and talk of Plato and Irving Anker and of the only honorable struggle, the one being celebrated over the day-care center.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The $78 million John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has serious financial problems that only Congress can alleviate, according to a study by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress. The findings were made public yesterday.

MARIETTA, Ga., Dec. 21 The last section of Interstate 75 was opened to traffic near here today, making the 1,575-mile superhighway the first in the system to be completed from one end of the country to the other.

"ANNIE HALL" was chosen the best film of 1977 by the New York Film Critics' Circle yesterday. The Woody Allen comedy was selected over Luis Bunuel's "That Obscure Object of Desire," in second place, and Steven Spielberg's "Close Encounters of the Third Kind," in third. The critics' group has 26 members, 25 of whom took part in the voting.

The sun had gone down and the sea had flattened out when Anh Hoang Dinh, his wife, and their four children, his brother, two nephews and 11 close friends crawled into a 33foot boat built for fishing, nosed the bow into the Gulf of Siam and watched the coast of Vietnam, and their lives to that time, fade beyond the stern.

Trans World Airlines, in a major move to diversify away from airline operations, disclosed yesterday that it would offer to pay $120 million in cash for a 64 percent stake in American Medicorp Inc., a leading operator of hospitals.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 21 (AP) President Augusto Pinochet reacted today to a United Nations resolution last week denouncing alleged human rights violations in Chile by saying he would seek a public vote of confidence for his military Government.

Back in 1965, when he was a graduate student at the Harvard Business School, Ghaith R. Pharaon wrote a paper on a mythical company ne named Redec. It was to engage in the construction business in Jiddah, on the

MONTREAL, Dec. 21 Premier Rene Levesque of Quebec predicts a narrow victory for independence when the province votes on the issue in 1979 or 1980, but if he should fail to get it, he is pre pared to hold a second referendum during a new term of office.

In a major blow to the billboard industry and a major victory for environmental groups, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that "as a general rule" regulations requiring the removal of roadside billboards were constitutional as long as the billboard owner was given enough time "to avoid substantial financial loss" before the sign was removed.

SO LONG was the reign of Elizabeth I and so full of incident, and so mettlesome was she in person that it is easy to think of her as the centerpiece of all sorts of dramatic offerings--as the many plays and operas about her attest. Cavada Humphrey, known to theater-goers for her role as Mrs. Patrick Campbell in "Dear Liar," the play made out of the Campbell-Bernard Shaw correspondence, evidently thinks so, too.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 A five-member panel has been appointed to study ways to resolve the conflict experienced by foreign correspondents of the Voice of America in their roles as journalists and government employees.

OTTAWA, Dec. 21 A love affair of more than 20 years between Canada and Harry Belfonte reached a moment of high emotion last night as Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, following a benefit concert by the singer and his company before a sold-out house, appeared on stage to honor the American performer with an unusual official tribute by the Canadian Government.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 (AP) Winds that had brought death and destruction to California slowed to 50 miles an hour today, and a misty rain helped fight a wind-whipped fire that killed three men at an Air Force base.
The precious metals market turned cautious yesterday as traders awaited President. Carter's comments on the sinking value of the dollar against foreign currencies, which came after the close.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Yesterday's proposal to transfer from the Department of Agriculture to the Food and Drug Administration the enforcement of virtually all Federal food laws would, even if adopted, still leave gaping holes in the ...

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, facing criticism from the New York State Comptroller's office for alleged irregularities in the letting of millions of dollars of construction and maintenance contracts for the World Trade Center, yesterday named a three-member panel to review procurement policies.

ROME After 18 years abroad, Paolo Carosone, a moderately successful sculptor and graphic artist, returned to his native Rome three years ago hoping to mount a few one-man exhibitions, publish a book on his best works and maintain a steady income.
Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch and several of his top aides plan to spend part of Christmas day at the Rikers Island House of Detention for Men, according to the Department of Correction.

A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn is investigating charges that officials of the Farmers Home Administration on Long Island have deliberately overappraised property on which subsidized Federal mortgages are written, thus allowing housing speculators to reap windfall profits.

NEW YORK City has a new market. Not one that sells pomegranates and papayas, luke fish, octopus and gweduc, like the famous market in Seattle, a center of city life and holy place of all true urbanists. Yet a market nevertheless officially so named, in the new Citicorp Building between Lexington and Third Avenues at 53d Street.

THERE WAS A TIME when Handel's "Messiah" was performed with such lugubrious tempos that it had to be cut to keep it within a decent performance-length's time. Nowadays, it is de rigueur to give the oratorio complete; the tempos have become so brisk that the whole occupies considerably less than three hours. Part of the change followed the rethinking of Baroque performance style, and as such was admirable.

Barbara Kraus, an international dietary specialist whose works included "The Cookbook of the United Nations," died yesterday at her home at 325 East 41st Street. She was 48 years old and had been ill for some time.

An off-duty police officer was shot in the back of the head and killed and another man was shot in the head and critically wounded last night in the hallway of an apartment building at 15 St. Nicholas Avenue in Harlem, the police reported.

A lawyer and three reputed members of a new organized-crime group called the Purple Gang were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal tax-evasion charges involving an investment in a vending-machine operation to sell New York State lottery tickets.

THREE TO MAKE READY With Christmas nearing and shopping and theatergoing stepped up in Midtown, some New Yorkers laden with packages or Playbills, or both, might wonder about convenient waystations for rest, a cocktail and perhaps a bit of background entertainment. To choose at random, there are three such spots in the Times Square area, each with a few surprises. They Also happen to be nice, well-run places with reasonable prices.

HOW-TO books continue to flourish covering every subject from how to cook for your cat to how to deliver your own baby. In the last few years, volumes on how to be prettier, slimmer or healthier have been appearing almost as frequently as cookbooks.

A lawyer and three reputed members of a new organized-crime group called the Purple Gang were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal tax-evasion charges involving an investment in a vending-machine operation to sell New York State lottery tickets.

John Francis Xavier Fay, who in the 1930's wrote industrial-relation stories for The New York Times and the old Newark (N.J.) Star-Eagle, died Tuesday in West Hudson Hospital, Kearny, N.J., after a six month illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 50 Hamilton Avenue, Kearny.

WASHINGTON Under the pressure of an Administration trucking reform policy soon to emerge, the Interstate Commerce Commission has begun to move on 39 regulatory improvements of its own, most of them to help the commission act faster.
PARIS, Dec. 21 At their receptions, diplomats around the world are exchanging bitter complaints these days about the may the new diplomacy has turned the tables on them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company with maintaining more than $1 million in secret funds that were used to make payoffs overseas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 A burst of inflation in some food prices and markups for Toyota cars imported from Japan helped propel the Consumer Price Index to an increase in November of one-half of 1 percent, more than in any of the preceding four months, the Government reported today.

James T. Ong of Inglewood, Calif.; Jean Taatjis of Libby, Mont.; Irvin Miller of Omaha; Everta Gibson of Parkersburg, W.Va., and Sally Hanes of Saginaw, Mich., make their network television debuts next week. So does the RCA Music Service, a record club. They are in fact all doing it together in a 30-second commercial. And of all of the involved parties, RCA has been preparing the longest.
LONDON, Dec. 21 (Reuters) Sir Reginald Rootes, one of the pioneers of motoring in Britain, died yesterday at 81.

Only three more days till Christmas. Will your nose make it? Seventy percent of all yearly fragrance sales are made during the Christmas season and this year, many more of those sweet smells are headed behind the living room sofa instead of behind the ears.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission today proposed a set of guidelines for affirmative action programs in employment that would protect companies from complaints of so-called reverse discrimination made by white males.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 21 (UPI) ' Wayne Radford, one of only two seniors on the team, pumped in a season-high 24 points tonight and Mike Woodson added 17 to lead 16th-ranked Indiana to a 66-57 victory over Alabama in the final of the Indiana Classic basketball tourney.

THE FACT that radio programers and record retailers settled on New Wave as a generic name for punk rock is more than a little ironic, for there is little new about it, musically speaking. Of the New Wave groups from England, where the phenomenon seems most convincing and least contrived, most seem intent on resurrecting the spirit of the early Rolling Stones or Who, with some going back to early 1960's rhythm and blues rockabilly.

Nigel S. MacEwan, who has been executive vice president and chief operating officer of White, Weld Company, has been named president of the international investment banking and brokerage firm, effective Jan. 1. The announcement was made yesterday by Paul Hallingby Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, who has been serving as president.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21 An exhibition of American painting from Winslow Homer to Andy Warhol was opened today to the public, and a small but intensely serious crowd of Russians pored over the 85 works, whispering comments to one another and furiously taking notes.

Anne Butler Henning of New York and Greenwich, Conn., and James Burns Cavanagh of Centerville, Del., were married yesterday in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. The Rev. John L. O'Hear of Christ Church, Christiana Hundred, Greenville, Del., performed the ceremony.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 Edward Koch becomes Mayor of New York on New Year's Day. Soon after that he will have to take a position on one of the biggest urban planning issues in the country: the proposal to build Westway, a $1.16 billion expressway along the West Side of Manhattan.

President Carter has adopted proposals by Transportation Secretary Brock Adams that would increase the flexibility of cities in planning transportation by giving mass transit projects the same Federal financial support as highways, the White House disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Frank Dawson is looking for a job, so he wrote out a resume of his career experience. "I showed it to my children over the Thanksgiving holidays," he said with a laugh. "It was a revelation to all of them."
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (UPI) Bishop Timotheos, head of a Greek Orthodox archdiocese that includes six Middle Western states, died today at Northwestern Memorial Hospital here. He was 60 years old.

"We've been having the kind of weather that makes a guy in my business think of giving it all up and heading for Florida," said Bill Norton, the experienced manager of New Hampshire's state owned Cannon Mountain ski area yesterday.
NEWARK, Dec. 21 This city, which sought unsuccessfully to gain landing rights to supersonic planes, saw its wish come partly true today: the Concorde made an unexpected landing at Newark Airport.

SHIRLEY Camper Soman, a writer, called several weeks ago with a complaint common among New Yorkers: "My answering service is driving me up the wall!" she said. "Can you recommend a good machine to replace it?"

TRENTON, Dec. 21 At the insistence of seven New Jersey bankers and insurance-company executives, Governor Byrne today agreed not to push for the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to rebuild and operate the Garden State Park race track at Cherry Hill unless a feasibility study showed this to be a "wise thing" to do.

A research technique for which the Nobel Prize in medicine was awarded this year has been used experimentally to improve the ability of a standard blood test to detect prostate cancer, a common malignant tumor in men.

A century, as reckoned by the dinosaurs end fossils at the American Museum of Natural History, is only a ticktock of time. But for the museum itself, today has significance: It is just 100 years and 132 million visitor-admissions since the first building on the present site was opened by President Rutherford B. Hays. The museum's founders first organized in 1869.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) The nation's air is getting cleaner but smog continues to be a serious problem in some areas, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

DOWNERS GROVE, Ill. After much debate in Washington among House and Senate conferees, Congress is putting the finishing touches on the new energy bill. The compromise legislation will have far-reaching effects on the American way of life, according to reliable Congressional sources who are visiting here during the holiday recess.

0WILTON, Conn., Dec. 21 Linda Blair, the 18-year-old actress who was arrested here yesterday on drug charges as she left her rented home, is scheduled to appear in court in Stamford, Conn., on Jan. 18, when lawyers for Florida and Connecticut are expected to argue about which state should proceed first with prosecution of the young actress.

LONDON, Dec. 21 Commerce triumphed handily over holiday spirit this evening as the producers of Johnnie Walker Red Label, the world's biggest-selling Scotch, removed it from the grasp of Britain's own drinkers.
Unless the city's subway and bus systems stem their increasing operating losses, the present 50-cent fare will rise gradually to 90 cents by 1982, the City Planning Commission warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The Carter Administration has decided to seek the emergency admission of 7,000 Vietnamese refugees instead of the 10,000 originally desired by the State Department. Administration officials said today.
CAIRO, Dec. 21 President Anwar elSadat said today that he would not accept an Israeli military presence on the West Bank of the Jordan as part of a peace settlement.

EVER SINCE the energy crisis, with its shortages and escalating fuel prices, interest has intensified in the traditional wood burning fireplace as a means of supplementing the central heating system (and possibly replacing it entirely in an emergency).

THE POETRY of perception is not the same as the poetry of drama. In "For Colored Girls," Ntozake Shange arranged her acid and lyrical perceptions into a fine, loose-jointed set of meditations and sketches.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Despite some quiet Administration support, a compromise on natural gas proposed by a group of House-Senate conferees was opposed on all sides yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 The Bonwit Teller fur salon in Chicago, one of the nation's largest independent furriers, sponsored what it said was the industry's "first gay fashion show" last night at a homosexual nightclub a few blocks north of the city's Loop.

Henry C. Miner ,Jr., who retired 10 years ago as board chairman of Century Circuit Inc., of New Hyde Park, N.Y., the motion-picture chain, died Tuesday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital after a lengthy illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 27 Willomere Circle, Riverside, Conn.

Q. Some time ago I had a washable wallpaper hung in my dinette and the paperhanger said it needed no lining. I find that the paper bubbles wherever I have attempted to wash off food stains. What is the cause of these bubbles and how can I remove the soil without washing? Mrs. R.P., New York City.

Lindsay Crouse, the actress, and David Mamet, the playwright, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Russel Crouse, widow of the playwright. State Supreme Court Justice James J. Leff performed the ceremony.

The State Racing and Wagering Board indicated yesterday that it would probably grant a temporary 1978 license to Jack Morgan, the listed ownertrainer of the mystery horse in Belmont Park's ringer case.

A declarer who sees Q-J-X in the dummy and A-10-X in his hand may think this entirely equivalent to Q-10-X opposite it is but he should bear in mind that his oppinents do not see matters in quite the same light.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21 (AP)--The earthquake casualty toll mounted today to at least 519 dead and 671 injured in 16 villages of Iran's coal basin in the south-central part of the country, the nation's relief agency said. Many of the dead were said to be children trapped by collapsing mud-brick walls.
In retrospect, the most unusual elements of the Giants' 12-9 overtime loss to the Chicago Bears last Sunday were not the snow and sleet, but the significance and the tension.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 In the headquarters of the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency are terminals linked to a million-dollar computer system in Flori- da the National Bank Surveillance Sys- tem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--Negotiators for the coal industry and the United Mine Workers today recessed their talks on a new coal labor contract until Tuesday. A contract could end the strike of 160,000 miners, now in its 16th day.
OTTAWA, Dec. 21 (UPI) Polar Gas Ltd., as expected, applied today for per mission to build a pipeline to carry natural gas from islands high in the eastern Arctic to markets in southern Canada.
A friend recovering from a serious illness in a hospital has prompted Ann Hartenstein of Syracuse to contribute to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Johnny Carson, who already is probably the highest-salaried performer in show business, has negotiated a new contract with NBC that gives him a new increase, reportedly bringing his salary close to $3 million a year.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec, 21 (AP) Six casino hotels in 1982 would draw 2.45 million more visitors here and place higher demands on area housing and South Jersey highways, according to projections in two studies made public here today.

Any angler without connections who wishes to fish for Atlantic salmon in Canada must rely on public waters or outfitters. Connections mean membership in a club that leases a stretch of a salmon river or friendship with an individual or club that does the same.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 Striking farmers, angry over an editorial criticizing what were described as the "union-goon tactics" of some of them, blockaded a Texas newspaper today, delaying delivery of its morning edition for four hours. Tractordriving farmers managed to delay the delivery trucks with 80,000 copies of The Lubbock Avalanche-Journal.
TRENTON, Dec. 21--New Jersey hopes to market a new product and solve much of the state's sewage-disposal problem with the start-up in February of a pilot project for composting sludge in Camden.
Glenn Mosley will be able to attend his brother John's birthday party the day before Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) Deputy Agriculture Secretary John White has emerged as the leading candidate to succeed Kenneth Curtis as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, informed sources said today.
CARABALLEDA, Venezuela, Dec. 21 The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, concluding a meeting here today, said that crude oil prices would not rise for the time being.
MANILA, Thursday, Dec. 22 (AP) Hostages overwhelmed a Filipino gunman today with the aid of law-enforcement personnel, ending a two-day siege at a bank on the United States Navy Base at Subic Bay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The Carter Administration has decided to seek the emergency admission of 7,000 Vietnamese refugees instead of the 10,000 originally desired by the State Department, Administration officials said today.

General Mills Inc., a diversified company whose products range from food and restaurants to chemicals, reported yesterday profit increases of 23.7 percent for the second fiscal quarter and 22.9 percent for the six months to Nov. 27.

A judiciary screening committee has reversed itself and rejected a Criminal Court judgeship for Sidney Baumgarten, an aide to Mayor Beame who heads a controversial campaign against vice in the midtown area.
Two more steel companies announced plans yesterday to raise prices, by 5.5 percent and 6 percent, close to the increases announced earlier this week by two major steel producers.
CAIRO, Dec. 21 President Anwar elSadat said today that he would not accept an Israeli military presence on the West Bank of the Jordan as part of a peace settlement.

The Civil Aeronautics Board softened restrictions on domestic and international charter flights yesterday, making it easier for charter operators to compete with a spate of bargain fares instituted on scheduled services.

Officials of the State Bank of Raritan Valley in Raritan said yesterday that alleged violations of banking regulations cited in a cease-and-desist order from Virginia Long, the New Jersey Banking Commissionar, earlier this month had been corrected.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, facing criticism from the New York State Comptroller's office for alleged irregularities in the letting of millions of dollars of construction and maintenance contracts for the World Trade Center, yesterday named a three-member panel to review procurement policies.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 1,999,183 shares in the month ended Dec. 15 to a record high of 35,321,594 shares. The interest for the year-earlier level totaled 27,510,879 shares.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--A burst of inflation in some food prices and markups for Toyota cars imported from Japan helped propel the Consumer Price Index to an increase in November of one-half of 1 percent, more than in any of the preceding four months, the Government reported today.

The painstaking and occasionally painful process of finding Yale University's 18th president has turned a public spotlight on the state of not only one leading campus but also American higher education. That the search ended with the selection of A. Bartlett Giamatti, a 39-year-old Renaissance scholar who combines youth with academic accomplishment and popularity among students, should do much to allay the fears of those who see the universities abandoned to fiscal experts.
NEWARK, Dec. 21 This city, which sought unsuccessfully to gain landing rights to supersonic planes, saw its wish come partly true today: the Concorde made an unexpected landing at Newark Airport.

Wilfredo Benitez of Puerto Rico, recognized as the world junior welterweight champion by the New York State Athletic Commission, has been rematched with Bruce Curry of Los Angeles. Curry floored the champion three times in their November fight, yet lost a split decision in one of the most controversial verdicts here.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 21 (UPI) John Newcombe, stepping up his comeback pace, defeated Brian Teacher in straight sets in the first round of the $250,000 Australian open tennis championships today. The Australian is the first of the four world events making up the Grand Slam.

For years, phone companies insisted that answering machines, which are considered "foreign attachments," be connected to the network through a "protective interface device." Many who bought the machines for home use simply plugged them in without confiding in the phone company. Usually nothing happened, but there was alway the risk that the phone company would uncover the "illegal" connection and force disconnection or acceptance of a coupler (at $1 a month).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The Carter Administration plans to appoint Frank C. Carlucci, the United States Ambassador to Portugal, as Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, top-ranking White House and State Department officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) The United States reduced its international payments deficit for the third quarter of l977 from the second quartet's record $4.6 billion, but only to $4.3 billion, the Commerce Department said yesterday.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz filed suit against New York City yesterday, seeking to end "overcrowding and unsanitary conditions" at the Rikers Island House of Detention for Men.

Nevertheless, out into the freezing rain they went, the six dogs and the 32 persons, most of them members of the Golden West Side Ecumenical Christmas Caroling and Dog Walking Society.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 President Carter gave his approval today for direct air service to Europe from 11 new American cities.
Christy Wilbert, a former motion picture advertising and marketing executive, died Monday of a coronary occlusion at his home in Bayside, Queens. He was 66 years old.

Business leaders and economists said that the $25 billion tax cut program decided on by President Carter should bolster capital spending by business in late 1978 and 1979 and expressed cau- tious approval of the program as a whole. The general impression of many economists and business spokesmen was that the Administration wanted to put through a tax cut as fast as possible with a minimum of delay in Congress.

WASHINGTON The Carter Administration has gone to great pains to describe the proposed $40 billion crude oil equalization tax as the "centerpiece" of its energy program. If it is to be so characterized, what is emerging from Congress will be a "centerpiece" to grace the banquet tables of the major oil and gas companies but at the price of the food to be served at the dinner tables of American consumers.

A controversial plan to build 72 attached houses on the former Delafield estate in Riverdale now the property of Columbia University was sharply debated yesterday at an all-day hearing of the New York City Planning Commission.

THE FIRST CHRISTMAS was the best, beyond a doubt. Since then, it's been downhill all the way for close on 2,000 years. It's natural, after all. Having something happen right there in front of one's eyes is better than thinking about it (no matter how reverently) a long time afterwards. And although the earliest accounts are not exactly straight from the scene, they have about them a pristine clarity.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 21 (UPI) The Oakland Raiders, thinking about the weather on the East Coast, have purchased 60 pairs of women's coffee-colored super-queen-size pantyhose, meant to fit a person with 48 to 60-inch hips who weighs between 200 and 260 pounds.

LOUISVILLE Ky., Dec 22 (AP) Led by Darrell Griffith's 23 points, Louisville sent Marquette to its first defeat of the season tonight with a 61-60 victory over the defending National Collegiate basketball champions.
Supplies of distillate oil fell slightly to 253.1 million barrels for the week ended Dec. 16, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 Beginning a long-range campaign to control dangerous toxic substances in the marketplace, the Environmental Protection Agency ordered all chemical makers today to report every product they made in 1977 to the Government by next May 1.
Dr. Francis S. Juhasz, chariman of the American language program at Columbia University, died Thursday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 52 years old and lived in Pleasantville, N.Y.

Gimbel Brothers Inc., which has made substantial progress as a result of eliminating unprofitable items, yesterday reported that its fourth-quarter loss had shrunk this year and that sales exceeded $1 billion for the first time in its 135-year history for the year ended Oct. 1.

MOSCOW, Dec. 22 The Soviet press agency Tass today rejected American statements of concern about Anatoly Shcharansky, who is being held pending an inquiry into alleged spying for the Central Intelligence Agency.

The resignation of Michael E. Tobin as president of the Midwest Stock Exchange to become president of the American National Bank and Trust. Company of Chicago was announced yesterday by the exchange's executive committee.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Dec. 22 (UPI) Ann Whitaker says that the prospect of being the first American woman in space is "mind-boggling" but that she will temper her excitement with realism until the selection process finished.

Peter Mark Andrew Phillips, the 37day-old first grandchild of Queen Elizabeth II, was baptized by the Archbishop of Canterbury yesterday, and he cried throughout the simple 20-minute ceremony. Master Peter, as he will be called, since his mother, Princess Anne, declined a title for him was christened in the gold, white and blue Music Room of Buckingham Palace.

WASHINGTON The nation's top businessmen received from President Carter an unexpected but highly welcomed expression of sympathy and pledge of help here recently for one of their most nagging problems excessive Government regulation.

The New York City Council overrode itself yesterday and killed its controversial pay-rise bill, but not without letting Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch who apposed the bill know that it would not be his rubber stamp.

MUSICA SACRA'S performance and interpretatation of Handel's "Messiah," as developed over the years by Richard Westenburg, probably comes about as close as possible to an ideal representation of the work in terms of current musicological information and present-day demands of musical performance in general.

FOR THE JEWS of the Eastern European diaspora, history was something to remember and wait for. The present was a few households, small rafts on a sea of irrational dangers nd hardships. Mingled with the orderly intimate life of the community there was an uncontrollable reality that had all the attributes of the supernatural; pogroms and the Czar's proclamations came like the decrees of a God who was asleep or away on other business.

SONGKHLA, Thailand, Dec. 19 For two women who arrived in a refugee camp here earlier this month from Vietnam, the flight by fishing boat was their second escape in little more than a year. For them, Vietnam represented a halfway house to freedom. They are Cambodian, and to them, after living for 16 months under the Cambodian Communist regime, Vietnam was a relief.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 22 (Reuters) Rhodesian settlement talks centered today on the key issue of safeguards for the white minority in a blackruled Rhodesia, and evidently little if any progress was made.

NEWARK, Dec. 22 A hearing officer found Dr. Peter T. De Marco guilty today of causing a hepatitis outbreak through "gross malpractice" and recommended that his license to practice medicine in New Jersey be revoked permanently.

In view of his professional history, he appeared surprisingly youthful, and in fact rather boyish, which made his belated debut seem not at all incongruous.

The New York City Board of Estimate ended the year yesterday by approving a new lease for the Bridgemarket to be built under the Queensborough Bridge and by voting a huge rent reduction for the operator of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. A number of lucrative Federal job-training contracts were also approved, including one for nearly $2 million for a group with no prior experience in the field.

For some five years now, Friday midnight has been a high point in Calvin Hampton's week. Mr. Hampton is the organist and director of music at Calvary Episcopal Church, Park Avenue South at 21st Street, and there at an hour when not everybody is stirring he plays weekly organ recitals from October through May every season. And people go to hear them.
