WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The Federal Government has failed to protect the public against the hazards of radiation, a Senate committee said today.

HOUSTON, Dec. 22 Thousands of illegal aliens are streaming across the Mexican border this week, south, not north. Instead of sneaking into the United States, they are sneaking out. Instead of leaving Mexico, they are going back home.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 22 (AP) The Steelers announced today that they would play a benefit basketball game for the basketball program at the University of Evansville.
The Nation, the oldest weekly magazine in the country, was sold yesterday to a group of investors organized by Hamilton Fish, a 26-year-old Harvard graduate who will be the magazine's new publisher.

Outbreaks of influenza cases, some widespread enough to close schools early for the holidays, have been reported in 11 of New Jersey's 21 counties, and schools in two districts in Suffolk County were shut yesterday because of what authorities called "flu-like conditions."

Business loans at major New York City banks jumped $784 million in the week ended Wednesday, their largest increase in three and a half years, and commercial paper volume an alternative source of borrowed funds climbed nationally by more than $1 billion to a record total.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 An era in American labor history came to an end today with the departure from office of two United Mine Workers union leaders whose "Miners For Democracy" uprising, by the power of the ballot, had thrust a corrupt regime literally into the street.

Following is a list of things I don't want for Christmas. This year I haven't gone to any trouble seeking out the latest in ungifts; these are depressingly familiar things that I am ready to have done with, and, in the belief that less is more, I petition for their banishment from my life.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 22 (UP) A Federal District Judge ruled today that John Meier a former side to Howard R. Hughes, had helped swindle the Hughes Tool Company out of $8.4 million on the purchase of Nevada mining claims.
ZARAND, Iran, Dec. 22 (UPI) The death toll neared 600 today from an earthquake that struck a string of villages in south central Iran, where floods isolated stricken areas and hampered rescue work.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 22 (AP) Top-seeded Vitas Gerulaitis of the United States breezed into the second round of the $250,000 Australian open tennis championships today, but the defending champion, Roscoe Tanner, was ousted. The American southpaw fumed at suggestions that he hadn't tried to win.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) States should not be given the choice on whether to comply with Federal vehicle safety inspection standards, the General Accounting Office said in a report released today.

Keely Smith, who used to be a monument of deadpan, disinterested patience and musical riot that Louis Prima raised onstage with Sam Butera and the Witnesses, is back in town for the first time in 14 years. But this time, at the Rainbow Grill where she will be appearing for the next three weeks, Miss Smith is the center of the commotion.

Three weeks of mysterious blasts along the Eastern Seaboard have led scientists to explore a number of explanations, but a11 they seem agreed on is that the blasts are strong and atmospheric, originating tens of miles off shore.
The Asia Society, ending a lengthy search, has purchased a site at the northeast corner of Park Avenue at 70th Street for a new cultural and educational building, the society confirmed yesterday.
Proposals by the New York Racing Association to set up its own system of telephone wagering received a conditional stamp of approval yesterday from the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

A 33-year-old queens civic leader, Phillip Jackson, who was to have given an award to Mayor Beame was eulogized by the Mayor instead at a civic reception last night as the police searched for a youth who shot and killed Mr. Jackson Wednesday night in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The United States, in a move with important policy implications, informed the Sudan recently that it was now willing to sell it a squadron of 12 F-5 fighter aircraft, American officials said today.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22 (AP) Argentina's navy chief said in a statement published yesterday that it was time for the military junta to carry out its original agreement, which would mean reducing the authority of President Jorge Videla, the army commander and a junta member.

The Canadian Government's announcement that it will no linger promote trade with South Africa is a useful reminder that there exists a range of steps short of boycott or embargo to bring pressure against the Pretoria regime. Ottawa's actions are ones which the United States and other nations that trade with South Africa should emulate.
Dr. Babette May Levy, an educator and author, died Wednesday night in the Birchwood Nursing Home, Huntington, L.I. She was 69 years old and had lived in Amherst, Va.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Dec. 22 (AP) The police manned buses traveling to black townships tonight after four days of disturbances in which the police reported shooting two blacks to death and wounding an unknown number.

Blanca Lazo Steinman, who retired in 1970 as a protocol specialist on guests from Spain and Latin America at the Carlyle Hotel here, died Wednesday in the DeWitt Nursing Home here. She was 87 years old and had lived at the Carlyle.
Dr. Bruno Puetzer, retired vice president of Schenley Industries, died of a heart attack at his home on Saturday. qe was 79 years old and lived at 1449 California Road, in Tuckahoe, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 A suggestion by a former high Treasury official to link the dollar, the Japanese yen and the West German mark into a zone of predetermined relationships is getting some attention in Washington in the debate over monetary management.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) Fortyseven senators have asked President Fidel Castro of Cuba to release three political prisoners said to be in need of medical attention.

Nine-year-old Melinda Hasbrouck of Summit penned her letter to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund on yellow-trimmed stationery that depicted a little girl watching a fluttering butterfly.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The HouseSenate energy conference buried the latest proposed natural gas compromise today and quit for a month.

HILLSBOROUGH, N.J. The object was to banish the rowhouse look while building suburban townhouses to a density of eight units to the acre. The solution, now in construction at a place called the Meadows of Hillsborough, is unusual suburban housing quadrangles of fourplexes facing outward around an interior court for cars and garaging. Sixteen townhouses to a court, and no one sees his neighbor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 Sam Brown, director of ACTION, the umbrella agency for Federal volunteer programs, today ordered the cancellation of a $50,740 contract because of "the appearance of" a conflict of interest. His agency signed the contract last Sept. 30.

GTE Sylvania Corporation was accused yesterday of paying nearly $12,000 in bribes to a New York City subway engineer who allegedly demanded the money for changing the specifications of $3.5 million in light bulb contracts.

ATLANTA, Dec. 22 R. Eugene Holley, for eight years the chairman of the Georgia Senate Banking and Finance Committee, is not as well known as a fellow financially troubled Georgia millionaire, Bert Lance, but his meteoric financial career, like Mr. Lance's, suggests that banking and politics can go hand in hand. When they do, banking regulations do not always forestall high-risk banking practices.

Oillian Sorensen, the wife of Theodore C. Sorensen, will head the city's United Nations office under Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch, according to the Koch transition office. She would succeed Mrs. John L. Loeb, who has held the unsalaried job under Mayors Lindsay and Beame.

A correction officer at the House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island has been charged in an indictment with accepting a $500 bribe from a prisoner to whom he allegedly delivered hacksaw blades and a knife and a $100 bribe from a prisoner to whom he allegedly promised to deliver marijuana.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that he strongly disagrees with President Carter's selection of Braniff Airways instead of Pan American World Airways for non-stop service between Dallas-Fort Worth and London.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The Federal Government, in a move that officials have said could save taxpayers as much as $15 million next year and improve flood insurance coverage, announced today that it would take over the $36 billion program that protects homeowners and small businesses in flood-prone parts of the country.

MADRID, Dec. 22 (Agence France-Presse) All parties in the Spanish Parliament signed a telegram sent today to Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, asking for a "just and lasting" settlement in the Western Sahara.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 22 Prime Minister Menahem Begin received a unanimous endorsement today from Israel's Cabinet on the peace plan that he will formally present to President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt when the two leaders meet in Ismailia, on the west bank of the Suez Canal, on Sunday.

SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, Dec. 22 (Reuters) Hostages who had been held captive by a Filipino gunman for two and a half days beat him over the head and shot him to death today at a bank on the American naval base here.

Representatives of the three commercial networks and the Public Broadcasting Service will jointly interview President Carter from the White House in a live telecast next Wednesday evening, just before his trip abroad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named six Americans, including a woman, as finalists for one of two scientist seats aboard the first Spacelab, a science laboratory to be orbited in the cargo bay of the space shuttle in March 1980.
Two financial institutions have agreed to put up $100 million to reconstruct the Commodore Hotel, asd work will begin in February, Donald Trump, the developer, announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, Dec. 22 (AP) The Crimean Tatar nationalist Mustafa Dzhemilev has been released from prison after completing a two-and-a- half-year term, dissident sources said today.

Three weeks of mysterious blasts along the Eastern Seaboard have led scientists to explore a number of explanations, but all they seem agreed on is that the blasts are strong and atmospheric, originating tens of miles off shore.
Governor Carey yesterday named Thomas R. Frey, a Democratic Assemblyman from Rochester, to the post of Director of State Operations, one of the administration's most powerful jobs.

ALGIERS, Dec. 22 (Agence FrancePresse) The Polisario guerrillas said here today that two French air force Jaguar fighters had been brought down, killing the pilot of one of them, and three others hit by Saharan ground fire in operations in Mauritania and Western Sahara since Dec. 2.

Max Euwe, the president of the International Chess Federation, has been summoned from the Netherlands, Yugoslavia, in a last-ditch effort to salvage the world championship challengers match between Boris Spassky and Viktor Korchnoi.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) In a major policy change, the Army is opening missile units and other combat support assignments to women. The decision means that women may be exposed to hostile fire in a war.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (Reuters) The State Department said today that the United States and the Soviet Union had made progress in talks last week on regulating naval forces in the Indian Ocean.

President Carter gave travelers from Atlanta, Cleveland and Kansas City something to cheer about this week when he approved non-stop air service to Europe from these and eight other American cities. But his action will bring no joy to New York City, which may lose hundreds of flights a year as well as hundreds of jobs to other airports.

TOKYO, Dec. 22 (AP) The dollar rose here today to 241,275 yen, compared with 240,725 yen at the close yesterday, as conversions of yen bonds into dollars increased and the markets reacted to President Carter's statement on the dollar.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Dec. 22 (UPI) Herbert Plank scored his second World Cup downhill ski victory of the season today and helped to silence the "cuckoo-clock controversy" that had soured the sporting rivalry between the Austrian and Italian teams.

PARIS, Dec. 22 The battered dollar rebounded sharply on European currency markets today, following President Carter's suggestion yesterday that the United States might actively defend its value and the decision of oil-exporting countries not to increase the price of oil.

OTTAWA, Dec. 22 The Canadian Government announced plans today for the first stage of a $1.5 billion ship replacement program to upgrade this country's contribution to the North Atlantic Treaty Organizatibn and strengthen the naval role in national defense.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 22 (AP) South Carolina scored the first 7 points in overtime tonight and defeated Southern California, 65-58, in the opening game of the Carolina Classic tournament. Both teams now have 5-4 records.

IMMEDIATELY, the good news: Angela Lansbury is coming back in a musical. It will be "Sweeney Todd," in which she will co-star with Len Cariou, but which, unfortunately, will not get here until next season. This is the musical for which Stephen Sondheim is doing the music and lyrics and Hugh Wheeler the book, and for which Hal Prince will be the director.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 22 Prime Minister Kriangsak Chamanand, accompanied by senior Thai military officers, left today for a two-day visit to the Cambodian frontier, amid mounting concern over intensified border skirmishes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) An offduty police detective was shot to death early today in a burglary and officers arrested a man free on bail for a murder that occurred in the same building earlier thi syear.

The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, yesterday announced price increases of 5.5 percent for most its steel products, a level in line with the advances of other major steel companies this week.
Christmas shoppers in the state are spending more freely than ever before, elated merchants and managers reported yesterday.
With the days running out, the master sat in his elegantly appointed office and talked about his abdication. The master is a small figure, dwarfed by the chair he sat in.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 22 Four years after shocking the world with a sudden, fourfold increase in crude oil prices, the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are worried about the possibility of basic disunity developing over the price question.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 22 (AP) Baseball leaders from Cuba and the United States met today to discuss a CubanAmerican all-star series, but no decision was made.

ATLANTA, Dec. 22 Minute samples of an influenza virus that has caused widespread illness in the Soviet Union and Hong Kong were distributed here today to vaccine manufacturers to enable them to grow it and study it while other experts try to assess its threat to the American population.
RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 22 (AP) Jay Jorgensen made six free throws in the last 1:21 of the game to help Fairleigh Dickinson University to a 6154 victory over North Carolina A. T. tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The Government is moving for the first time to impose Federal standards to protect the public from cancer-causing chemicals now believed to contaminate much of the nation's drinking water supply.

Bruce Campbell and Dwight Williams combined for 35 points as Providence College survived a late threat and beatCalifornia State at Bakersfield, 72-70, tonight for the Friars' sixth victory without a defeat.

TOKYO, Dec. 22 Spurred by the demands of its major trading partners, Japan has drafted an expansionary fiscal 1978 budget designed to increase its purchases overseas and reduce its multi-billion dollar trade surplus.
The Federal Commodity Futures Trading Commission cited two leading brokerage houses yesterday for allegedly violating futures trading rules.

In January 1971, Jim Zeitler coached the first girl to participate in a boys' track meet in New York State. Now, almost seven years after Anita Scandurra's appearance, Zeitler, the boys' and girls' track coach at Harborfield in Suffolk County, is spearheading a drive to get the county's girls' indoor track program going on its own.

CAIRO, Dec. 22 Egyptian officials said today that Cairo had received assurances that Prime Minister Menahem Begin, at his meeting with President Anwar elSadat on Sunday, would take a substantially more forthcoming position on the crucial Palestinian issue than he did publicly during his recent trip to Washington and New York.

Detectives investigating the shooting death of an off-duty police officer and the wounding of another man in the hallway of a Harlem tenement on Wednesday night were waiting for ballistics tests yesterday to determine if a third person had shot the two men. The officer's service revolver was not found at the scene.

John Schumacher, who was dismissed in October as chairman of the Bonwit Teller retail chain, has been charged by Genesco Inc. Bonwit's parent company, with allegedly diverting funds, labor and materials from the remodeling of Bonwit's Fifth Avenue store in 1976 and 1977 to renovating his own Park Avenue triplex apartment.
For two days and nights, Rabbi Osher Shoretz patrolled the kitchens of the Waldorf-Astoria to make sure that the first ever gourmet kosher meal there really would be kosher.

CHRISTMAS in the country has always been special, and nowhere more so perhaps, than in the Hudson River environment of Washington Irving, America's first impor tant author, and of the wealthier Frederick Philipse and Pierre Van Cortlandt, who owned much of what is now Westchester County.
PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 22 (AP) James Bailey scored 39 points to lead Rutgers to a 91-76 victory over Manhattan tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 President Carter, in a decision that distresses the military, has approved a defense budget of $126 billion for the next fiscal year. The figure is about $4 billion lower than that sought by Defense Secretary Harold Brown.

As the dark envelops New York late this afternoon, the ad hoc Christmas tree that is the Empire State Building, swathed in garish green and red lights for the holiday season, towers over a city that is slowing down for the Christmas weekend.

Neil Papiano, handling Charles O. Finley's legal battles on two fronts, expressed hope yesterday that Commissioner Bowie Kuhn would soon let him know what problems he might see in Finley's Vida Blue deal with the Cincinnati Reds.

Jim Ringo was dismissed yesterday as coach of the Buffalo Bills following a season in which his team lost 11 of its 14 games. That record was good for a tie for last place with the Jets in the American Conference. Eastern Division, and the only teams with lesser records were Kansas City and Tampa Bay, both 2-12.

ONE of the trans-Atlantic sleepers of the year that has gained wide acceptance in academic circles and with the public as well is the biography "Caught in the Web of Words: James A.H. How the book came to be published by Yale University Press instead of Oxford University Press is one of the book adventure stories of 1977.

The Minnesota Vikings lost another offensive player yesterday, Brent McClanahan, which made the National Football League's upcoming four divisional playoff games even more of a black-white-and-gray proposition.

Stein yesterday promised an "activist" term as Borough President.

Enid Sillcox Darlington and Fred E. Brown of Harding Township, N.J., were married yesterday in St. Eustace Episcopal Church in Lake Placid, N.Y. Mr. Brown is chairman and chief executive officer of the Tri-Continental Corporation. The Rev. William L. Hayes performed the ceremony.

TRENTON, Dec. 22 New Jersey's economy should grow at a faster rate next year than the national average, the state's Economic Policy Council forecast today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 22 Following two recounts, a judge today declared last month's election for First Selectman of Greenwich a tie the first such in the state and both candidates agreed to participate in a new election.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 22 An Israeli official said today that it was "quite possible" for Israel eventually to agree to full withdrawal from Sinai and a restoration of Egyptian sovereignty providing that there was increased American surveillance, possibly in conjunction with the United Nations.

WITH a revival of the 1950's now in progress, it was probably inevitable that 10th Street one of the more fondly remembered scenes of the art world of the period would sooner or later be given its due. And so it now has in a mammoth show called "Tenth Street Days: The Co-ops of the 1950's" spread out in five galleries in or adjacent to SoHo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 At the end of his first calendar year in the White House, Jimmy Carter is getting what Damon Runyon used to call "a medium hello," and it's not surprising. All of our last four Presidents have dropped points in the popularity polls during their first year, except Kennedy, but Mr. Carter has slipped more in his first 12 months than any of them except President Ford.
Prices of precious metals bounded upward yesterday after Handy Harmon, the big metals refiners, forecast $200 gold and $5 silver before the end of 1978.
After more than 20 years with KSW and its predecessor agency, the Konica Camera Company, Woodside, Queens, is switching it account to Philip Stogel. The billings are around $1.5 million.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) The United States today hailed the decision by the worlds major oil producers to freeze the price of crude oil, at least temporarily, and said it would help keep the United States economy growing and dampen inflation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The Carter Administration has decided to appeal a Federal court decision that held that former President Richard M. Nixon and two of his top aides had violated the constitutional rights of a former White House staffmember by allowing a wiretap to remain on his home telephone for 21 months, Justice Department Officials said today.

COLUMBIA, N.C. Affirmativeaction policies affect more than the life of one individual. The results of such policies can change the life and expectations of a whole people, for they change the way people view themselves and the world around them. One member of a disadvantaged minority on a job that formerly had been forever closed to him says to many, many others similarly situated, "You, too, can have a chance."

As her ballet world turns, Emilia is announcing to her family that she has reached "the fork in the road": A famous New York company, dancing at her hometown auditorium in Oklahoma City for two nights, has suddenly invited her to join it.
UNIONDALE, L.I, Dec. 22 Bring on Montreal! That was the Islanders' theme tonight as they beat the St. Louis Blues, 6-3, at Nassau Coliseum.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 22 A Lebanese Christian leader insisted today on the withdrawal of all Palestinians from Lebanon as a condition for national reconciliation from the deep divisions created by the civil war.
President Carter's choice on Wednesday of Braniff Airways to fly the new Dallas-to-London route instead of Pan American is likely to have little immediate impact on the profits of either carrier.

State Comptroller Arthur Levitt, reviewing the 53 audits of the Medicaid program that his department has performed since Medicaid began 11 years ago, said that the state had saved a half billion dollars by implementing his suggestions but had passed up another 400 million by not doing more.

There is a new and controversial trend in recruiting by corporations that may affect many college seniors in the peak January-through-March recruiting period. It involves prescreening, a tactic to cut the number of students the corporate recruiter interviews when makes an annual visit to the campus.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 22 When President Carter arrives in India on New Year's Day, he will find a Government eager to maintaining much friendlier relationship with the United States, and a people who seem delighted to welcome him here.
A recovery in the sagging dollar in foreign-exchange trading fueled a sharp stock market rally in Wall Street yesterday on heavy volume.
Seventy-four young women were presented at the 42d annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

JERUSALEM, Dec 22-Prime Minister Menahem Begin received a unanimous endorsement today from Israel's Cabinet on the peace plan that he will formally present to President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt when the two leaders meet in Ismailia, on the west bank of the Suez Canal, on Sunday.
Leo Perper, for many years president of the Roger Kent clothing-store chain and a devoted patron of the performing arts, died yesterday in New York. He was 83 years old.
TOKYO, Dec. 22 (AP) Chen Shao-min, a prominent Chinese woman labor leader, died Dec. 14 in Peking, it was reported today. She was 75 years old.
CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., Dec. 22 Governor Cyril E. King, who has an inoperable tumor of the stomach, stepped down this afternoon, turning the office temporarily over to Lieut. Gov. Juan Luis.

TRENTON, DEC. 22 (AP) Two reporters appeared under subpoena in Federal Court here today in an inquiry to determine the anonymous source of information sent to their newspapers concerning a banking matter.

Mayor-elect Edward I. Koch had his first confrontation with organized labor yesterday at a meeting of the Emergency Financial Control Board and while labor put up a hard, well-orchestrated fight, Mr. Koch won.

Fortunately for the Pulettis, the weather was cold enough in November so that they were able to store their perishable foods in their driveway. Their refrigerator, along with their furniture and books, had been ruined on Nov. 9.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 22 The president of the Lakeland School Board resigned his post yesterday almost six weeks after district teachers went back to work, ending the longest, school strike in New York State's history.

THE 92d STREET Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. has its own special chamber-music organization, which is headby the violinist Jaime Laredo. Also a member of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Mr. Laredo is trying to do in a modest way what that august group does at Alice Tully Hall. If the "Y" programs are fewer and less ambitious, they at least have outstanding talent at their disposal.

LOS ANGELES. Dec. 22 Elisita S. Hill, a pioneer in the bilingual education of deaf children, died at Northbridge Hospital last night of the effects of a stroke suffered on Oct. 28. She was 66 years old.

When Josephine Striano was a little girl, she used to accompany her father on his business calls. Yesterday she joined her father and three brothers in their chosen calling, She became the first woman in New York City to become a licensed master plumber.

PLAINS, Ga., Dec. 22 President Carter, home for the holidays, visited with friends and relatives in this little south Georgia village today, answered a few questions from reporters, bought a hunting license and took off into the countryside to do some quail shooting.
The problem was: Since Mayorelect Edward I. Koch has promised that all his deputies will be "equal,' which deputy would get the big office next door to the Mayor's?

A CERTAIN tension is evident, both in and out of the Metropolitan Museum, over the length of time the Met is tak ing to find a new management team; a paid president and a director to replace Thomas Hoving, who on Dec. 31 retires officially from the directorial post.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (Ap) The Army announced today that it would test a new computerized system that would speed mobilization of 160,000 reservists in a major crisis.

CHRISTMAS brings the traditional programming package of holiday reruns, old movies, live pickups of caroling and religi ous ceremonies around the world and a sprinkling of fresh specials. As usual on Christmas Eve, WPIX will supply canned music to the filmed visual accompaniment of a burning Yule log. The ultimate exercise in make-believe gets under way at 9 P.M. tomorrow.
The incoming Koch administration has devised a plan to allow public-school students to remain in their home schools to avoid disrupting their studies when their families move.

Viji Prakash of Bombay, India, who has performed Bharat Natyam, the centuries-old Indian classical dance, in Asia, Europe and this country, will give a recital tonight at the Hindu Temple Society's Cultural Center in Flushing, Queens.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 22 (UPI) South Carolina rallied to defeat Southern California. 65-58, in overtime and Oklahoma defeated Pennsylvania, 8074, tonight in the opening round of the Carolina Classic basketball tournament.

TRENTON, Dec. 22 Three New York state Assemblymen came here today to discuss New Jersey's school-financing mechanism, including the state income tax and the laws that place limits on spending by state and local governments and by school districts.
John W. O'Connor, a former head of the Paper Corporation of the United States, died Tuesday at his home after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 8 Bobbie Lane, Rye,N.Y.

RICHFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 22 Spencer Haywood, restored to the Knicks' starting lineup, scored 20 points and Bob McAdoo, making 13 of 25 shots, scored 35 tonight. But neither they nor the other Knicks could make a basket over the last 6 minutes 36 seconds and that paved the way for the Cleveland Cavaliers to post a 112-100 triumph.

If there had been a prize for the best-played hand at the Winter Regionat Championship in New York a week ago, it might well have gone to Larry Edwards of New York for the diagramed deal. He reached a normal contract of three no-trump after a Stayman auction, and reached an unusual ending to make nine tricks.

With sonic booms apparently eliminated, attention focused yesterday on the possibility that the rumbles and sharp blasts heard along the last Coast in recent seeks were explosions of huge methane gas bubbles erupting through one or more faults beneath the sea.
TOKYO, Dec. 23 (AP)--The dollar rose marginally for the second straight day against the yen today in a generally steady and quiet market.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23 (AP)--Al Wood and Mike O'Koren scored 21 points each to lead third-ranked North Carolina to a 108-103 victory over Tulane tonight. It was the most points North Carolina has scored in a game this season and also the most points given up by the Tar Heels in a game this season.
With some grunting, groaning and argument, but with essentially unslackened impetus, the nation is moving into the second half of a decade-long effort to eradicate water pollution.

RENO (UPI)--A mile-long Southern Pacific freight train was forced to slam on its brakes to avoid hitting a pedestrian standing on the tracks in downtown Reno. The man was escorted safely from the tracks. However, the train's diesel engine stalled, traffic was blocked for 30 minutes before engineers could restart them.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (Reuters)--The police today ruled out as a possible "Hillside strangler" suspect a 30-year-old man who on Wednesday allegedly tried to pull a teen-age girl into an auto looking like a black and white police car.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 23 (AP)--Led by James Lee and Chuck Aleksinas, two reserves, top-ranked Kentucky outscored Iona, 19-2 in one span of the first half tonight and eased home from there for a 104-65 college basketball victory.
The stock market staged a rousing preChristmas rally yesterday to cap three days of steadily rising prices. Advances on the New Yerk Stock Exchange outnumbered losers by a 10-to-4 ratio.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (Reuters)--In the last eight years the number of blacks holding elective office has more than tripled but is still far from representative of the black population, according to a survey released here today.

The New York State Liquor Authority moved yesterday to stop Plato's Retreat from serving liquor because, it said, the club catered to "swingers" and encouraged sexual relations on its premises among its patrons.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 23 (UPI)-- Mayor Charles Stanton announced today that Manchester might soon become the home of a sports arena that could attract such events as the Eastern College Athletic Conference or National Collegiate Athletic Association postseason basketball tournaments.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 23 (UPI)-- Duke M. Fishman, an actor who gained fame as the bald strongman "Mr. Clean" in a television commercial for a detergent, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 71 years old.
MONTREAL, Dec. 23--Life in the upper stratosphere of the National Hockey League proved too heady for the Islanders tonight.

For many of the 188,000 striking members of the United Mine Workers, Christmas was brightened yesterday with payment of two weks' wages, the last pay the miners will see until two weeks after their walkout is settled, United Press International reported.

SAN MARINO, Calif., Dec. 23 (UPI)-- Judge E. Talbot Callister of Superior Court, who put Patricia Hearst on five years' probation last May for her part in a shooting at a sporting goods store, died at his home today of cancer. He was 52 years old.
Rachel Nason Zimmerman, who spent more than 30 years in government service specializing in human rights and problems facing women, died last Saturday in Albuquerque, N.M. She was 78 years old.
Jacques Tourneur, a French-born Hollywood director known chiefly for his macabre horror films, died Monday in Bergerac, France. He was 73 years old.

Although New York City's action on the proposed convention center seems regularly to consist of one step forward and two steps back, the recent report of the Advisory Committee on the Convention Center Site moves the decision-making process cautiously ahead. It would also move the preferred location of the center.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 23 (UPI)--The Coast Guard cutter Courageous escorted into port today a 100-foot Venezuelan ship loaded with 25 tons of marijuana, worth an estimated $18 million.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--With the fate of the President's energy package hanging in the balance, a House-Senate conference committee considering the legislation is stalemated as a result of failing to resolve the natural gas issue this week, according to Congressional sources.

WESTWEGO, La., Dec. 23 (UPI)--The portable floodlights were merciful. They pierced the night far enough to let the rescue workers do their job but not enough to show the deadly destruction of the nation's worst grain industry accident.
PARIS, Dec. 23 (AP)--Lotte Schone, a leading operatic soprano between the two world wars, died yesterday at her home in suburban Bobigny. She was 86 years old.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd is not entitled to retire next Saturday on a disability pension that would give him $46,600 a year tax free, New York City's Corporation Counsel said yesterday.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 23 (UPI)-- The state estimated today that rain and high winds that swept California this week caused $30 million damage to homes, business and agriculture. Eric Orme, assistant director of the Office of Emergency Services, said about 6,000 residences were damaged in three counties, causing $8 million damage, while 2,000 businesses were damaged at a cost of $2 million.
A.N. Spanel got a patent this week for a Barber King, a home hair cutter that is manufactured by Spanel International Ltd., a New York company of which he is president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI)--Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, will leave tomorrow on a Christmas goodwill mission to China and Japan, accompanied by members of his family and an adviser on Sino-American affairs.
PARIS, Dec. 23 (AP)--Lotte Schone, a leading operatic soprano between the two world wars, died yesterday at her home in suburban Bobigny. She was 86 years old.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 23--The Mexican Government's decision to postpone negotiations for natural gas sales to the United States is dependent on completion of the prolonged energy debate in the United States Congress, senior Mexican officials said today.

The marriage of Sandra Fay Larson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merle E. Larson of Hampton, Va., to John Hamilton Randolph took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edmund William Randolph 3d, in Yorktown, Va. The Rev. George Massay of the Grafton Christian Church performed the ceremony.

Tenants in city-owned buildings who find themselves without heat over the holiday weekend can call an emergency telephone number on Monday for heating repairs, according to Stephen Fisher, the city's Real Property Commissioner. The number is 566-2860.

DETROIT, Dec. 23--The nation's automobile industry, struggling to maintain the strong sales momentum built up earlier in the year, reported another decline today for the mid-December selling period.

WASHINGTON--The RCA Corporation believes that solar cells it is developing will be able to convert sunlight directly into electricity at costs competitive with conventional power sources by the mid-1980's. This week the company received what it regards as a basic patent on amorphous silicon semiconductor devices to be used in the cells.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 23 (AP)-- Tony Price and Keven McDonald led a surge in the second half that carried Pennsylvania to an 88-71 victory over Southern California in the consolation game of the Carolina Classic tonight.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 23 (UPI)--Five workers were killed and eight injured today when the roof of a sports hall under construction collapsed in Santiago, the second largest city in the Dominican Republic, authorities here said. Several of the injured were said to be in serious condition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--The United States has urged President Anwar elSadat of Eaypt and Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel to show the utmost sympathy for each other's political problems and to approach their meeting in Ismailia, Egypt, on Sunday with as openminded an attitude as possible to avoid setting back the prospects for an overall Middle East peace.

The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, which for nearly 40 years has devoted itself to contemporary art with increasing impact--it now averages more than 1,000 visitors a day--has begun a campaign to raise $20 million in the next five years.

Some capital-hungry utilities, pushing against their debt limits on one hand and hard put to sell common stock on the other, are going to considerable lengths to interest individual investors in preferred stock.

LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 23 (AP)--Bob Sirois scored two goals in 17 seconds and led the Washington Capitals to a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings, tonight.

In Zurich, sources in the government said that Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the exiled dissident Soviet writer, owed Switzerland $250,000 in back taxes. He established Swiss residence when he was expelled from the Soviet Union in 1974 but since August 1976 has been living in seclusion in Vermont.
SEATTLE, Dec. 23--Daniel Owings doesn't expect much of a Christmas in the Navy brig here, where he has been held without charges since late October.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP)--The White House today denied a televised report that the acting budget director, James T. McIntyre Jr., would be nominated next week to take over the post officially.

Governor Carey, continuing a Christmas tradition, yesterday commuted the sentences of six prison inmates, five of whom are serving sentences for marijuana offenses and a sixth who has been convicted of selling a small amount of heroin.

CAIRO, Dec. 23--Egyptian Officials predicted today that Prime Minister Menahem Begin's proposals to President Anwar el-Sadat Sunday would include a plan to give Palestinians in the West Bank of the Jordan interim self-rule for five years, after which they would go to the polls to vote on their future status.

LONDON, Dec. 23 (AP)--The dollar closed mostly down on European money markets today, and some dealers said President Carter's statements bolstering the dollar may not have the effect originally envisioned.

Building the Westway could create up to 10,000 more jobs than would result from using the funds for that project to construct a more modest road and make major mass-transit improvements, according to figures provided to Governor Carey and Mayar-elect Edward I. Koch by a special study panel.

JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 23 (AP)--The family of Stephen Biko, the leading black activity who died in the custody of the security police Sept. 12, sent letters to two Government ministers today demanding monetary damages, according to the office of an attorney for the family.

TRENTON, Dec. 23--Voter rejection of school construction referendums can be overturned by state education officials if they believe the capital projects are needed to insure an efficient educational system, the State Attorney General ruled today.

BUFFALO, Dec. 23--An explosion and spectacular fire this morning in an industrial storage tank spread a low-lying cloud of dense smoke and soot over Buffalo's northern suburbs, but only one person was injured Seriously.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 23--It may not be winner-take-all when the Oakland Raiders play the Baltimore Colts here tomorrow in the opening round of the National Football League playoffs, but it certainly is loser-take-none. The playoffs are a single-elimination tournament, and no team knows that better than the Raiders, the defending Super Bowl champions. They won it all last year, obviously because they didn't lose.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI)--Dr. Bertram S. Brown, the Government's mental health chief, has been dismissed by Joseph Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, who said today that while Dr. Brown had done a fine job, the program needed "fresh blood."
GENEVA, Dec. 23--Philippe Etter, who was Switzerland's Minister of the Interior for 25 years, died today in Bern. He was 86 years old.

BETHLEHEM, W. Va., Dec. 21-- When Tim McDonald and his wife Andrea want to put the fear of Santa Claus in the minds of their three young children, they do not threaten that misbehavior will produce coal in stockings on Christmas morning.
TUPELO, Miss., Dec. 23 (AP)--One 51yeas-old man died today of burns suffered in an explosion yesterday at a dog food plant here, and five others injured in the blast remained in critical condition.

LONDON, Dec. 23--Eric Ashley Sutcliffe-Smith, a former member of the London Stock Exchange, died on Tuesday at his home in Balcombe, in Sussex. He was 66 years old.

HOUSTON, Dec. 23 (AP)T--wo AWOL soldiers who stowed away, on a west German cargo ship were hospitalized in fair condition today after spending two weeks, apparently without food or water, in a cargo container carried by the ship from Europe.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP)--A temporary restraining order against Charles O. Finley and Marvin Davis was dissolved today and Oakland Coliseum officials agreed to meet next week with Finley, the owner of the Oakland A's.

New York City, where tourists are counted like money in the bank, attracted a record total of 16.75 million visitors who pumped an estimated $1.6 billion into the local economy in 1977, the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau reported yesterday.

The National Football League was in contact with a fourth television news show last Monday about the advisability of replaying the controversial "fumble" by Bert Jones, it was learned yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (AP)--Two of nine known cases of the legionnaires' disease since last May have ended in death at a Veterans Administration Hospital in West Los Angeles, according to Dr. Earl Gordon, the hospital's chief of staff. He said that he did not consider the incidence of the pneumonia-like disease an outbreak or an epidemic and that no special precautions were being taken.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 23 (AP)--An Eritrean secessionist leader said today his movement was willing to discuss peace with Ethiopia if Ethiopia's military Government recognized the principle of independence for its Eritrean and Somalipopulated areas, Somalia's official radio reported.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 23 (AP)-- Yugoslav organizers of the world chess championship challengers' match today postponed until Monday the 12th game of the stalled 20-game contest between Viktor Korchnoi and Boris Spassky. They said their decision had the support of Max Euwe, the president of the International Chess Federation.

Freddie Laker, the ebullient Londoner who has made the "Laker Skytrain" if not a household word, at least a common boardroom word in the airline industry, brought controversy, publicity and, most important, low fares to the New YorkLondon air corridor this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--Despite President Carter's announcement earlier this week that he planned to complete an executive order pulling together United States intelligence surveillance priorities, which are now in disarray, knowledgeable Administration officials said that the new disposition will leave important issues unresolved.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 23 (AP)--A Common Market official predicted today that the organization would announce late next week a minimum import price for steel to protect jobs and business in the West European steel industry.

FALLSTON, N.C., Dec. 23 (UPI)--Six persons, five of them children, died today in a fire that swept a small frame home where 14 persons, believed to be members of two separate families, were staying. When the St. Louis Art Museum started planning its renovation in 1971, the New York architectural firm of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates came up with a radical idea to do as little as possible. QUEBEC, Dec. 28 (AP) The Soviet Union rallied after trailing by 2-0 and defeated Canada, 3-2, in the first game of the A Division final in the Junior World Cup hockey tournament.

THE MUSIC P.D.Q. Bach is untiringly disinterred by Prof. Peter Schickele, who sees fit to present his new finds to New York audiences as a kind of holiday gift each year. After five months of studying last July's systemwide power blackout, the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday announced a five-year, $65 million program of technical steps intended to prevent a recurrence.

The deaths of Elvis Presley and Bing Crosby, two of the most successful recording artists in history, have created a commercial bonanza for the nation's record industry. An unexpected surge in demand for new copies of their old records has strained capacity throughout the industry and forced delays in producing new releases.

Union College will not play tonight and tomorrow in its own hockey tournament at its home base in Schenectady, N.Y., nor against Clarkson next Tuesday. As it happens, Union has had 10 cancel all the games.

JUST about the surest way to invite a ski accident is to set off on the slopes before your body is in shape for strenuous sport. Even if you are an experienced skier, if you haven't been on skis since last winter, all experts warn that you are asking for trouble if you plunge in before your muscles are ready.

IN THREE weeks Verdi's "II Trovatore" will be 125 years old, a success from the day it first saw the light of a stage in Rome. It is a perennial favorite despite the fact that relatively few people who know and love music are able to give a coherent account of the plot.

Priscilla B. Hoefer, an editor with the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company in New York City for 34 years, died last Saturday in her home, 175 East 74th Street, Manhattan, after a lingering illness. She was 62 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) In the 11 months since Jimmy Carter became President, members of his family have enjoyed a windfall of nearly a million dollars from ventures ranging from well- paid public appearances and product endorsements to books by several family members.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 28 (UPI) Guyana has sold 25,000 tons of alumina to the Soviet Union for delivery during the first quarter of 1978, the first ever sale from Guyana's bauxite industry to the Russians.
The stock market, lifted by selected buying late in the session, finished slightly higher yesterday as trading volume expanded from Tuesday's slow pace.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 28 A 1975 state police investigation that indicated extensive corruption within the Stamford Police Department was terminated that year by State Police Commissioner Edward P. Leonard despite repeated pleas by investigators in his department for followup inquiries, it has been learned.

Dr. Howard B. Shookhoff, an authority on tropical diseases and an epidemiologist, died Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 67 years old and lived at 550 Fieldstone Road in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

Edith Sillcox Kelly of Montclair, N. J., widow of Frank A. Kelly, was married yesterday in the Unitarian Church of Montclair to Conrad Frederick Reiman Jr. of Orange, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald Kinloch Edmonds of Glasgow and Norfolk, Va.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 On the eve of his departure, President Carter immersed himself today in preparations for his second trip abroad a six-nation tour covering 18,500 miles.

New York State will break a $1 million ad campaign next week that is aimed at keeping New York businesses in New York. In print and on radio, the advertising will respond to negative attitudes quantified in two studies by Yankelovich, Skelly White, the research firm.

THE CHAMBER Dance Group was formed by Nanette Bearden and William Scott two years ago as an outlet for the talents of black dancers and choreographers. Several of the interracial company's 14 members have performed with the Dance Theater of Harlem and George Faison's Universal Dance Experience. The rest are part of that floating body of gypsies whom dancegoers see only sporadically but, when they do view the troupe, are sometimes touched.

Marc Bonnefous, who tried unsuccessfully to negotiate the freedom of hostages aboard a hijacked Air France jet in Entebbe, Uganda in July 1976 was named French Ambassador to Israel yesterday. Israeli commandos later freed the hostages in a daring raid on the airport. Ambassador Bonnefous, a 53-year-old career diplomat, has held embassy posts in Algeria and Peru.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 2--King Hussein of Jordan said today that he had seen nothing in the Israeli peace proposal offered to Egypt last week that could form the basis for a negotiated solution of the Arab-Israeli dispute.

Joy suffuses the Brooklyn community that "adopted" 13 Jewish women from Syria last August because next month the first of them will be married, and within a few weeks two others will also become brides.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--After more than a year of investigations into the Korean scandal by the Department of Justice and the House ethics committee, there is no light at the end of the tunnel.

Mayor Koch said yesterday he would issue an executive order to ban discrimination against homosexuals by the city government--guaranteeing, among other things, their right to be hired as policemen and firemen.

ROME, Jan. 2 (Reuters)--Unidentified extremists today attempted to set fire to a Communist Party office in the northern city of Udine and Christian Democratic offices in Bologna and Bergamo. No serious damage was reported.

HIGHTSTOWN, Jan. 2--This tiny Mercer County borough has been offered $6,000 for four cannons surrounding a monument erected soon after the Civil War in honor of New Jersey troops who served in that conflict.

The Volkswagen Manufacturing Corporation of America announced yesterday that it would assume operation today of a million-square-foot metal stamping plant in South Charleston, W.Va., thus completing a transaction started 11 months ago when it purchased the facility from the American Motors Corporation.

The correct terms involve an offer by Humana to pay $15 in cash plus half of a $25 preferred share, or a total of $27.50, for each of 5.7 million American Medicorp shares.

DENVER, Jan. 2 (AP)--An attorney for Ron Lyle, the world-ranked boxer, said today that Mr. Lyle would plead not guilty to any charges in connection with the fatal shooting of his former trainer on New Year's Eve.

Long-term Government and corporate bond yields ended 1977 at their highest levels since August 1976, and most other interest rates climbed during the year. Former Ambassador Robert D. Murphy, the career diplomat credited with planning the Allied invasion of North Africa in World War II, died yesterday at his home at 1009 Park Avenue. He was 83 years old and had been ill since suffering a stroke last November.

LOWRY, Minn., Jan. 9 (AP)--Protesters who oppose the construction of a power line across an area of rich farmland faced a large contingent of state troopers today and offered them plastic carnations and cookies while the troopers stood by to protect construction crews.
TOKYO, Jan. 9 (AP)--Production of Japan's seven largest shipbuilders in 1977 dropped 37.9 percent in tonnage from the preceding year, the Shipbuilders' Association of Japan reported today.

A Coast Guard spokesman said that there appeared to be no spillage.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 9--Introducing the Begin Government's first national budget bill in Parliament, Finance Minister Simha Ehrlich predicted today that prices would rise by about 30 percent this year.

Adele Strauss Allen, a civic leader who helped found the Women's Auxiliary of the French Hospital in 1914, died yesterday at University Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived at the Peter Coopar Hotel, at 130 East 39th Street.

NEVADA CITY, Calif., Jan. 9 (UPI)-- Darius Pahlavi Hillyer, a nephew of the Shah of Iran, pleaded not guilty today to charges of assaulting two police officers after a high-speed auto chase in November. Judge Frank Francis of Nevada County Superior Court ordered Mr. Hillyer, a, 20-year-old college student, to go on trial March 14 on two felony counts of battery.
